Sec. 1-10. - Disposition of fines and penalties. 
    All fines and penalties for the violation of any ordinance or any order of the city council shall, when recovered, inure to the use of the city, and be paid into the city treasury, unless it is otherwise directed by law or ordinance. 
(Code 1971,  1-9) 
Sec. 1-11. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the city council that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code. 
(Code 1971,  1-10) 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, ch. 9; community services department, ch. 11; personnel, ch. 12; planning and development, ch. 13; police, ch. 14; purchasing, ch. 15; rules of council, app. A. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Description of city seal. 
    The seal of the city shall be in the form of a circle 13/4 inches in diameter with the following device: A representation of the General Shepard Monument on a pedestal and a flight of steps; within an inner circle the inscription "Incorporated a Town 1669, a City 1920"; within the outer circle the words "Seal of the City of Westfield, Mass." 
(Code 1971,  2-1) 
State Law reference- Seal, M.G.L.A. c. 40,  47 . 
Sec. 2-2. - Custody, use of city seal. 
    The city clerk shall be custodian of the city seal and shall affix, or permit any duly authorized city officer to affix the same to any deed, bond, lease, indenture or instrument executed by the city, which requires a seal. 
(Code 1971,  2-2) 
State Law reference- Custodian of city seal, M.G.L.A. c. 40,  47; unauthorized use of city seal, M.G.L.A. c. 268,  35. 
Sec. 2-3. - Decals on city-owned motor vehicles. 
    Every motor vehicle owned, registered and/or insured by the city shall bear an official city decal affixed to the sides of such vehicle. Each department head shall ensure that all vehicles under his control bear such decals; the only exception to this requirement shall be vehicles designated by the chief of police for special departmental use. The official city decals shall be in the custody of and issued from the office of the mayor. 
(Code 1971,  2-2.1) 
Cross reference- Traffic and motor vehicles, ch. 17. 
Sec. 2-4. - City flag. 
    The city hereby adopts a city flag in details as follows: 
(1)  Color. White background. Lines of circles-seal scarlet. Lettering and statue-black. 
(2)  Design. A seal having the general appearance of the seal of the city shall appear on both sides of the flag and shall be located in the center of a white background. The seal will be composed of an outer circle and a partial inner circle. Within these circles will be a facsimile of the General Shepard statue located on the base in the center. Within the outer circle at the top will be the words "City of Westfield," and in the bottom half of the circle "1669 Town-City 1920." Directly under the statue and in the inner circle will be the letters "Inc." 
(3)  Size of seal. On a three-foot by five-foot flag, the seal will be 24 inches in diameter. On a 4 1/3 -foot by 51/2-foot flag, the seal will be 36 inches in diameter. 
The flag shall be in substantial conformity with a design executed by the W. M. Young Regalia Company, Inc., which design shall be filed in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1971,  2-3) 
Sec. 2-5. - Wards. 
    The territory of the city is divided into six wards, each composed of precincts designated A and B; the territory of each ward to conform with its established precinct boundaries. 
Ward One: The territory comprising Ward One of the City of Westfield is hereby established: 
Beginning at the intersection of the middle line of the Westfield River at the Russell and Montgomery town lines, thence northerly along the Montgomery town line to the Southampton town line, thence easterly along the Southampton town line to the intersection of Southampton Road, thence southerly along Southampton Road to North Elm Street, thence southerly on North Elm Street to the intersection of the middle line of the Westfield River, thence westerly along the middle line of the Westfield River to the intersection of the Russell and Montgomery town lines and the point of beginning. 
Ward Two: The territory comprising Ward Two of the City of Westfield is hereby established:

Beginning at the intersection of Southwick Road with the shore of the Little River, thence easterly, northeasterly, and northerly along the Little River to the intersection of the Westfield River, thence easterly along the shore of the Westfield River to the intersection of Springfield Road at the East Main Street bridge, thence easterly along Springfield Road to the Agawam town line, thence southerly along the Agawam town line to the Southwick town line, thence westerly along the Southwick town line to the intersection of Hillside Road, thence northerly along Hillside Road to the intersection of Heggie Drive, thence northerly along Heggie Drive to the intersection of Valley View Drive, thence northerly along Valley View Drive to City View Road, thence easterly along City View Road to the intersection of Southwick Road, then northerly to the shore of Little River and the place of beginning.

(Code 1971,  2-4; Ord. No. 1289, 9-6-01; Ord. No. 1312, 3-7-02; Ord. No. 1553, 11-3-11) 
Charter reference- Division of city into wards,  2.

(Ord. No. 908, 1-2-86; Ord. No. 1102, 4-1-93; Ord. No. 1112,  B, 6-17-93; Ord. No. 1289, 9-6-01; Ord. No. 1312, 3-7-02; Ord. No. 1553, 11-3-11) 
Sec. 2-7. - Performance by city of duty imposed upon person by Code. 
    In any case where a duty is imposed upon any person by any of the provisions of this Code, and a penalty is affixed for refusal or neglect to perform the same, and refusal or neglect to comply with such duty occurs, such duty may be performed by the city at the expense of the person liable to perform the same. Such expense may be recovered of such person by the city in an action of contract in the name of the city treasurer. 
(Code 1971,  2-12) 
Sec. 2-8. - Use of city-owned equipment in private business. 
    No city-owned equipment shall be loaned, rented or leased to any person for use in private business unless it is to be used in connection with work being done for the city. 
(Code 1971,  2-13) 
Sec. 2-9. - Annual reports required of departments and boards. 
    Each city department and board shall report annually to the city council. Such reports shall be delivered to the city clerk not later than November 30. 
(Code 1971,  2-11) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to require annual reports, M.G.L.A. c. 40,  21(12). 
Sec. 2-10. - Declaration of emergencies. 
    For purposes of declaration of an emergency to authorize civil defense activities pursuant to the Federal Emergency Management Act (FEMA) or any similar state law or city ordinance, there is hereby established the office of emergency declarant. If an emergency requires such declaration, but neither the mayor nor the city council president, as acting mayor, is within the city or unable to respond to an emergency, then the emergency declarant is authorized to do so. The authority of this office is limited to determining and declaring a state of emergency for the city to authorize civil defense activities pursuant to federal, state or local law. The position of emergency declarant shall be filled by the director of public health in the city. 
(Ord. No. 987,  2-24.1, 11-17-88) 
Secs. 2-11-2-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY COUNCIL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- City council, composition,  4; terms of members of certain boards; appointment,  10; salaries of mayor and council,  12; legislative powers of council; quorum; rules; role of city clerk,  26; vacancies in office of mayor or on city council; temporary appointment for certain appointed officers,  33. 
Cross reference- Rules of council, app. A. 

Sec. 2-36. - Regular council meetings. 
(a)  The regular meetings of the city council shall be held at the council chamber in the municipal building on the first and third Thursdays of each month. Council meetings shall begin no earlier than 7:00 p.m. During the months of July and August, one regular meeting per month shall be held, on the first Thursday of July and on the third Thursday of August. 
(b)  When any such Thursday shall fall on a holiday, the regular meeting shall be held on the following Monday at 7:00 p.m. 
(Code 1971,  2-37; Ord. No. 1035,  2-37, 4-5-90; Ord. No. 1421, 5-17-06; Ord. No. 1486, 10-22-08) 
Sec. 2-37. - Special council meetings. 
    Special meetings of the city council may be called by the president or by the city clerk on written application to him by not less than three members of the council. In either case, the call shall be in writing and state the business proposed to be transacted at such meeting. The action of the council at such meeting shall be confined to such business. The call therefor shall be given to each member personally, or left at his residence at least 48 hours before the time of the meeting. 
(Code 1971,  2-38) 
Secs. 2-38-2-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference- Appointment by the mayor,  6; vacancies in office of mayor or on city council; temporary appointment for certain appointed officers,  33. 
Cross reference- Superintendent of building,  6-26 et seq.; inspector of gas piping and appliances,  6-61 et seq.; office of fire chief created,  7-21; deputy chiefs of the fire department,  7-22; director of parks,  11-34; director of community development and planning,  13-126 et seq.; director of lands and natural resources,  13-231 et seq.; chief of police,  14-6 et seq.; superintendent of the water department,  18-71 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-61. - Powers and duties of city officers and employees. 
    All city officers and employees shall exercise the powers and perform the duties delegated them by the General Laws of the commonwealth, the Charter of the city and the ordinances, orders and resolutions of the city council. 
(Code 1971,  2-24) 
Sec. 2-62. - Bond of officials-When required; approval; custody. 
    Before entering upon their respective duties, the city officials named in section 2-63 shall provide surety company bonds for the faithful performance of their various duties. Such bonds shall be approved by the mayor and shall be kept in the safe deposit box of the city, which shall be accessible only to the mayor. 
(Code 1971,  2-25) 
Sec. 2-63. - Same-Amount of bond; premium payment. 
(a)  The city clerk, city treasurer, city collector, bookkeeper, the clerk of the treasurer/collector and the assistant city clerk and clerks in the city clerk's department shall obtain surety bonds in an amount which shall be set from time to time by the state department of regulation. 
(b)  The premiums of all bonds required by this section shall be paid by the city. 
(Code 1971,  2-26) 
State Law reference- Fidelity bonds, payment of premiums, M.G.L.A. c. 41,  109A. 
Sec. 2-64. - Indemnification of certain officers. 
(a)  The city shall indemnify and save harmless members of the city council, members of elected or appointed boards and commissions, the mayor, all department heads including but not limited to superintendents, directors, auditor, treasurer/collector, city solicitor, managers, and their respective assistants, and the superintendent of schools, from personal financial loss and expenses, including legal fees and costs, if any, in an amount not to exceed $1,000,000.00 arising out of any claim, action, award, compromise, settlement or judgement by reason of an intentional tort or by reason of any act or omission which constitutes a violation of the civil rights of any person under federal or state law; if such aforementioned official or employee at the time of such intentional tort or act or omission was acting within the scope of his official duties or employment; provided, however, that such aforementioned official or employee shall provide reasonable cooperation to the city in the negotiation, investigation and defense of any claim or action brought as a result of such intentional tort or act or omission. No such aforementioned official or employee shall be indemnified under this section for violation of any civil rights if he acted intentionally or in a grossly negligent, willful or malicious manner. 
(b)  The defense and/or settlement of any such claim shall be undertaken or negotiated by the city solicitor, his agent or designee. However, if the city solicitor determines that a conflict of interest has arisen or is likely to arise by his mutual defense of the city and the officer(s) or employees in question, the officer(s) or employees in question shall not be defended by the city solicitor, his agent or designee, but shall seek outside counsel for such defense. The expense incurred by the official or the employee for outside counsel shall be borne by the city unless the mayor and/or the city council shall deem such legal fees to be unreasonable, in which event such legal fees shall be subject to the fee arbitration procedure of the Massachusetts Bar Association. 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall be deemed to limit the effect of any indemnification statute applicable to the city at the time of any such intentional tort or act or omission. This section shall apply to any settlement or judgement made in compliance with this section on or after the date this section is approved. 
(Ord. No. 943,  2-27, 3-19-87) 
State Law reference- Indemnification of public employees, M.G.L.A. c. 41,  100. 
Secs. 2-65-2-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CITY AUDITOR[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Auditors generally, M.G.L.A. c. 41,  48 et seq. 

Sec. 2-86. - Duties. 
(a)  The duties of the city auditor shall be those described in section 8(14) of the Charter of the city; sections 2-7 and 2-8 of this Code; M.G.L.A. c. 41,  50, 52, 54A, and M.G.L.A. c. 44,  16, 31A, 31C, 43 as well as any other duties proscribed by statute, ordinance or by Charter and amendments thereto. 
(b)  The auditor must have knowledge of the theory and practice of modern municipal accounting. 
(c)  The auditor shall examine the books and accounts of all its officers and committees intrusted with the receipt, custody or expenditure of money, and all original bills and vouchers on which money has been or may be paid from the city treasury. The auditor shall have free access to such books, accounts, bills and vouchers as often as may be deemed necessary for the purpose of examination, and shall examine the same at least once in each year, and annually report in writing the result of the examinations. The auditor shall, at least once in each year, verify the cash balance of each of such officers and committees by actual count of the cash and by reconciliation of bank balances, and shall insert in the auditing department annual report a certificate under oath of the facts so found. 
(Ord. No. 857,  2-180, 6-3-82) 
Sec. 2-87. - Reconciliation of accounts. 
    The city auditor shall be responsible for accurate reconciliation of all municipal general ledger accounts. 
(Ord. No. 857,  2-181, 6-3-82) 
Sec. 2-88. - Budget preparation. 
    The city auditor shall prepare the municipal budget under the direction of the mayor and provide the mayor with a detailed analysis of all departmental budget requests, including the school department, water department and sewage disposal department. 
(Ord. No. 857,  2-182, 6-3-82) 
Sec. 2-89. - Monthly reports. 
(a)  The city auditor shall prepare a monthly written report for the mayor and city council. The report shall be available at least two days prior to the second regularly scheduled monthly meeting of the city council and contain the following: 
(1)  A list of the daily cash balances for the preceding month. 
(2)  A list of all cash investments for the previous month including the rate of return and amount of interest earned, listed by location, description and dollar amount. 
(3)  Problems which the auditor feels that the mayor and city council should be familiar with. 
(b)  The auditor shall furnish the mayor and city council with a monthly budget report showing the total departmental budgets, the expenditures to date and unexpended balances. 
(Ord. No. 857,  2-183, 6-3-82) 
Sec. 2-90. - Meetings of city council. 
    The city auditor shall be available, upon 24 hours' notice, for attendance at meetings of the city council and/or subcommittees thereof. 
(Ord. No. 857,  2-184, 6-3-82) 
Sec. 2-91. - Reporting to mayor. 
    The city auditor shall report to and be accountable to the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 857,  2-185, 6-3-82) 
Sec. 2-92. - Approval of bills. 
    All accounts rendered to or kept in the departments of the city shall be subject to the inspection of the auditor. The auditor may require any person presenting for settlement an account or claim against the city to make oath before him in such form as he may prescribe, as to the accuracy of such account or claim. The willful making of a false oath shall be punishable as perjury. The auditor shall approve the payment of all bills or payrolls of all departments before they are paid by the treasurer, and may disallow and refuse to approve for payment, in whole or in part, any claim as fraudulent, unlawful or excessive; and in that case the auditor shall file with the treasurer a written statement of the reasons for the refusal; and the treasurer shall not pay any claim or bill so disallowed. 
Sec. 2-93. - Notice to auditor of payment of public funds to the treasurer. 
    Whenever any officer of the commonwealth, or of a county, city or town, makes a payment of public money to the treasurer, he shall furnish at the same time to the auditor a written statement of the amount of the payment and the date and purpose thereof. 
Sec. 2-94. - Notification to the assessors as to receipts. 
    The auditor shall notify the assessors, not later than August first in each year, of the total receipts of the preceding fiscal year, except from taxes, loans and trust funds, and shall specify in detail the source of such receipts. 
Sec. 2-95. - Books of accounts and financial records. 
    The auditor shall keep a complete set of books wherein shall be entered the amount of each specific appropriation, the amounts and purposes of expenditures made therefrom, the receipts from each source of income, the amount of each assessment levied and the abatements made; and he shall keep his accounts, as far as practicable, in conforming with the classifications and forms prescribed by the director of accounts in accordance with M.G.L.A. c. 44,  43, and in conformity with any systems, classifications, forms and designations prescribed pursuant to the regulations of the board of education for use by school committees. The auditor shall have custody of all contracts of the city, shall keep a register of the sureties on all bonds of indemnity given to the city, shall keep a record of the city debt, showing the purpose for which it was incurred, when incurred, when due, the rate of interest and the provisions made for the payment of debt. 
Sec. 2-96. - Notice of condition of appropriations; record of appropriations. 
    Whenever any appropriation shall have been expended or whenever, in the judgment of the auditor, it appears that the liabilities incurred against any appropriation may be in excess of the unexpended balance thereof, he shall immediately notify the mayor, city council, board, committee, head of department or officer authorized to make expenditures therefrom, and no claim against such appropriation shall be allowed nor any further liability incurred until the city makes provision for its payment. The auditor shall, at regular intervals and as often at least as once a month, send to the mayor, the city council, and to each board, committee, head of department, or officer having the disbursement of an appropriation a statement of the amount of orders approved and warrants drawn on behalf of such board, department or officer during the preceding month, and a statement of the balance of such appropriation remaining subject to draft. Each head of a department, board or committee authorized to expend money shall furnish the auditor, at the close of the fiscal year, a list of bills remaining unpaid, showing to whom and for what due, and their amounts; and the auditor shall incorporate such in his annual report covering the financial transactions of the city as provided by M.G.L.A. c. 41,  61. 
Sec. 2-97. - Annual report. 
    The auditor shall make an annual report, to be published as a city document, giving a statement of all receipts and expenditures of the city for the past financial year, including those of funds managed by trustees or commissioners for the city and showing also the amount of each specific appropriation, the expenditures therefrom, and the purpose for which money has been spent; and such statement shall be arranged in accordance with the classifications prescribed by the director of accounts. Such report shall contain a statement of any change in the amount of city debt during the year and a list of indebtedness incurred and unpaid at the end of the financial year. 
Sec. 2-98. - Revolving funds. 
(a)  Purpose . This section establishes and authorizes revolving funds for use by city departments, boards, committees, agencies and officers in connection with the operation of programs or activities that generate fees, charges or other receipts to support all or some of the expenses of those programs or activities. These revolving funds are established under and governed by M.G.L.A. c. 44,  53E1/2. 
(b)  Expenditure limitations . A department or agency head, board, committee or officer may incur liabilities against and spend monies from a revolving fund established and authorized by this ordinance without appropriation subject to the following limitations: 
(1)  Fringe benefits of full-time employees whose salaries or wages are paid from the fund shall also be paid from the fund. 
(2)  No liability shall be incurred in excess of the available balance of the fund. 
(3)  The total amount spent during a fiscal year shall not exceed the amount authorized by city council vote on or before July 1 of that fiscal year, or any increased amount of that authorization that is later approved during that fiscal year. 
(c)  Interest . Interest earned on monies credited to a revolving fund established by this ordinance shall be credited to the general fund. 
(d)  Procedures and reports . Except as provided in M.G.L.A. c. 44,  53E1/2 and this section, the laws, charter provisions, by-laws, rules, regulations, policies or procedures that govern the receipt and custody of municipal monies and the expenditure and payment of city funds shall apply to the use of a revolving fund established and authorized by this ordinance. The city auditor shall include a statement on the collections credited to the fund, the encumbrances and expenditures charged to each fund and the balance available for expenditure in the regular report the city auditor provides the department, board, committee, agency or officer on appropriations made for its use. 
(e)  Authorized revolving funds . The table establishes: 
(1)  Each revolving fund authorized for use by a town department, board, committee, agency or officer, 
(2)  The department or agency head, board, committee or officer authorized to spend from each fund, 
(3)  The fees, charges and other monies charged and received by the department, board, committee, agency or officer in connection with the program or activity for which the fund is established that shall be credited to each fund by the city treasurer, 
(4)  The expenses of the program or activity for which each fund may be used, 
(5)  Any restrictions or conditions on expenditures from each fund; 
(6)  Any reporting or other requirements that apply to each fund, and 
_____ 
(7)  The fiscal years each fund shall operate under this section.

DIVISION 4. - CITY COLLECTOR/CITY TREASURER[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1660 , adopted Dec. 15, 2016, repealed the former Div. 4,  2-136-2-145, and enacted a new Div. 4 as set out herein. The former Div. 4 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 1191, adopted Aug. 21, 1997; Ord. No. 1330,  1, adopted Sept. 19, 2002; Ord. No. 1437, adopted Jan. 31, 2007. 

Sec. 2-136. - Office established; powers and duties. 
    The office of Treasurer and Collector of the City of Westfield is hereby established. The duties of the treasurer and collector shall consist of the statutory duties of a city treasurer and collector under the General Laws of Massachusetts and in addition thereto, the duty to collect all accounts due to the city pursuant to M.G.L.A. c. 41,  38A. 
(Ord. No. 1660 , 12-15-16) 
Sec. 2-137. - Appointment of assistant collector. 
    The treasurer and collector may in writing appoint, with the approval of the city council, as assistant collector who may be an employee in said collector's department. The appointment of said assistant collector shall be pursuant to M.G.L.A. c. 41,  39C. 
(Ord. No. 1660 , 12-15-16) 
Sec. 2-138. - Appointment of assistant treasurer. 
    The treasurer and collector may in writing appoint, with the approval of the city council, as assistant treasurer who may be an employee in said treasurer's department. The appointment of said assistant treasurer shall be pursuant to M.G.L.A. c. 41,  39A. 
(Ord. No. 1660 , 12-15-16) 
Sec. 2-139. - Bond. 
    Every treasurer and collector shall give bond annually for the faithful performance of his/her duties in a form approved by the commissioner of revenue and in such sum, not less than the amount established by said commissioner, as shall be fixed by the city council or the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 1660 , 12-15-16) 
Sec. 2-140. - Departments to keep record of moneys received; make payments to treasurer. 
    Each department shall keep a written record of moneys received and pay all such moneys to the treasurer forthwith, taking the treasurer and collector's receipt therefor. 
(Ord. No. 1660 , 12-15-16) 
Sec. 2-141. - Petty cash funds. 
    Upon the approval of the auditor, the treasurer and collector may turn over to the head of any department a sum not exceeding $50.00 per month for petty cash. Vouchers shall be presented showing payments from petty cash, and any balance on hand shall be returned to the treasurer and collector prior to December 31 in each year so that at the close of the fiscal year all moneys may be in the hands of the treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 1660 , 12-15-16) 
Sec. 2-142. - Collection of unpaid bills. 
(a)  Generally . Whenever any person incurs any liability to the city on any claim or demand, the department having charge thereof shall forthwith commit a bill or claim to the city treasurer and collector, giving him/her the name of the person liable therefor, his/her address, the amount and nature of such claim and all other information pertaining thereto that may assist in the collection thereof, giving notice thereof in writing to the city auditor. The city collector shall proceed to collect such bill or claim, and if such amount is not paid within a reasonable time after a bill for the same has been sent, shall take appropriate steps to collect the same. All collections of accounts shall be paid over to the city treasurer and collector in the same manner as taxes. 
(b)  Water bills . The city treasurer and collector shall notify the board of water commissioners, in writing, of all water rents which remain unpaid 60 days after such water bills become due. 
(Ord. No. 1660 , 12-15-16) 
Sec. 2-143. - Annual statement. 
    The city treasurer and collector shall present to the city council at the close of the financial year a written detailed list of all accounts and claims, except taxes and assessments, which have been committed to him/her for more than one year, and which remain uncollected in whole or in part. He shall also submit to the city council at the close of the financial year a written statement of the total amount of all taxes and assessments outstanding, by years. 
(Ord. No. 1660 , 12-15-16) 
Sec. 2-144. - Failure to pay municipal taxes or charges as grounds for denial, suspension, revocation of license or permit. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Licensing authority means the board, commission, department, officer or other city entity which issues a permit or license. 
    Municipal charge means any charge established, required or imposed by any board, commission, department, officer or other entity of the city for services of personnel or equipment, use of facilities, charges for utilities, goods/materials/equipment supplied or used, or other activities performed by the city, its employees or agents. 
    Overdue obligation means any local tax, assessment, betterment, fee or municipal charge which remains unpaid unless such tax, etc., is the subject of a pending application for abatement or of a pending appeal before the appellate tax board. 
(b)  Any licensing authority of the city may deny, suspend or revoke any license or permit issued by said licensing authority, including any transfers of said license or permit, with the exception of those licenses and permits set out in paragraph (g), intra, if the applicant or holder thereof has any outstanding overdue obligation, or with respect to any activity, event or other matter is carried out or exercised or is to be carried out or exercised on or about real estate whose owner has any outstanding overdue obligation. 
(c)  The city treasurer and collector shall annually, and may periodically, for all municipal commitments which are under his/her control, issue a list of all persons, corporations, or business entities which have an overdue obligation to the city. Any other official of the city having control of records of municipal charges not committed to the city treasurer and collector shall annually, and may periodically, issue a similar list of overdue obligations, Such lists shall be supplied to all licensing authorities within the city. 
(d)  A licensing authority may deny, revoke or suspend any license or permit held by any person, corporation, or business entity appearing on any list of overdue obligations. Prior to taking such action, the licensing authority shall give written notice, as required by the applicable provisions of law, to the party responsible for the overdue obligation and to the tax collector of the intended action and shall give such party a hearing on the proposed action, such hearing to be held not earlier than 14 days after such notice. The list of overdue obligations shall be prima facie evidence for denial, revocation or suspension of the license or permit. Any findings made by the licensing authority in connection with a denial, revocation or suspension shall not be relevant to or introduced in any proceeding at law except for an appeal from such denial, revocation or suspension. The city treasurer and collector may intervene in any hearing held hereunder. 
(e)  Any license or permit which is denied, revoked or suspended under this section shall not be issued, reissued, renewed or reinstated until the licensing authority receives a certificate from the city collector stating that the applicant for or holder of such license or permit is in good standing with respect to any and all local taxes, fees, assessments, or other municipal charges payable to the city as of the date of issuance of such certificate. 
(f)  The licensing authority shall give any applicant for or holder of a license or permit who has an overdue obligation the opportunity to enter into a payment agreement for satisfaction of such overdue obligation. Upon execution of any such agreement, the licensing authority shall issue a certificate, to be displayed with the license, indicating that such license or permit is conditioned upon satisfactory compliance with the payment agreement. 
Failure to comply with the payment agreement shall be grounds for the suspension or revocation of the license or permit following notice and hearing as required by the applicable provisions of law. 
(g)  The following licenses and permits shall not be subject to the provisions of this section (all references are to the Massachusetts General Laws): Chapter 48, Section 13 (open air burning), Chapter 85, Section 11A (bicycle permits); Chapter 101, Section 33 (safes for charitable purposes); Chapter 140, Section 21E (clubs dispensing food or beverages); Chapter 140, Section 137 (dog licenses); Chapter 131, Section 12 fishing/hunting/trapping license); Chapter 207, Section 28 (marriage license); Chapter 140, Section 181 (public exhibition/theatrical permits). Also exempted are parade permits issued under section 17-7 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1660 , 12-15-16) 
Sec. 2-145. - Municipal tax repayment agreements. 
(a)  Authority . This section is adopted pursuant to the authority of M.G.L.A. c. 60,  62A, which authorizes municipalities to enact ordinances to authorize payment agreements between the city treasurer/collector and persons entitled to redeem parcels in tax title. 
(b)  Purpose and intent . The purpose and intent of this chapter [section] is to foster the collection of unpaid taxes and assessments and to promote community reinvestment. The city finds and determines that such a program will mitigate the consequences of property seizures and will help delinquent taxpayers meet their obligations to the city while avoiding the legal expenses and time delays of taking the property to land court. During the term of any municipal tax repayment agreement, the treasurer/collector may not bring an action to foreclose the tax title account unless the taxpayer fails to comply with the terms and conditions of the municipal tax repayment agreement. 
(c)  Definitions . For the purpose of this chapter [section], the following definitions shall be applicable. 
    Commercial taxpayer means the owner of record of a commercial, industrial or institutional use property. 
    Documentation means supporting documentation including, but not limited to, the following: 
a.  Federal and state income tax returns; 
b.  Savings and checking account statements; 
c.  Financial statements; 
d.  Schedule of assets; and 
e.  Outstanding bills. 
(d)  Community reinvestment agreement . 
(1)  Any delinquent commercial, industrial or institutional taxpayer may enter into a community reinvestment tax repayment agreement and, upon execution of such agreement with the city treasurer/collector, shall make a minimum payment of 25 percent of the total amount to redeem the parcel. The maximum term of a community reinvestment agreement cannot exceed two years for a commercial, institutional, or industrial delinquent taxpayer. 
(2)  The treasurer/collector is authorized to grant and to waive 50 percent of the interest that has accrued on the amount of tax on the tax title account in a community reinvestment agreement to commercial, institutional, or industrial taxpayer under the following criteria: 
a.  A commercial/industrial delinquent taxpayer that is based in an area of Westfield documented to be located on an environmental, contaminated site in accordance with state or federal environmental protection regulations, wherein the owner commits in writing to specific steps toward remediation and property improvements. 
b.  In cases where the commercial, institutional or industrial user commits in writing to implement specific investments in the property during the term of the repayment agreement worth at least twice the amount of taxes, excluding interest and penalties, owed on the property, upon completion of such improvements. 
(e)  Penalties . The taxpayer must pay all current taxes owed when due. Any failure to stay current on taxes, payments, fees, and licenses issued by or otherwise owed the city when due would cause the municipal tax repayment agreement to be terminated immediately. 
(Ord. No. 1660 , 12-15-16) 
Secs. 2-146-2-160. - Reserved.

DIVISION 6. - CITY SOLICITOR[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1581, adopted Dec. 20, 2012, repealed the former Art. III, Div. 6,  2-211, 2-212, and enacted a new Div. 6 as set out herein. Charter reference- City departments, boards and officers,  9. 

Sec. 2-211. - City solicitor: Head of department/appointment/term. 
(a)  The law department shall be under the supervision and control of the city solicitor, who shall be an attorney admitted to practice in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. 
(b)  The city solicitor shall be the department head for the law department and have primary responsibility for the administrative functions of the department. The city solicitor shall be legal advisor to the mayor, city council, boards, commissions and department heads and shall defend the city in all legal actions. 
(c)  The city solicitor shall be appointed by the mayor. 
(d)  The city solicitor shall assign cases and tasks to the assistant city solicitors. 
(Ord. No. 1581, 12-20-12) 
Sec. 2-212. - First assistant city solicitor/appointment/term. 
(a)  There shall be a first assistant city solicitor who shall be an attorney admitted to practice in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. 
(b)  The first assistant city solicitor shall be appointed by the mayor and subject to confirmation by majority vote of the city council for a term of three years from the date of being sworn, or until a successor is duly chosen, or otherwise removed for good and reasonable cause by the mayor subject to confirmation by a majority vote of the city council. 
(c)  The first assistant city solicitor shall, in the absence of the city solicitor, or should the city solicitor be unable to serve due to illness or other incapacity, have all of the powers of the city solicitor and act on behalf of the city solicitor. 
(Ord. No. 1581, 12-20-12) 
Sec. 2-213. - Labor counsel. 
(a)  There shall be the position of labor counsel under the supervision of the city solicitor who shall be an attorney admitted to practice in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. 
(b)  Labor counsel shall be assigned all labor matters within the city and shall assist the school department and will be the collective bargaining agent for the city and schools. representation of the school department shall be subject to school committee approval. 
(c)  Labor counsel shall be appointed by the mayor and subject to confirmation by a majority vote of the city council for a term of three years from the date of being sworn, or until a successor is duly chosen, or otherwise removed for good and reasonable cause by the mayor subject to confirmation by a majority vote of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1581, 12-20-12) 
Sec. 2-214. - Assistant city solicitors/appointment/term. 
(a)  There shall be between two and five assistant city solicitors under the supervision and direction of the city solicitor all of which shall be admitted to practice in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. 
(b)  The assistant city solicitors shall be appointed by the mayor and subject to confirmation by a majority vote of the city council for a term of three years from the date of being sworn, or until a successor is duly chosen, or otherwise removed for good and reasonable cause by the mayor subject to confirmation by a majority vote of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1581, 12-20-12) 
Sec. 2-215. - Duties of the office of the city solicitor. 
(a)  The office of the city solicitor shall be the legal advisors to the mayor, city council, department heads and the boards and commissions and shall assist the city council in all matters of legislative preparation including, but not limited to, orders, resolutions and ordinance amendments. 
(b)  The office of the city solicitor shall represent the interests of the city before the courts of the commonwealth or any other tribunal. 
(c)  The office of the city solicitor shall review and approve all contracts as to form. 
(d)  The office of the city solicitor shall investigate all claims made against the city. 
(Ord. No. 1581, 12-20-12) 
Sec. 2-216. - Additional staff. 
(a)  There shall be the position of a legal secretary to be appointed by the city solicitor for a term of three years, or until a successor is duly appointed or for removal for just and reasonable cause. 
(b)  There shall be up to two positions of a legal assistant/paralegal to be appointed by the city solicitor for a term of three years, or until a successor is duly appointed or for removal for just and reasonable cause. 
(c)  Such other staff as authorized by the mayor in the annual budget submission to the city council for which appropriation is voted. 
(Ord. No. 1581, 12-20-12) 
Secs. 2-217-2-235. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - OFFICE OF MAYOR[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1519, adopted May 26, 2010, added div. 7, consisting of  2-213, to art. III. At the editor's discretion, the new provisions have been redesignated as herein set out to allow for expansion in div. 6. 

Sec. 2-236. - Office of the mayor-Established. 
    There is herby established the office of the mayor. 
(1)  Administrative assistant. The mayor shall appoint an administrative assistant. The administrative assistant shall report directly to the mayor and shall be responsible for any administrative tasks assigned by the mayor. 
(2)  Additional staff. Such other staff as authorized by the mayor in the annual budget submission to the city council for which appropriation is voted. 
(3)  City advancement officer. The mayor shall appoint with council approval, a city advancement officer for a two year term to run concurrent with the mayor's term. The city advancement officer shall perform a variety of administrative, mechanical and professional tasks in planning strategies to attract new businesses and encourage expansion and retention of existing business to promote a stronger economic base for the city. 
(4)  Community outreach coordinator . The mayor shall appoint a community outreach coordinator for a two year term to run concurrent with the mayor's term. The community outreach coordinator shall perform a variety of administrative and professional tasks in coordination of city branding and marketing initiatives; managing inbound and outbound communication of city policy matters; and coordinate community events, initiatives, and partnerships with businesses, non-profit, and civic organizations. 
(5)  Media systems specialist . The mayor shall appoint, with council approval, a media systems specialist for a one year term. The media systems specialist shall perform a variety of administrative, technical and professional tasks in coordination of television and radio production for the public access television and/or radio and public safety radio maintenance. The media systems specialist shall also coordinate, maintain and manage training on proper use of equipment, review and provide information to the mayor regarding cable and wireless provider contracts, cable production and processing needs, FCC licenses as well as assist with the development of curriculum. 
(Ord. No. 1519, 5-26-2010; Ord. No. 1640 , 4-7-16; Ord. No. 1675 , 10-19-17) 
DIVISION 8. - DEPARTMENT OF FACILITIES MANAGEMENT 

Sec. 2-237. - Establishment. 
    There is hereby established within the mayor's office a department of facilities management. The department shall be under the control and direction of the director of facilities management and shall consist of such administrative, clerical, maintenance and technical staff as the mayor and city council may authorize. 
(Ord. No. 1608, 11-6-14) 
Sec. 2-238. - Director of facilities management. 
    The director of facilities management shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation by the city council for a term of three years or until a successor is appointed. 
(Ord. No. 1608, 11-6-14) 
Sec. 2-239. - Duties and responsibilities of director. 
(a)  The director of facilities management shall oversee the capital improvements, care and maintenance of all municipal buildings, including, but not limited to structural maintenance and repairs, operating systems including heating and cooling systems, plumbing and heating; building maintenance technology. 
(b)  The director of facilities management shall oversee the care and maintenance of all equipment relating to municipal property including tools, lawnmowers, etc. 
(c)  The director of facilities management may act as a liaison to the assigned project manager or act as project manager on all qualified capital projects relating to municipal buildings. The director shall supervise and control all work performed by tradesmen, craftsmen or technicians in support of public buildings including contracting for labor and materials to be supplied. 
(d)  The director of facilities management shall investigate, study and render reports and recommendations on all matters pertaining to public buildings, including new construction, additions and/or renovations of current public buildings. 
(Ord. No. 1608, 11-6-14) 
Secs. 2-240-2-255. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS, AND COMMITTEES[10] 
Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Cross reference- Board of engineering,  2-466 et seq.; airport commission,  5-21 et seq.; building board of appeals,  6-116 et seq.; parks and recreation commission,  11-51 et seq.; planning board,  13-21 et seq.; flood control commission,  13-51 et seq.; community development and planning commission,  13-101 et seq.; conservation commission,  13-151 et seq.; development and industrial commission,  13-201 et seq.; police commission,  14-1 et seq.; off-street parking commission,  17-241 et seq.; board of water commissioners,  18-41 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-256. - Municipal board meetings. 
(a)  All meetings of boards, commissions and committees shall be held in the municipal building (city hall). 
(b)  All regular scheduled meetings of such boards, commissions and committees shall begin no earlier than 5:00 p.m. Special meetings of such boards, commissions and committees may be called at any time allowed by law. 
(c)  The council on aging may hold regularly scheduled meetings during the afternoon hours. 
(d)  The Westfield Barnes Airport Commission meetings shall be held at the airport administration building located at the airport. 
(e)  The Commission for Citizens with Disabilities may meet at 4:00 p.m. on the fourth Tuesday of every month. 
(f)  The Westfield Redevelopment Authority may hold regularly scheduled meetings during the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. 
(g)  The fire commission meetings may be held at the Little River Fire Station Community Room. 
(Code 1971,  2-39; Ord. No. 848, 9-3-81; Ord. No. 1421, 5-17-06; Ord. No. 1452, 10-9-07; Ord. No. 1466, 11-26-07; Ord. No. 1485, 10-22-08; Ord. No. 1540, 2-3-11; Ord. No. 1624 , 4-16-15; Ord. No. 1676 , 12-21-17) 
Sec. 2-257. - Off-duty or special details, administrative fee. 
    In the event that a city board, commission, committee (including the school committee) or department head acting under the authority of M.G.L.A. c. 44,  53C shall authorize employees to participate in off-duty work details or special detail work as set forth therein then, in that event, in addition to the rate of compensation charged to the person or persons requesting the off-duty work detail or special detail work, there shall be added a fee of seven percent of the cost of services authorized. The total of all such fees shall be transferred to the city general fund no later than the close of the fiscal year in which such fees were paid. City departments are exempt from the fee. 
(Ord. No. 1157, 3-11-96) 
Sec. 2-258. - Miscellaneous regulations. 
(a)  All boards and commissions at all regularly scheduled meetings shall begin each session by providing a 15-minute public participation period. This time limit may be extended by a majority vote of the board or commission at any meeting wherein the board feels an extension is warranted. 
(b)  Each person speaking during the public participation period shall be limited to three minutes, unless the board by majority vote grants an extension and states the additional amount of time to be granted. 
(c)  If no one appears to speak during the public participation period, the board or commission may vote to waive the public participation period and proceed with the regular meeting. 
(d)  The public participation period shall take place at the beginning of each regularly scheduled meeting of each board and commission of the city. 
(e)  Each board and commission may vote to provide a public participation period at any special meeting. 
(Ord. No. 1177, 11-21-96) 
Sec. 2-259. - Standing committee for business systems. 
    There is hereby established the standing committee for business systems. The committee is an eight member committee chaired by the city auditor with representatives designated from those seven city departments with the largest annual operating budgets. The committee shall meet periodically to review the business practices and rules of the city and to recommend changes and enhancements thereto. Special committee meetings may be called by the mayor, by the city auditor or by a majority of the members. 
(Ord. No. 1270, 12-7-00) 
Sec. 2-260. - Membership on boards and commissions. 
    All members of boards and commissions in the City of Westfield shall either be a legal resident of the city or own a business within the city. 
(Ord. No. 1524, 6-17-10) 
Secs. 2-261-2-280. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CULTURAL COUNCIL[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1637, adopted December 3, 2015, repealed the former div. 2.,  2-281-2-285, and enacted a new div. 2 as set out herein. The former div. 2 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 969,  2-180-284, adopted January 7, 1988. 

Sec. 2-281. - Established. 
    There shall be established in and for the city a cultural council, pursuant to M.G.L.A. c. 10,  58, hereinafter called the cultural council. 
(Ord. No. 1637 , 12-3-15) 
Sec. 2-282. - Purpose. 
    The cultural council shall exist for the purpose of serving and enhancing the development and growth of the arts and humanities in the city encompassing the pursuit, performance, exhibition and enjoyment of artistic and cultural activities in the broadest sense. 
(Ord. No. 1637 , 12-3-15) 
Sec. 2-283. - Composition, appointment, term. 
(a)  Pursuant to M.G.L.A. c. 10,  58, the cultural council shall consist of at least five and not more than 22 members, all of whom shall be legal residents of the city and shall have demonstrated scholarship or creativity in, or distinguished service to, the arts and humanities or interpretive sciences. A quorum shall be a majority of the duly appointed members of the commission. 
(b)  The mayor, subject to confirmation by the city council, shall appoint all members of the cultural council for terms of three years. No such member shall be appointed to more than two consecutive terms. Notwithstanding the foregoing, nothing in this section shall prohibit the appointment of a member that had previously served two consecutive terms after having not been appointed for one term. 
(c)  Upon a vacancy, for any reason, the mayor shall appoint a successor for three years in the same manner as in original appointments. 
(d)  All members of the cultural council shall serve without compensation, and, for purposes of M.G.L.A. c. 268A, they shall be considered to be special municipal employees. 
(Ord. No. 1637 , 12-3-15) 
Secs. 2-284-2-305. - Reserved.

DIVISION 4. - CABLE TELEVISION COMMISSION[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1257, adopted April 20, 2000, repealed former Div. 4,  2-331-2-337 in its entirety and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former Div. 4 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 963,  1-6, adopted Nov. 19, 1987. 

Sec. 2-331. - Established. 
    There shall be in and for the city a cable television commission, hereinafter called the commission, which shall consist of seven members, as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 1257, 4-20-00; Ord. No. 1654 , 6-16-16) 
Sec. 2-332. - Appointment. 
    The mayor, subject to confirmation by the city council, shall appoint all members of the commission from the existing wards respectively and one at-large member, and all said members shall be legal city residents. The members of the commission are hereby classified as special municipal employees within the meaning of M.G.L.A. c. 268A. 
(Ord. No. 1257, 4-20-00; Ord. No. 1572, 4-19-12; Ord. No. 1654 , 6-16-16) 
Sec. 2-333. - Terms of office; compensation. 
    The terms of office of members of the commission shall be for such length of time not exceeding five years, and so arranged that the term of one member will expire each year, and the succeeding member shall be appointed for five years. All members shall hold office until their successors are appointed and qualified, and if a vacancy occurs, not withstanding term expiration, it shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as an original appointment. 
(Ord. No. 1257, 4-20-00) 
Sec. 2-334. - Selection of chairman. 
    The members of the commission shall elect one of their members to act as chairman for that ensuing year or until a successor is elected or qualified, but no member may be elected chairman for two consecutive terms. 
(Ord. No. 1257, 4-20-00) 
Sec. 2-335. - Meetings, advisory body. 
    The commission shall hold regular meetings once per month, and it shall keep a record of all its proceedings. The commission shall act in an advisory capacity to the mayor under such powers as may be properly delegated to it by the mayor as the licensing authority. 
(Ord. No. 1257, 4-20-00) 
Sec. 2-336. - Duties generally. 
    The commission shall have the following duties: 
(1)  To develop, publish, and amend as necessary, from time to time, the rules that define the commission's procedures. The commission shall submit the same to the mayor for approval prior to final adoption or publication. 
(2)  To conduct periodic evaluations of all Westfield cable systems and their compliance with terms of all licenses and applicable laws. A report of said evaluation shall be submitted to the mayor. 
(3)  To make such inspections and/or inquiries as are necessary to insure that all licensees maintain their cable systems as required by their licenses. 
(4)  To establish procedures for the hearing and disposition of complaints from any person or other entity relating to the operation of all Westfield cable systems. 
(5)  To maintain vigilance regarding possible abuses of privacy. 
(6)  To have the planning board notify all Westfield cable system licensees, upon approval by the planning board, of new subdivisions and real estate developments. 
(Ord. No. 1257, 4-20-00) 
Sec. 2-337. - Right to appeal. 
    A licensee shall have the right to appeal to the mayor on any of the commission's decisions of which said licensee is aggrieved. Said appeal shall be presented to the mayor, in writing, and not later than ten calendar days subsequent to licensee's receipt of said decision. The mayor, upon receipt of said appeal, shall have 30 calendar days to examine said appeal, and he shall inform the commission and licensee of his findings. 
(Ord. No. 1257, 4-20-00) 
Secs. 2-338-2-360. - Reserved.

State Law reference- Council on aging, M.G.L.A. c. 40,  8B. 

Sec. 2-361. - Established.

Sec. 2-362. - Composition; appointment; term. 
    The council on aging shall consist of seven members who shall be citizens of the city to be appointed by the mayor subject to confirmation by the city council. The members appointed by the mayor shall serve for terms of three years.

DIVISION 7. - SCHOOL COMMITTEE[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
Charter reference- School committee,  37 et seq. 

Sec. 2-416. - Joint convention for filling vacancy. 
(a)  If it is officially determined that a vacancy exists within the school committee, the mayor shall request a joint convention of the city council and school committee. This convention will be held in the city council chamber no more than 30 days after the vacancy has been officially established. 
(b)  If the mayor is not present, the president of the city council shall preside. If the president of the city council is not present, the vice-chairman of the school committee shall preside. In the absence of all three of the above officials, the members of the joint convention shall elect a presiding officer from within the joint membership. 
(Ord. No. 934,  2-45, 2-46, 2-5-87) 
Charter reference- Vacancy on school committee,  44. 
Secs. 2-417-2-425. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - COMMISSION FOR CITIZENS WITH DISABILITIES 

Sec. 2-426. - Establishment. 
    There is hereby established under the provisions of M.G.L.A. c. 40,  8J, a commission for citizens with disabilities to be known as the Westfield Commission for Citizens with Disabilities, hereinafter called the commission. 
(Ord. No. 1122,  A, 1-6-94) 
Sec. 2-427. - Purpose. 
    The commission shall be empowered to: 
(1)  Research and identify the problems of citizens of the city with disabilities; 
(2)  Advise and assist municipal officials and employees regarding compliance with those state and federal laws and regulations that affect people with disabilities; 
(3)  Coordinate with other local groups and the state office on disability to carry out programs designed to educate people about the problems of those with disabilities; 
(4)  Provide information, referrals and guidance to individuals, public agencies, businesses and civic organizations in matters pertaining to disabilities. 
(5)  Review and make recommendations about policies, procedures, services, activities and facilities of departments, boards and agencies of the city that affect persons with disabilities. 
(6)  Coordinate activities of other local groups organized for similar purposes. 
(Ord. No. 1122,  A, 1-6-94) 
Sec. 2-428. - Membership. 
(a)  The commission shall consist of seven members who shall, in accordance with the City Charter, be appointed by the mayor subject to confirmation by the city council. No less than three members shall be individuals with a disability as defined in the Americans with Disabilities Act at 42 U.S.C.,  12102(2), as it may from time to time be amended. At least one member shall be a member of the immediate family of a person with a disability as defined above. At least one member shall be an elected or appointed official of the city. 
(b)  Commission members shall be appointed for and shall serve a three-year term and until a successor is appointed and confirmed unless the member resigns, is removed from office in accordance with the requirements of the City Charter, or, in the case of the one member who is appointed to fill the position as reserved for an elected or appointed city official, that member ceases his or her other elected or appointed position with the city. 
(Ord. No. 1122,  A, 1-6-94; Ord. No. 1445,  A, 3-14-07; Ord. No. 1568, 2-16-12) 
Sec. 2-429. - Organization. 
    The commission shall meet no less frequently than once each calendar month. A chairperson shall be elected at the first meeting held each calendar year by majority vote of the commission members. A quorum shall consist of four members. The commission shall keep records of its meetings and actions, including minutes of each regular meeting, and shall prepare an annual report which shall be submitted to the mayor and city council. 
(Ord. No. 1122,  A, 1-6-94; Ord. No. 1611 , 2-23-15) 
Sec. 2-430. - Gifts. 
    The commission may receive gifts of property, both real and personal, in the name of the city but subject to the prior approval of the city council. Such gifts as are received shall be managed or controlled by the commission in furtherance of the commission's enumerated purposes subject to such review by the city auditor as is reasonable or required by law. 
(Ord. No. 1122,  A, 1-6-94) 
Secs. 2-431-2-435. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - YOUTH COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-436. - Establishment. 
    There is hereby established in the city a commission to be known as the youth commission. 
(Ord. No. 1147,  A, 6-15-95) 
Sec. 2-437. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the youth commission is to identify the need for social, cultural and recre-ational activities for the youth of the city and to provide information on programs providing such activities. 
(Ord. No. 1147,  A, 6-15-95) 
Sec. 2-438. - Composition. 
    The number of members shall be no fewer than 11 and no more than 20. 
    The youth commission shall meet no less frequently than six times each calendar year. 
    At least 70 percent of members shall be between the ages of 12 and 19 at time of appointment. 
    Notwithstanding Chapter 2, Article IV, Division 1, section 2-260, members of the youth commission are required to either be a resident of the city or attend a city school. 
    There shall be a minimum of one member from each of the city's middle schools. 
    There shall be a minimum of at least two members from each of the city's high schools. 
    No more than 50 percent of members from any one school shall be represented on the commission. 
(Ord. No. 1147,  A, 6-15-95; Ord. No. 1585, 4-4-13; Ord. No. 1598, 5-1-14) 
Sec. 2-439. - Appointment; term. 
    Youths interested in becoming a member of the youth commission must first complete an application. The active youth commission will screen applicants through an interview process and submit those approved applicants to the city council. The mayor shall appoint youth commission members subject to city council confirmation. 
(Ord. No. 1147,  A, 6-15-95; Ord. No. 1585, 4-4-13) 
Sec. 2-440. - Filling vacancies. 
    Any vacancy occurring otherwise than by expiration of a term shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as the original appointment. 
(Ord. No. 1147,  A, 6-15-95) 
Sec. 2-441. - Powers and duties. 
    The youth commission shall be empowered to: 
(1)  Research and identify the need for social, cultural and recreational activities for the youth of the city; 
(2)  Provide information, referrals and guidance to individuals, public agencies, businesses and civic organizations regarding such activities; and 
(3)  Publish a monthly schedule of such activities. 
The youth commission will facilitate the funding of these activities when possible. 
(Ord. No. 1147,  A, 6-15-95) 
Sec. 2-442. - Organization. 
    If a member reaches the age of 21 while in term they will finish the term at the end of the city's current fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. 1147,  A, 6-15-95; Ord. No. 1585, 4-4-13) 
Sec. 2-443. - Gifts. 
    The youth commission may receive gifts of property, both real and personal, in the name of the city but subject to the prior approval of the city council. The youth commission shall manage or control such gifts in furtherance of the youth commission's enumerated purposes subject to such review by the city auditor as is reasonable or required by law. 
(Ord. No. 1147,  A, 6-15-95) 
DIVISION 10. - COMMUNITY PRESERVATION COMMITTEE 

Sec. 2-444. - Established. 
    There is hereby established in the city in accordance with the provisions of M.G.L.A. c. 44B, Massachusetts Community Preservation Act ("the Act"), a committee to be known as the community preservation committee ("the committee"). 
(Ord. No. 1348, 3-20-03) 
Sec. 2-445. - Purpose; powers and duties. 
    The purpose of the committee shall be to undertake the duties of a community preservation committee as set forth in the Act. In furtherance thereof, the committee shall exercise all powers and perform all duties set forth in the Act as it may from time to time be amended. 
(Ord. No. 1348, 3-20-03) 
Sec. 2-446. - Membership; term of office; vacancy; special municipal employees. 
(a)  The committee shall consist of seven members, one each to be designated by (i) the conservation commission; (ii) the historical commission; (iii) the planning board; (iv) the parks and recreation commission, and (v) the Westfield Housing Authority, from among their membership; and two citizens of the city to be appointed by the mayor subject to confirmation by the city council. 
(b)  The term of each committee member shall be three years, subject to the following. When the committee is first constituted, the term shall be from the date of designation or appointment to the first Monday of the month of February next following and three years thereafter. Members shall serve until resignation, duly accepted, or until a successor is duly qualified and appointed. 
(c)  Subject to section 2-446(d), below, any vacancy occurring otherwise than by expiration of a term shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as the original appointment. 
(d)  In the event of the dissolution of one of the appointing authorities as designated, the position on the committee filled by said appointing authority shall be declared vacant and said vacancy shall, unless otherwise mandated by state law, be filled by the mayor as if the position were one of the two citizen appointments reserved to the mayor, above. 
(e)  Committee members shall serve part-time without compensation, and are hereby classified as special municipal employees within the meaning of M.G.L.A. c. 268A. 
(Ord. No. 1348, 3-20-03) 
Cross reference- Historical commission,  2-391 et seq.; parks and recreation commission,  11-51 et seq.; planning board,  13-21 et seq.; conservation commission,  13-151 et seq. 
Sec. 2-447. - Organization. 
(a)  The committee shall meet no less frequently than once each calendar quarter with special meetings to be called by the chairperson as necessary. A chairperson shall be elected at the first meeting of the committee and at the first regular quarterly meeting of each calendar year thereafter. The first order of business after the election of the chairperson shall be the designation of the date and time of the regular quarterly meetings. 
(b)  The committee shall not conduct business without the presence of a quorum and, in the absence of a quorum, shall not meet other than to set a date and time for the next meeting. A majority of the members of the committee shall constitute a quorum. The committee shall approve its actions by majority vote. 
(c)  The committee may adopt and promulgate such lawful rules and regulations, not inconsistent with its powers and duties, as it deems appropriate for the conduct of its business. No proposed rule or regulation shall be adopted at the meeting at which it is first introduced provided, however, that amendments to a previously introduced rule or regulation may be made and voted on at the meeting in which first offered. Rules and regulations shall be codified and shall not be effective until filed with the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 1348, 3-20-03) 
Secs. 2-448-2-450. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ENGINEERING[15] 
Footnotes: 
--- (15) --- 
Cross reference- Planning and development, ch. 13; streets and sidewalks, ch. 16; traffic and motor vehicles, ch. 17; water and sewers, ch. 18. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-451. - Department of engineering established. 
    There is hereby established a department of engineering. 
(Code 1971,  2-77) 
Sec. 2-452. - Engineering department to be run by city engineer. 
    The department of engineering shall be under the direction and control of an administrative officer, titled the city engineer. 
(Code 1971,  2-78) 
Sec. 2-453. - Appointment, qualifications and term of city engineer. 
(a)  The city engineer shall be appointed by the mayor with the confirmation of the city council. The city engineer must have at least ten years of full-time paid experience in civil engineering, field or office work, of professional caliber. The city engineer must possess a current and valid registration as a professional engineer with the ability to obtain, within six months of employment, registration by the state board of professional engineers and land surveyors. Substitution of up to five years of the required experience may be met by successfully completed years of engineering training as follows: 
(1)  In a recognized university or engineering school granting the Bachelor's degree or the Master's degree on the basis of one school year for one year of the required experience; 
(2)  In a recognized technical school not granting the Bachelor's degree, on the basis of one school year for one-half year of experience; or 
(3)  An equivalent combination of subsections (1) and (2). 
(b)  The term of the city engineer shall be for three years, starting on the first Monday in February, and, unless sooner removed, shall hold office until the appointment and qualification of a successor. 
(Code 1971,  2-79; Ord. No. 1006,  2-79, 2-82, 8-17-89) 
Sec. 2-454. - Duties of city engineer. 
    Acting under the general direction of the board of engineering, the city engineer shall have sole charge and control of and shall perform all the engineering work for the city, and shall be responsible for carrying out all engineering details of the master plan. He shall: 
(1)  Make and prepare, or cause to be made, all needed specifications and plans describing and governing the work of constructing or reconstructing all sewers, storm drains, streets and sidewalks and other public works and shall have full authority to see that plans are properly executed. 
(2)  Perform all such services respecting the waterworks of the city as are proper for a civil engineer to perform. 
(3)  Make or cause to be made all surveys and prepare all plans required by the board of assessors for use as tax maps, and all surveys and plans required by any other department, board or committee. 
(4)  Perform all traffic engineering and make all surveys and studies required in reference thereto. 
(5)  At least once in every two months, give a report to the board of engineering of the progress of the various departments in carrying out the master plan. 
(Code 1971,  2-80) 
Sec. 2-455. - Assistant city engineers. 
    The board of engineering may appoint such other persons under civil service rules and regulations as may be required to aid the city engineer in the performance of his duties. 
(Code 1971,  2-81) 
Sec. 2-456. - Assistant civil engineer. 
    The assistant civil engineer, by nature of his job, will be clerk of the works, inspector and assistant engineer in the engineering department. The assistant civil engineer, among other duties, shall work as directed by the engineer on projects of special interest to the city. 
(Ord. No. 829, 6-19-80) 
Secs. 2-457-2-465. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF ENGINEERING[16] 

Footnotes: 
--- (16) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1232, adopted May 6, 1999, repealed div. 2, which pertained to the board of engineering, and replaced it with a new div. 2 pertaining to similar provisions. See the Code Comparative Table. 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions and committees,  2-256 et seq. 

Sec. 2-466. - Created; composition. 
    There is hereby created a board of engineering. Such board shall consist of the superintendents of public works, sewage wastewater treatment, water, buildings and gas and electric, and the city planner, community development director and the city engineer. Each member of the board shall be prepared to discuss and update projects to with they have a responsibility. 
(Ord. No. 1232, 5-6-99) 
Sec. 2-467. - Mayor to serve as chairman. 
    The mayor shall serve as chairman of the board of engineering without compensation. The city engineer shall serve as the secretary to the board and shall file the minutes of each meeting with the city clerk within seven days. 
(Ord. No. 1232, 5-6-99) 
Sec. 2-468. - Monthly meetings. 
    Meeting of the board shall be held at least three months or at such other times as the chairman may deem advisable. 
(Ord. No. 1232, 5-6-99) 
Sec. 2-469. - Coordination of the work of other boards. 
    The board of engineering shall coordinate the work of the board of public works, water, sewage wastewater treatment, buildings and gas and electric. The board of engineering shall be responsible for ongoing projects of each department represented on the board of engineering. 
(Ord. No. 1232, 5-6-99) 
Secs. 2-470-2-479. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - DEPARTMENT OF INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY[17] 

Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1491, adopted Jan. 13, 2009, added art. VI, consisting of  2-470-2-474, to the Code. At the editor's discretion the new provisions were redesignated as 2-480-2-484 to allow for growth in art. V. 
Subsequently, Ord. No. 1521, adopted May 6, 2010, amended art. VI in its entirety to read as herein set out. 

Sec. 2-480. - Department of information technology established. 
    There is hereby established a department of information technology to serve the needs of city departments including the school department. 
(Ord. No. 1521, 5-26-10) 
Sec. 2-481. - Head of department; appointing authority. 
    The department of information technology shall be under the direction and control of an administrative officer titled information technology manager. The information technology manager shall serve as the head of the department of information technology, shall oversee preparation and administration of the budget of the department and shall serve as appointing authority for such assistants as are authorized by the mayor and city council to assist the information technology manager in the performance of required duties. 
(Ord. No. 1521, 5-26-10) 
Sec. 2-482. - Appointment, term of information technology manager. 
    The information technology manager shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation by vote of the city council, for a term of three years from the date of the commencement of their duties as information technology manager, or until a successor is chosen and duly qualified. 
(Ord. No. 1521, 5-26-10) 
Sec. 2-483. - Duties of information technology manager. 
    The information technology manager shall guide, develop and implement the information technology plans of the city in consultation with city and school officials. As part of implementing the city's information technology plans, the information technology manager shall provide for staff training, hardware and software procurement, and the installation, maintenance and repair of the city's information technology systems. 
(Ord. No. 1521, 5-26-10) 
Sec. 2-484. - Purpose and authority. 
    This article is adopted in accordance with the authority granted, inter alia, by chapter 294 of the Acts of Massachusetts of 1920, as amended, and the powers granted to cities in the Massachusetts General Laws. It is intended that the department of information technology as hereby created shall have the status of a municipal data processing center as authorized by M.G.L.A. c. 41,  23D; that the information technology manager as appointed hereunder shall have the duties and privileges of a data processing coordinator as specified therein and shall not, therefore, be subject to the provisions of M.G.L.A., c. 31. 
(Ord. No. 1521, 5-26-10) 
Secs. 2-485-2-489. - Reserved. 
Chapter 3 - ADVERTISING[1]

Sec. 3-1. - Posting restricted generally. 
    No person shall make any marks, letters or figures of any kind, or make, paint, place or affix any notice, sign, advertisement or placard upon or against any stone, fence, ledge, tree or natural object in the city, or upon any wall, building or land in the city, unless it is done by authority of law, or is of some matter concerning the affairs or business of the owner or occupant thereof and by his permission. 
(Code 1971,  3-1)
