Sec. 6-116. - Established. 
    A board of appeals is hereby established. 
(Code 1971,  6-48) 
Sec. 6-117. - Regular membership. 
    The board of appeals shall consist of the head of the fire department, ex officio, who may designate from time to time a person serving in the fire department to act temporarily as a member of such board, with the same powers and duties as other members of the board, and two members appointed by the mayor subject to the confirmation of the city council. One of the members so appointed shall be either a professional engineer registered under the provisions of M.G.L.A. c. 13,  45-47 and M.G.L.A. c. 112,  81D-81T, or an architect registered under the provisions of M.G.L.A. c. 13,  44A-44D and M.G.L.A. c. 112,  60A-60J; and one shall be either a master electrician licensed under the provisions of M.G.L.A. c. 141, or a master plumber licensed under the provisions of M.G.L.A. c. 142. 
(Code 1971,  6-49) 
Sec. 6-118. - Terms of office of regular members. 
    The first appointments of regular members made to the board of appeals shall be for terms of two and four years respectively, so that the term of one member shall expire biennially. All subsequent appointments of members shall be for terms of four years. 
(Code 1971,  6-50) 
Sec. 6-119. - Associate members. 
    There shall be appointed by the mayor two associate members of the board of appeals, subject to the confirmation of the city council, either of whom may be a registered professional engineer, a registered architect, a licensed master plumber, or a licensed master electrician. The first appointments of the associate members made hereunder shall be for terms of two and four years respectively, so that the term of one associate member shall expire biennially. All subsequent appointments of associate members shall be for terms of four years. 
(Code 1971,  6-51) 
Sec. 6-120. - Annual election of chairman, clerk. 
    The board of appeals shall elect annually a chairman from its own number, and a clerk. 
(Code 1971,  6-52) 
Sec. 6-121. - Replacement of members. 
    In case of a vacancy, inability to act, or interest on the part of a member of the board of appeals, his place shall be taken by an associate member designated by the majority and the chairman. 
(Code 1971,  6-53) 
Sec. 6-122. - Removal of members for cause. 
    Any member of the board of appeals may be removed for cause by the appointing authority on written charges, and after a public hearing. 
(Code 1971,  6-54) 
Secs. 6-123-6-145. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - APPEALS 

Sec. 6-146. - Appeal of denial of building permit; time limitation. 
    A person whose application for a permit required by this chapter has been refused by the superintendent of building shall appeal to the board of appeals within 30 days after receipt of written notice of such refusal, or the refusal by the superintendent of building shall stand and no similar appeal shall be permitted thereafter for a period of two years from the date of the notice of such refusal. 
(Code 1971,  6-60) 
Sec. 6-147. - Appeal from order to incur expense; time limitation. 
    Except as provided in the General Laws, a person who has been ordered by the superintendent of building to incur expense for any reason under this chapter shall appeal within 30 days from the date of such order, or such order by the superintendent of building shall stand, and no appeal therefrom shall be permitted thereafter. 
(Code 1971,  6-61) 
Sec. 6-148. - Appeal from adverse interpretation of chapter disallowing construction; time limit. 
    A person aggrieved by an adverse interpretation of the city's building code and a disallowance by the superintendent of building of proposed construction shall appeal from such disallowance within 30 days after the date thereof, or such disallowance by the superintendent of building shall stand and no appeal shall be permitted thereafter. 
(Code 1971,  6-62) 
Sec. 6-149. - Appeals to be on certain forms; appeal fees. 
    All appeals filed under this chapter shall be on forms provided by the superintendent of building, and shall be accompanied by such fee as may be established by the city council. 
(Code 1971,  6-63) 
Sec. 6-150. - Referral of cases without cost to board of appeals. 
    The superintendent of building may refer such cases, as in his opinion justice requires, without fee to the board of appeals for its decision. 
(Code 1971,  6-64) 
Sec. 6-151. - Notice of appeal; filing; contents. 
    The notification of appeal shall be filed with the board of appeals and with the superintendent of building, and shall specify the grounds thereof. 
(Code 1971,  6-65) 
Sec. 6-152. - Transmittal of documents, records, etc. 
    Upon the filing of a notice of appeal, the superintendent of building shall forthwith transmit to the board of appeals all papers or documents constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken. 
(Code 1971,  6-66) 
Sec. 6-153. - Date of appellate hearing; notice of same. 
    The board of appeals, upon receipt of a notice of appeal, shall fix a date for a hearing within 30 days, and shall give notice thereof in a newspaper of general circulation in the city, and shall also send notice by mail, messenger or other means to the superintendent of building, the appellant and the owners of property deemed by the board of appeals to be affected thereby. 
(Code 1971,  6-67) 
Sec. 6-154. - Appearance at hearing. 
    At the hearing of an appeal filed under this article, the superintendent of building, the appellant and any interested party may appear in person, by agent or by attorney. 
(Code 1971,  6-68) 
Sec. 6-155. - Variances of terms of chapter on appeal. 
    The board of appeals, when appealed to and after due notice and a hearing, may vary the application of any provision of this building code to any particular case where, in its opinion, the enforcement thereof would do manifest injustice; provided that, the decision of the board of appeals shall not conflict with the spirit of any provision of the city's building code. 
(Code 1971,  6-69) 
Sec. 6-156. - Decisions requiring unanimous assent of board of appeals. 
    If the decision of the board of appeals is made to vary the application of any provision of the city's building code, or to modify an order of the superintendent of buildings, such decision shall require the unanimous assent of the board. 
(Code 1971,  6-70) 
Sec. 6-157. - Justification of judgment rendered for the appellant. 
    A decision of the board of appeals to vary the application of any provision of the building code, or to modify an order or disallowance of the superintendent of building, shall specify in what manner such variation or modification is made, the conditions upon which it is made and the reasons therefor. 
(Code 1971,  6-71) 
Sec. 6-158. - Decisions to be in writing; vote to be indicated. 
    Every decision of the board of appeals under this article shall be in writing, and shall indicate the vote of each member upon the decision. 
(Code 1971,  6-72) 
Sec. 6-159. - Filing, posting of decisions; to be open to public. 
    Every appellate decision of the board of appeals shall be immediately filed in the office of the superintendent of building and in the office of the city clerk, and shall be open to public inspection. A certified copy of each decision shall be sent by mail or otherwise to the appellant, and a copy thereof shall be kept publicly posted in the office of the superintendent of building for 15 days after filing. 
(Code 1971,  6-73) 
Sec. 6-160. - Time limit for decision. 
    The board of appeals shall, in every case, reach a decision within five days after any appellate hearing, or the whole action shall become null and void, and such refusal, order or disallowance shall stand, and no appeal shall be permitted. 
(Code 1971,  6-74) 
Sec. 6-161. - Effect of decision for appellant as to establishing precedent. 
    If any refusal, order or disallowance of the superintendent of building is reversed or modified, or the application of any provision of this chapter is varied by a decision of the board of appeals, the superintendent of building shall take action in accordance with such decision, but no decision of the board shall be regarded as establishing a precedent or be held to amend this building code or the interpretation thereof by the superintendent of building. 
(Code 1971,  6-75) 
Sec. 6-162. - Appeal to county court as alternative remedy; time limit on filing appeal; remedy to be exclusive. 
    Any person, whether or not previously a party to any proceedings before the board of appeal who is aggrieved by a decision of the board of appeals, or any municipal officer or board, may appeal to the superior court sitting in equity for the county; provided that such appeal is filed in the court within 15 days after such decision is recorded. The court shall hear all pertinent evidence and determine the facts, and, upon the facts as so determined, annul such decision if found to exceed the authority of such board, or make such other decree as justice and equity may require. The foregoing remedy shall be exclusive, but the parties shall have all rights of appeal and expectations as in other equity cases. 
(Code 1971,  6-76) 
Sec. 6-163. - When costs are allowed against board of appeals on appeal. 
    Costs shall not be allowed against the board of appeals on appeal from its decision unless it shall appear to the county court that the board acted with gross negligence, or in bad faith, or with malice in making the decision from which the appeal was taken. 
(Code 1971,  6-77) 
Chapter 7 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- City departments, boards and officers,  9. 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 6; health and environmental regulations, ch. 8; keeping and storing explosives,  10-9; planning and development, ch. 13; zoning,  13-1; subdivision regulations,  13-2; water and sewers, ch. 18. 
State Law reference- Fire prevention generally, M.G.L.A. c. 148. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 7-1. - Fire pits, chimineas, outdoor fireplaces. 
(a)  Definitions . The following definitions shall be used for the provisions of [this section]. 
    Attended . Under the personal supervision of an adult over the age of 18 who shall remain at the location of the fire until the fire is thoroughly extinguished. 
    Chiminea . Portable devices, as defined by the manufacturer, intended to contain and control outdoor fires and which emit smoke or products of combustion from an enclosed chamber through a stack, chimney, duct, flue or pipe. 
    Fire pit . Portable devices, as defined by the manufacturer, intended to contain and control outdoor fires; permanently or temporarily constructed above-ground and below ground pits intended to contain and control outdoor fires. 
    Nuisance . Any odor, emission, or event that prevents the reasonable use and enjoyment of one's property. 
    Outdoor burning device . Any chiminea, fire pit, outdoor fireplace as defined in this section. 
    Outdoor fireplace . Portable devices, as defined by the manufacturer, intended to contain and control outdoor fires which may be open in design or which emit smoke or products of combustion from an enclosed chamber through a stack, chimney, duct, flue or pipe; permanently constructed devices intended to contain and control outdoor fires which may be open in design or which emit smoke or products of combustion from an enclosed chamber through a stack, chimney, duct, flue or pipe. 
(b)  Use of fire pit . The primary purpose of the fire must be for cooking unless a burning permit is obtained from the city fire department and all relevant conditions of such permit are adhered to. Cooking fires must be reasonable in size. Use must also comply with general requirements for all outdoor burning devices as stated in subsection (e) of this section. 
(c)  Use of chiminea . The primary purpose of the fire need not be for cooking and a burning permit is not required. Use must also comply with general requirements for all outdoor burning devices as stated in subsection (e) of this section. 
(d)  Use of outdoor fireplace . Unless the outdoor fireplace emits smoke or products of combustion from an enclosed chamber through a stack, chimney, flue or pipe, the primary purpose of the fire must be for cooking unless a burning permit is obtained from the city fire department and all relevant conditions of such permit are adhered to. Cooking fires must be reasonable in size. If the outdoor fireplace emits smoke or products of combustion from an enclosed chamber through a stack, chimney, duct, flue or pipe the primary purpose of the fire need not be for cooking and a burning permit is not required. Use must also comply with general requirements for all outdoor burning devices as stated in subsection (e) of this section. 
(e)  General requirements for all outdoor burning devices . All use of outdoor burning devices must be attended, conducted during periods of good atmospheric ventilation and without causing a nuisance. If the city fire department receives a complaint that the smoke or product of combustion emitted from an outdoor burning device is causing a nuisance, the fire department will investigate and if necessary, have the fire extinguished. 
The outdoor burning device may only be upon a flat surface of sandy or gravelly land or otherwise non-combustible material free from living or dead vegetation. Any permanently constructed outdoor burning device may be constructed using only non-combustible materials. 
The outdoor burning device shall not be located within 20 feet of any structure and shall not be used on decks and porches. 
For those outdoor burning devices in which wood is burned, only the burning of aged dried wood is permitted. 
Burning of grass, hay, leaves, stumps and tires is prohibited. The burning of any type of construction material or trash is prohibited. 
(f)  Penalty . The city fire department, through its agents and employees, is hereby empowered to enforce the provisions of this section pursuant to M.G.L.A. c. 40  21D and M.G.L.A. c. 111  31C. Whoever violates the provisions of this section shall be penalized by non criminal penalty of $50.00 for the first offense, $75.00 for the second offense and $100.00 for the third and each subsequent offense. Each day or portion thereof shall constitute a separate offense. If more than one, each condition violated shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 1683, 7-5-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1683, adopted July 5, 2018, repealed the former  7-1, and enacted a new  7-1 as set out herein. The former  7-1 pertained to open burning and derived from Ord. No. 1642 , adopted April 7, 2016. 
State Law reference- Fires in open air, M.G.L.A. c. 48,  13. 
Sec. 7-2. - False alarms. 
(a)  Defined. For the purposes of this section, the words "false alarm" shall mean the triggering of the alarm by any cause other than a person whose presence the alarm system is intended to report, or the occurrence of a fire such alarm is designed to report. 
(b)  Fee. A fee of $35.00 shall be assessed against any resident for each false alarm, after the first three false alarms in any calendar year brought about by the triggering of such resident's home burglar or fire alarm system which results in either a police or fire department call to such resident's home. 
(c)  Application. The provisions of subsections (a) and (b) above and subsection (d) below shall apply to any and all false alarms reported from any business in the city, whether such business is operated by a resident or nonresident of the city. 
(d)  Disconnection. Upon failure to pay the $35.00 fee within 30 days of the sending of a bill to such resident or person operating such business, the city may require that such burglar or fire alarm system shall be disconnected so that such system no longer gives notice to the police or fire department upon being triggered. 
(Ord. No. 870,  9-35, 5-19-83; Ord. No. 1490, 1-13-09) 
Sec. 7-3. - Mutual aid agreements and activities. 
    The fire commission is hereby authorized to enter into mutual aid agreements pursuant to M.G.L.A. c. 48,  59A. Such an agreement shall include the authority to expend funds for a contingency fund for mutual aid expenses and equipment. The fire commission may delegate to the fire chief, or in his absence the chief officer in charge, the implementation of such mutual aid agreements. 
(Ord. No. 985, 10-6-88) 
Sec. 7-4. - Engineered lumber notice. 
(a)  Definitions . 
(1)  Engineered lumber shall mean prefabricated I-joists, truss joists, and truss rafters, and laminated beams and studs. 
(2)  Structure shall mean primary, secondary and accessory structures as defined in the Massachusetts State Building Code that have electrical meters that serve the structure. 
(b)  Application. 
(1)  All structures constructed with engineered lumber after the effective date of this section must have a reflective symbol affixed to each electrical meter serving the structure. 
(2)  The reflective symbol shall be in the form of a sticker issued by the city that states that the structure is constructed with engineered lumber. The sticker shall be issued by the building department. 
(c)  Violation . Any person violating this section by refusing to use the reflective symbol or by removing the reflective symbol shall be subject to a fine in an amount of $25.00 per violation. Each day that a violation occurs shall constitute a separate violation, subject to a separate fine. 
(d)  Compliance . The owner of any structure that was constructed with engineered lumber prior to the effective date of this section is requested to place the reflective symbol on the electrical meter serving the structure on a voluntary basis. 
(Ord. No. 1509, 1-14-10) 
Secs. 7-5-7-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 7-21. - Fire chief. 
(a)  The office of fire chief is hereby created. Such office shall be filled pursuant to applicable statutes, Charter provisions and ordinances. 
(b)  In addition to amounts allowed pursuant to subsection (a), in the cases of longevity plan, uniform allowance, holidays and sick leave, the fire chief may be allowed other amounts if agreed to in negotiations by the mayor and approved for funding by the city council. 
(Code 1971,  7-1; Ord. No. 1007, 8-17-89) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees,  2-61 et seq. 
Sec. 7-22. - Deputy chiefs. 
(a)  Offices established. The offices of deputy chief, second deputy chief, third deputy chief, fourth deputy chief and fifth deputy chief of the fire department are hereby established. 
(b)  Appointment. Deputy chiefs of the fire department shall be appointed by the fire commissioners in accordance with and subject to the laws of the commonwealth and the civil service rules and regulations pertaining thereto. 
(c)  Duties. Deputy chiefs shall perform such duties as the board of fire commissioners and chief of the fire department may direct. One deputy chief shall be designated as the fire prevention officer. 
(d)  Chain of command. In the absence of the fire chief, the first deputy chief shall act as chief during such absence, and be subject to the regulations and amenable to the same rules as have application to the chief. In the absence of the chief and the first deputy chief, the second deputy chief shall act as chief and shall be subject to the same rules and regulations as have application to the chief. In the absence of the chief, the first deputy chief and the second deputy chief, the third deputy chief shall act as chief and shall be subject to the same rules and regulations as have application to the chief. In the absence of the chief, the first deputy chief, the second deputy chief, the third deputy chief and the fourth deputy chief, the fifth deputy chief shall act as chief and shall be subject to the same rules and regulations as have application to the chief. 
(e)  Seniority. The office of the first deputy chief shall be held by the deputy chief senior in grade of deputy chief; the office of second deputy chief shall be held by the deputy chief next senior in grade of deputy chief; the office of third deputy chief shall be held by the deputy chief next senior in grade of deputy chief; the office of fourth deputy chief shall be held by the deputy chief next senior in grade of deputy chief; and the fifth deputy chief shall be held by the deputy chief least senior in grade of deputy chief. 
(Code 1971,  7-2-7-6) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees,  2-61 et seq. 
Sec. 7-23. - Captains in the permanent force. 
    The offices of nine captains in the permanent force of the fire department are hereby established. Captains shall perform such duties as the board of fire commissioners and the chief of the fire department may direct. One captain shall be designated as a training officer. 
(Code 1971,  7-7; Ord. No. 1171, 9-20-96) 
Sec. 7-24. - Superintendent of fire alarms. 
(a)  Office created. The office of superintendent of fire alarms in the permanent force of the fire department is hereby established. 
(b)  Appointment. The superintendent of fire alarms shall be appointed by the fire commissioners in accordance with and subject to the laws of the commonwealth and the civil service rules and regulations pertaining thereto. 
(c)  Powers, duties generally. The powers and duties of the superintendent of fire alarms shall be such as usually pertain to such office, and such as may be prescribed by law, or by the rules and regulations of the fire department. 
(Code 1971,  7-8-7-10) 
Sec. 7-25. - Emergency medical technicians. 
    Individuals receiving a permanent appointment to the fire department shall complete the emergency medical technical course within one year from the date of such permanent appointment. 
(Ord. No. 920,  7-12, 9-18-86) 
Sec. 7-26. - Reserve fire force. 
(a)  This section creates a reserve fire force pursuant to M.G.L.A. c. 48,  59B, 59C and 59D. The city hereby accepts M.G.L.A. c. 48,  59B, 59C and 59D and ordains creation of a reserve fire force. 
(b)  The reserve force shall consist of no more than 19 reserve firefighters, except, however, whenever five officers are added to the regular roster up to 80 officers, then one more reserve firefighter may be added. However, after 80 officers, one additional reserve firefighter may be added for each ten full-time firefighters added. 
(c)  The city council accepts M.G.L.A. c. 48,  59E, requiring that appointment to the reserve fire force be subject to M.G.L.A. c. 31, and that appointment of reserve firefighters would be from the eligible list provided by the division of personnel administration of the commonwealth. 
(Ord. No. 877,  7-13, 7-14, 10-20-83) 
Secs. 7-27-7-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - AMBULANCE SERVICE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic and motor vehicles, ch. 17. 

Sec. 7-41. - Operation of municipal ambulances. 
    The operation of municipal ambulances shall be governed by rules and regulations as set out by the fire commission. 
(Code 1971,  7-12) 
Cross reference- Vehicles for hire,  9-291 et seq. 
Sec. 7-42. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article the following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, unless otherwise required by the text: 
    Ambulance attendant shall mean the person in charge of the ambulance during the delivery of service to a user. 
    Charge, in the singular or plural form, shall mean the amount an insurer pays for a client's use of an ambulance, according to an insurance policy or contract or any law. 
    Insurer shall mean and include the name of the insurance company or agent with whom a user is insured directly or indirectly by contract or policy, or any governmental agency which provides medical payments to a user. 
    User shall mean the person who is transported by the city's ambulance service. 
(Ord. No. 978, 5-19-88) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally,  1-2. 
Sec. 7-43. - Charges for ambulance use. 
(a)  Pursuant to M.G.L.A. c. 40,  5F, the city is hereby establishing charges for the use of the city's ambulance service. 
(b)  Based upon the cost of providing municipal ambulance service as of November, 1990, a fee of $175.00 per each use is established and shall continue hereafter unless adjusted as provided herein. Pursuant to the provisions of M.G.L.A. c. 40,  22F, which are hereby accepted in order to effectuate the purposes as set forth herein, the city fire commission is hereby empowered and authorized, pursuant to its authority to promulgate rules and regulations for the operation of the ambulance service under section 7-41, to adjust the fee as adopted herein from time to time hereafter as, in its discretion, such adjustment is required. The authority as granted to the fire commission shall include the authority to adopt a fee schedule which sets a base rate for basic life support ambulance service with additional separate fees for services generally recognized within the health care community as advanced, specialized ambulance services; provided, however, that no fee for an advanced, specialized service shall be adopted until such time as the municipal ambulance service is capable of providing such service. In no event shall the fee for basic life support service nor the additional fee or fees for an advanced, specialized service or services exceed the maximum fee allowance or allowances for ambulance services in urban Massachusetts as established by the federal government, or its designee, for ambulance services subject to Medicare reimbursement. Any fee adjustment as adopted by the fire commission shall require a unanimous vote of the commission members prior to taking, and in order to take effect. 
(Ord. No. 978, 5-19-88; Ord. No. 1051, 12-6-90; Ord. No. 1119,  B, 10-21-93) 
Sec. 7-44. - User to give information. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, every user of the city's ambulance service shall furnish the ambulance attendant with such user's insurer, as well as the user's name and address. 
(Ord. No. 978, 5-19-88) 
Sec. 7-45. - Official form; information. 
    After completion of each use of the ambulance service, the ambulance attendant shall enter upon an official form, approved by the fire commission, information containing, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  User's name and address. 
(2)  Date and time of use of the service. 
(3)  Place the use began. 
(4)  Insurer. 
(5)  Attendant's signature. 
(Ord. No. 978, 5-19-88) 
Sec. 7-46. - Collection plan. 
    The fire commission, with the assistance of the mayor, the city auditor and the city treasurer/collector, are hereby authorized and directed to collect from users of the municipal ambulance service all charges due to the city pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 978, 5-19-88; Ord. No. 1152, 11-16-95) 
Sec. 7-47. - Entitlement to service. 
    Nothing contained in this article may be construed as a denial of ambulance service to any Westfield resident who is not insured, and nothing contained in this article may be construed that such uninsured resident shall be required to pay a charge for the use of the ambulance service. 
(Ord. No. 978, 5-19-88) 
Sec. 7-48. - Expenditure of funds. 
(a)  All monies received as charges for the use of the municipal ambulance service shall be separately accounted for in a fund known as the ambulance fund maintained separately from the city general fund. The ambulance fund shall be subject to appropriation by the mayor as approved by the city council. 
(b)  The fire department shall annually submit to the mayor an ambulance fund budget contemporaneously with the regular fire department budget. The mayor and city council shall have the same powers and duties regarding the ambulance fund budget as exist with respect to the regular fire department budget, except that monies held in the ambulance fund shall not be available for the use of nor transfer to any city department other than the fire department nor the funding of any activity, unless that activity is specified in subsection (c) below. 
(c)  The following activities are eligible for funding with ambulance fund monies: 
(1)  Payment of the full annual salaries, including the cost of all benefits, for no more than two of the eight emergency medical technician positions assigned to ambulance duty. 
(2)  Payment of required course materials, tuition and, if not included as, nor charged as, tuition, the actual cost of instructor fees, for those fire department personnel required to attend a course or courses of instruction to either obtain certification of, or maintain certification in, one of the following subject areas: 
a.  Basic emergency medical technician; 
b.  Emergency medical technician-I; 
c.  Paramedic; 
d.  Defibrillator; 
e.  Dispatcher. 
(3)  Purchase of medical supplies. 
(4)  Purchase of medical equipment. 
(5)  Purchase of rescue tools and equipment. 
(6)  Purchase and repair of radios, computers and computerized dispatch equipment. 
(7)  Purchase of ambulance run slips. 
(8)  Payment of services for ambulance billing. 
(9)  Purchase and repair of ambulances. 
(10)  Payment of such other costs or expenses related to operation of the municipal ambulance service as appropriated by the mayor and approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1121,  A, 1-6-94) 
Sec. 7-49. - Severability. 
    This article shall remain in effect until and unless otherwise amended by action of the city council. Should, however, any section or subsection of this article be held or declared invalid by a ruling of a court of competent jurisdiction, such ruling shall not affect those sections or subsections of this article not so held or declared invalid which shall continue in force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 1121,  B, 1-6-94) 
ARTICLE IV. - PUBLIC SAFETY COMMUNICATIONS DEPARTMENT 

Sec. 7-50. - Established. 
    There shall be established a department of public safety communications to enhance the emergency dispatch services for the City of Westfield. 
(Ord. No. 1571, 3-15-12) 
Sec. 7-51. - Administrator established as head of department; appointment; term; duties. 
(a)  The initial appointment of the public safety communications administrator shall be made by the mayor, upon the recommendation of the fire chief, police chief and information technology manager, subject to a confirmation vote of the Westfield City Council for a term of three years. 
(b)  All appointments thereafter shall be made by the majority vote of the public safety communications commission for a term of three years. 
(c)  The administrator shall direct the operations, planning, development, coordination and management of the public safety communications center under the administrative direction of the police and fire chiefs. 
(d)  The administrator shall be responsible for the supervision of the public safety telecommunicatiors through defined work standards and internal instructions and procedures. The administrator shall oversee the operation and maintenance of the equipment at the public safety communications center. 
(Ord. No. 1571, 3-15-12) 
Sec. 7-52. - Public safety communications commission; established, appointment and term; duties. 
(a)  A public safety communications commission is hereby established. 
(b)  The commission shall consist of five members, the chief of police, the fire chief, the information technology manager and two mayoral appointments. The mayor appointments are for three-year terms and are subject to council confirmation. 
(c)  The commission shall elect a chairperson from its membership. 
(d)  The commission will have the charge, management and control of the employees of the public safety communication center and the power to make such lawful rules for their discipline. The commission shall approve all bills of the department, including the payroll. 
(Ord. No. 1571, 3-15-12) 
Chapter 8 - HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENTAL REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 7; junk, junk dealers and junk collectors,  9-101 et seq.; spitting in public,  10-22; planning and development, ch. 13; placing garbage and refuse in streets,  16-12; water and sewers, ch. 18. 
State Law reference- Health generally, M.G.L.A. c. 111; crimes against public health, M.G.L.A. c. 270. 

ARTICLE I. - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1620, adopted April 2, 2015, repealed the former Art. I.,  8-1-8-5, and enacted a new Art. I as set out herein. The former Art. I pertained to Public Nuisances and derived from Ord. No. 1495, adopted March 19, 2009. 

Sec. 8-1. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the: "Westfield Property Maintenance Ordinance". 
(Ord. No. 1620, 4-5-15) 
Sec. 8-2. - Purpose and intent; statutory authority. 
    The intent of this article is to protect and preserve public safety, security and quiet enjoyment of the residents of the City of Westfield. The purpose is to eliminate nuisances affecting real property in the City of Westfield. Conditions such as dilapidated buildings, overgrowth of vegetation, debris, trash, stagnant water cause and contribute to blight within the city and have an adverse affect on property values and may impair the public health and safety. This article is meant to supplement existing statutory authority. 
(Ord. No. 1620, 4-5-15) 
Sec. 8-3. - Definitions. 
    Abate means to remove, stop, demolish or cure that which constitutes a public nuisance. 
    Enforcement officer means one or more of the following: superintendent of buildings and/or his designated agent; the director of public health and/or his designated agent; the fire chief and/or his designated agent. 
    Foreclosure means the process by which a property, placed as security for a real estate loan, is prepared for sale to satisfy the debt if the borrower defaults. 
    Initiation of foreclosure process means (1) taking possession of a residential property pursuant to MGL c. 244, section 1; (2) Commencing a foreclosure action on a property in any court of competent jurisdiction; or (3) recording a complaint to foreclose with the registry of deeds. 
    Nuisance means any condition which falls below the standards established by this article in section 8-3, or any condition which constitutes a nuisance at common law or which is determined by the board of health or the director of public health to constitute a nuisance pursuant to regulations adopted by them under statutory authority under MGL c. 111, section 122. 
    Owner means any person entity, service company, property manager or real estate broker who alone or severally with others has legal title to any building or parcel of land, vacant or otherwise, has care, charge or control of such a building or parcel of land, is a mortgagee in possession or has initiated the foreclosure process of such a building or parcel of land or is an agent, trustee or other person appointed by the courts and vested with possession or control of any such building or parcel of land, or is an officer or trustee of the association of unit owners of a condominium. Each such person or entity is bound to comply with the provisions of these minimum standards as if he/she/they were the owner. 
    Property means any real property, or portion thereof, or structure. 
    Vacant means any real property which is not being actively used or occupied and which has not been actively used or occupied within the preceding 90 days. This definition shall not apply to property which is being renovated or repaired or due to owner's seasonal absences. 
(Ord. No. 1620, 4-5-15) 
Sec. 8-4. - Property standards, maintenance and security requirements. 
    All property in the City of Westfield shall be maintained in accordance with the following property standards: 
(a)  General . All property, whether occupied or vacant, shall be maintained in good repair in a safe and sanitary condition. All property shall be in compliance with all state sanitary codes, building codes and City of Westfield ordinances concerning maintenance. The property shall be so maintained as to not have an adverse affect on the public health and safety or property value of adjacent or surrounding property, the public at large or public safety officials entering the property in the course of their public duties. The owner, as defined in this article, shall maintain the property on a routine basis to ensure compliance. 
(b)  Overgrowth and standing water . All property shall be maintained free of unkempt vegetation and overgrowth of any plant or materials that may reasonably encourage, foster or enhance the possibility of infestation with rodents or other animals or insects. Maintenance shall include the regular mowing of lawns, pruning and/or trimming of trees and other shrubbery and upkeep of other landscape features. Overgrowth shall be considered anything 12 inches or taller. All property shall be maintained to prevent pools of water and free of standing or stagnant water. 
(c)  Structures . All structures, including any buildings, fences, storage sheds, or any portion thereof shall be maintained in a structurally sound condition, in good repair. All property shall be maintained free of extensive peeling, flaking or chipping paint. 
(d)  Debris . All property shall be kept free of litter, refuse, garbage, accumulations of debris, trash or junk of any kind. 
(e)  Security . Every owner shall maintain every structure in a manner so that it is not open to the weather and, if vacant, so secured, pursuant to the state building and fire codes, so as to keep trespassers and children from entering the structure. 
(Ord. No. 1620, 4-5-15) 
Sec. 8-5. - Registration of vacant and foreclosure residential properties. 
(a)  All owners of vacant and/or foreclosed properties shall register such properties with the superintendent of buildings on a form as provided by said office. If the owner is an out-of-state corporation, person or other entity, the owner shall appoint an in-state agent authorized to accept service of process and other documents. 
(b)  Each registration shall state the owner's and/or agent's name, direct telephone number and mailing address. The mailing address shall not be a post office box. 
(c)  Each registration shall designate a property management contact or company responsible for the maintenance and security of this property. This designation must include the individual or company's name, direct telephone number and mailing address. The mailing address shall not be a post office box. 
(d)  All property registrations are valid for on calendar year from the date when the registration is received by the building superintendent. An annual registration fee of $100.00 must accompany the registration form. Subsequent registrations and fees are due within 30 days after the date of the expiration of the previous registration. 
(e)  Any owner that has registered a property under this section must report any change in information contained in the registration within ten days of the change. 
(Ord. No. 1620, 4-5-15) 
Sec. 8-6. - Removal of nuisance/complaints/orders to abate. 
(a)  Complaints . Whenever a written complaint is made to the board of health, the code enforcement officer, the police department or the fire department of the existence of a nuisance the board or officer shall promptly cause to be inspected the property on which the alleged nuisance exists. 
(b)  Investigation . If after inspecting the property on which the nuisance is reported, the board or officer declares the existence of a nuisance as defined herein, they may take enforcement action. 
(c)  Order to abate . The enforcement agent shall order the owner to abate any violation of the foregoing sections. Said order shall be served upon an owner in person, by registered mail, return receipt requested or by posting said notice at the site. The order shall require the owner to take such action as may be necessary to abate the violation within 14 days of receipt of notice or of the date of posting, whichever is later. 
(Ord. No. 1620, 4-5-15) 
Sec. 8-7. - Enforcement and penalties. 
(a)  Violations of any portion of this article shall be punishable by a fine of $100.00 per violation with each day the violation continues constituting a separate violation. 
(b)  The penalties provided herein shall not be construed to restrict the city from pursuing other legal remedies available. 
(c)  In addition to any other remedies available to the city, this article may be enforced by noncriminal disposition pursuant to MGL c. 40, section 21D. The noncriminal fine for each violation shall be $100.00 and each day a violation continues shall be considered a separate violation. 
(d)  Nothing in this article shall abrogate the powers and or duties of municipal officials to act pursuant to any general statutory authority, including, without limitation, MGL c. 139 and MGL c. 143. 
(Ord. No. 1620, 4-5-15) 
Sec. 8-8. - Severability interpretation. 
(a)  If any section, subsection, sentence, clause or portion of this article is for any reason held invalid or unconstitutional, each section shall be considered severable from the remainder of the ordinance and shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions thereof. 
(b)  Nothing in this article is intended to, nor shall be construed to, diminish or limit the powers, authorities and duties of the board of health. 
(Ord. No. 1620, 4-5-15) 
Secs. 8-9-8-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - HAZARDOUS MATERIAL AND UNDERGROUND STORAGE 

Sec. 8-21. - Statutory authority. 
    The city adopts the following measures under its home rule powers, its police powers to protect the public health and welfare, and its authority under M.G.L.A. c. 40,  21. 
(Ord. No. 1082,  8-212, 2-6-92) 
Sec. 8-22. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Discharge means the spilling, leaking, pumping, emitting or dumping of toxic or hazardous materials upon or into any land or waters of the city. 
    Hazardous material means any substance with such physical, chemical or infectious characteristics as to pose a potential hazard to existing or potential water supplies or to human health. Hazardous materials include, but are not limited to, toxic chemicals, road salt, heavy metals, radioactive or infectious waste, acids and alkalies, and products including, but not limited to, pesticides, petroleum products, herbicides, solvents and thinners. 
    Underground storage means storage below ground level but not including storage in a freestanding container within a building. 
(Ord. No. 1082,  8-213, 2-6-92) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction,  1-2. 
Sec. 8-23. - Discharges prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  The discharge of hazardous materials within the city is prohibited, with the following conditions: 
(1)  Disposal of sanitary sewage to subsurface sewage disposal systems approved under Title 5 of the Massachusetts Environmental Code or to a wastewater treatment facility. 
(2)  Application of fertilizers and pesticides in accordance with label recommendations and with regulations of the Massachusetts Pesticide Control Board. 
(3)  Application of roadsalts or other deicing chemicals, provided that such use is minimized and consistent with public highway safety standards. 
(4)  Proper disposal of acceptable materials at a facility or site which has received and maintained all legal approvals as specified in the Massachusetts Hazardous Waste Management Act, M.G.L.A. c. 21C,  7. 
(b)  The use of septic system cleaners, toxic or hazardous cleaners, including but not limited to: methylene chloride; orthodichlorobenzene; 1,1,1,1 Trichloroethane; acids; and trichloroethylene. 
(Ord. No. 1082,  8-214, 2-6-92) 
Sec. 8-24. - Hazardous material registration and controls. 
(a)  Every owner or operator of a commercial, industrial or agricultural operation shall store or dispense hazardous material in a manner consistent with 527 CMR 9.00. 
(b)  The fire department may require that an inventory of hazardous materials be maintained on the premises and be reconciled with purchase, use, sales and disposal records on a monthly basis. 
(c)  Hazardous materials shall be stored in product-tight storage containers and shall be removed and disposed of in accordance with the Massachusetts Hazardous Waste Management Act, M.G.L.A. c. 21C. 
(d)  The fire department may require that containers of hazardous materials be stored on an impervious, chemical-resistant surface, that the storage area be enclosed with an impermeable dike, and that the containers be protected from weather, vandalism, corrosion and leakage. 
(Ord. No. 1082,  8-215, 2-6-92) 
Sec. 8-25. - Underground storage systems-Existing. 
    The following regulations shall apply to all underground storage systems containing toxic or hazardous materials, as defined above. 
(1)  Compliance with applicable state regulations. Every owner of an underground storage system for fuel or other hazardous or toxic materials shall comply with 527 CMR 9.00 and all other applicable state regulations for such storage. 
(2)  Registration of all existing underground storage systems. 
a.  Every owner of an existing underground storage system, as of July 1, 1992, containing toxic or hazardous materials including petroleum products, whether in use or abandoned, shall apply to the fire department for a permit to have a storage facility. 
b.  Application shall be made within 60 days on a form provided by the fire department, which shall contain, at a minimum, the following information: 
1.  Name, address and telephone numbers of the owner and operator. 
2.  Address of storage tank location. 
3.  The type of materials stored. 
4.  Tank size and construction type for tank and piping. 
5.  Evidence of the date of installation and of system warranty (where the age of a tank is unknown, the tank shall be presumed to be 20 years old). 
6.  Plot plan of the site, if available, including location of the tank, pumping components, any walls or water bodies, and any subsurface drains. 
7.  Appropriate tank location marked on a copy of an 81/2?  11? street atlas map or United States Geological Survey topographic map, provided with the fire department's application form. 
8.  Leak detection, overall prevention and spill containment devices. 
9.  Corrosion prevention, if any. 
(3)  Registration tags. 
a.  Upon registering the tank with the fire department, the tank owner will receive a permanent metal or plastic tag, embossed with a registration number unique to that tank. This registration tag must be affixed to the fill pipe or in such location as to be visible to any inspector authorized by the city. 
b.  Effective June 1, 1993, every petroleum or other chemical distributor, when filling an underground storage tank, shall note on the invoice or bill for the product delivered, the registration number appearing on the tank. Every petroleum or other chemical distributor shall notify the fire department of the existence and location of any unregistered or untagged underground tank, or any tank which the distributor cannot clearly identify as being either above or below ground, which they are requested to fill. Such notification must be completed within two working days of the time the distributor discovers that the tank registration tag is not present. 
(4)  Tank removal. 
a.  Prior to the removal of an underground storage tank governed by this regulation, the owner shall first obtain a permit from the head of the fire department or the fire marshal, pursuant to M.G.L.A. c. 148. 
b.  Before any person is granted a permit by the head of a local fire department or the marshal to remove a tank under the provisions of M.G.L.A. c. 148 or 527 CMR 9.00, and such tank is not being transported to an approved tank yard, the person requesting the permit shall provide the permit granting authority with written approval from the owner/manager of the disposal site. (Reference 502 CMR 3.00 for tank removal and disposal procedure.) 
c.  Any person granted a permit by the local fire department or the marshal to remove a tank under the provisions of M.G.L.A. c. 148 or 527 CMR 9.00 shall, within 72 hours, provide the permit granting authority with a receipt for delivery of such tank to the site designated on the permit. 
(5)  Costs. In every case, the owner shall assume responsibility for costs incurred necessary to comply with this regulation. 
(6)  Abandoned tanks. Underground tanks or storage systems which are abandoned or temporarily out of service must comply with Massachusetts Board of Fire Prevention regulations under 527 CMR 9.22-23. All abandoned tanks must be drained and removed or otherwise brought into compliance with state regulations as specified in 527 CMR 9.22-23. 
(7)  Fees for registration. These permits shall be in addition to any license or permit required by M.G.L.A. c. 148, as amended, or any regulations issued thereunder. There is no fee for this permit. 
(8)  Transfer of ownership. If the ownership of any underground storage system is transferred, the seller shall notify the fire department within ten working days. Any tanks 20 years or older, without cathodic protection or other leak prevention devices, shall be removed under the supervision of the fire chief. This provision may be waived if the tank owner can prove, through testing to the satisfaction of the fire chief, the tank and piping are tight. If proof of date of installation is not known, the tank will be assumed to be 20 years old. 
(Ord. No. 1082,  8-216-8-224, 2-6-92) 
Sec. 8-26. - Same-New or replacement. 
    The following regulations shall apply to all applications for new storage systems containing toxic or hazardous materials. 
(1)  Registration of underground storage systems. All new or replacement storage systems must comply with the registration procedures in section 8-25(2). 
(2)  Procedures for review of permit applications. 
a.  Before issuance of the permit by the fire department, the owner must forward approvals of the city clerk, conservation commission, board of health and water department to the head of the fire department. 
b.  Subsequent to the effective date of this ordinance from which this article is derived, no new or replacement underground storage containers shall be installed unless the owner shall have first obtained a permit from the fire department. If the fire department determines that the proposed storage container constitutes a danger to a water supply, water body, public health or safety, the fire department may deny the permit or may grant it subject to conditions which the department determines are necessary. All new and replacement underground storage tanks, regardless of size, shall meet the requirements of Massachusetts Regulations 527 CMR 9.00 regarding tank design, construction and installation. 
c.  All new or replacement systems for class A flammables shall be located underground as required by the Massachusetts Building Code. All such storage systems shall be protected by one of the secondary containment systems specified in Massachusetts Board of Fire Prevention Regulations 527 CMR 9.08(3). The fire department, with the advice of the local officials listed in section 8-26(2)a., shall set conditions on the installation and use of UST systems storing class A flammables which may include, but are not limited to, the following: 
1.  The tanks and/or piping must have tertiary containment through the use of a buried vault or liner surrounding the tank and/or piping and filled with backfill material. 
2.  The interstitial space monitors must be able to identify vapor, product and water, and alarms from those monitors must be connected to a central point where calls to the police, fire, and water departments are automatically made when an alarm sounds. 
3.  The spill containment device must have a capacity of between ten and 25 gallons. 
4.  Spills at the dispenser area must be a capacity of between ten and 25 gallons. 
5.  The area for filling the tanks must be designed to contain a spill of 2,700 gallons or the size of one tanker truck compartment, whichever is greater. 
6.  The facility must have spill and leak contingency plans so that all employees know how to safely and rapidly respond to a spill or leak. The plans must be made together with local emergency personnel and the water department. 
7.  Safe absorbent material, booms, and other spill containment material must be kept at the facility and all staff must be trained to use them. 
8.  Monitoring wells must be installed between the facility and the nearest public wells. 
9.  The piping must be, whenever possible, European suction piping as defined in 527 CMR 9.00. 
d.  All new or replacement storage systems for toxic or hazardous materials shall be located above ground inside a structure or within the basement of a structure, within an impervious bermed containment area sufficient to contain the volume of the tank. 
e.  Aboveground tanks must comply with all applicable provisions of 527 CMR 9.00, Massachusetts Board of Fire Prevention regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1082,  8-225, 2-6-92) 
Sec. 8-27. - Report of leaks, spills or violations. 
    Any owner, agent, user or responsible party of an underground or aboveground container who is aware of a spill of ten gallons or more from any cause, or a loss of product, or unaccounted for increase in consumption which may indicate a leak or violation of this article, shall report such spill, loss or increase immediately to the head of the fire department, to the board of health, and to the office of incident response of the Massachusetts Department of Environmental Protection, as required in 527 CMR 9.20. 
(Ord. No. 1082,  8-226, 2-6-92) 
Sec. 8-28. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Any violation of the provisions of this article, the conditions of a permit granted under this article, or any decisions rendered by the fire department under this article, shall render the violator liable for a fine of no more than $100.00 for each violation. Each day such violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(b)  In addition to the procedures for enforcement as described above, any decision rendered by the fire department under this article may be enforced by the head of the fire department by noncriminal complaint pursuant to the provisions of M.G.L.A. c. 40,  21D. 
(Ord. No. 1082,  8-227, 2-6-92) 
Secs. 8-29-8-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - UNATTENDED DONATION BOXES 

Sec. 8-56. - Purpose. 
(a)  To regulate the placement of unattended donation boxes within the city to ensure that the boxes do not pose a hazard to public health, safety or have the potential to cause a nuisance. 
(b)  To ensure that material is not allowed to accumulate outside of the unattended donation boxes where it can be scattered by adverse weather conditions and to provide maintenance standards and requirements. 
(Ord. No. 1684, 8-16-18) 
Sec. 8-57. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Operator means a person, entity, association or organization who places, maintains or operates unattended donation box(es) to solicit donations of salvageable personal property. 
    Unattended donation box means any unattended container, receptacle or similar device that is located on any property within the city used for soliciting and collecting donations of clothing or other salvageable personal property. 
(Ord. No. 1684, 8-16-18) 
Sec. 8-58. - Permits and fees. 
(a)  Any person or entity seeking a permit to place an unattended donation box in the city must file a permit application with the health department which will contain the following information: 
(1)  The name, address, email and telephone number of the applicant as well as the name, address and telephone number of the person or entity responsible for maintaining each unattended donation box. 
(2)  The location of where the unattended donation box will be located including a detailed sketch indicating the position of the box on the site. 
(3)  If the applicant is not the owner of the property upon which the unattended donation box will be located, the written and notarized consent of the property owner must accompany the application. 
(4)  The schedule at which the unattended donation box will be collected/emptied and regular maintenance performed. The schedule of collection must be posted on the unattended donation box. 
(5)  Payment of the nonrefundable permit fee of $50.00. Said fee shall cover up to ten donation boxes per entity. 
(b)  Permits issued hereunder shall be valid from January 1 through December 31 of the following year and renewable for one year periods thereafter. Permits are not transferable or assignable. 
(Ord. No. 1684, 8-16-18) 
Sec. 8-59. - Prohibitions, requirements and standards for maintenance. 
(a)  Unattended donation boxes shall be appropriately located as to not create a threat to public safety including but not limited to fire lanes, loading zones, sidewalks and crosswalk entrances. 
(b)  Unattended donation boxes may not be located on any unpaved areas or within landscaped areas and cannot be located outside of setbacks. Unattended donation boxes may not be placed on any public property. 
(c)  Unattended donation boxes must be of the type that are enclosed by use of a receiving door and locked so that they are not accessible to anyone other than those responsible for the retrieval of the contents. 
(d)  Unattended donation boxes must be collected weekly with a schedule posted on each box. Any damaged box must be repaired within five business days of notice by the health department and any graffiti on the box or items left outside of the box must be cleaned within 48 hours of notice by the health department. 
(e)  Unattended donation boxes may not be placed on any parking spaces that are required per the Westfield Zoning Ordinances or any other applicable ordinances or regulations of the city. 
(f)  Unattended donation boxes shall be placed in a well-lit and visible area. 
(g)  Unattended donation boxes shall not be placed within the 100 year floodplain zone unless the name of a local agent is given and an agreement signed as part of the application process that in the event of a potential flood event and/or upon the request of the city director of public health or his/her designee, the unattended donation box be removed from the location and out of the 100 year floodplain within 24 hours. 
(Ord. No. 1684, 8-16-18) 
Sec. 8-60. - Violation/penalty and enforcement. 
(a)  The owner, lessee or other person or legal entity in control of the property where an unattended donation box is being maintained in violation of this article and the person or entity which owns, maintains or operates an unattended donation box in violation of this article shall be jointly and severally liable therefore. 
(b)  The board of health, through its authorized agents and employees, is hereby empowered to enforce the provisions of this section pursuant to M.G.L.A. c. 40,  21D. 
(c)  Whoever violates the provisions of this section shall be penalized by a non-criminal penalty of $50.00 for the first offense, $100.00 for the second offense and $200.00 for the third and each subsequent offense. 
(d)  Each and every day of the violation shall constitute a distinct and separate offense. 
(e)  A permit may be revoked by the director of public health if any violations of sections 8-58 and 8-59. The director of public health shall provide a written notification to the operator of the unattended donation box stating the specific grounds for the revocation. Upon revocation, the unattended donation box shall be removed within 30 calendar days. 
(f)  In the event that any provision of this article shall be deemed illegal or otherwise unenforceable by a court of competent jurisdiction, then only that specific provision shall not be enforced and all other sections and provisions shall remain in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 1684, 8-16-18) 
Secs. 8-61-8-90. - Reserved.
