ARTICLE V. - LITTER[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1364, adopted Dec. 4, 2003, set out provisions intended for use as Art. I,  8-1-8-9, of this chapter. For purposes of classification and for ease of indexing, these provisions have been included as Art. V,  8-151-8-159, of this chapter at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 8-151. - Short title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the "Westfield Anti-Litter Ordinance". 
(Ord. No. 1364,  8-1, 12-4-03) 
Sec. 8-152. - Purpose and authority. 
(a)  This article has as its purpose the maintenance of the public health, the preservation of property values and the promotion of the public welfare by making the city a more attractive and desirable place in which to reside and do business. 
(b)  This article is adopted in accordance with the authority granted, inter alia, by Amendment Article 89 to Article II of the Massachusetts Constitution, Chapter 294 of the Acts of Massachusetts of 1920, as amended, and the powers granted to cities in the Massachusetts General Laws. 
(Ord. No. 1364,  8-2, 12-4-03) 
Sec. 8-153. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein: 
    Building materials. The term "building materials" shall mean any material such as lumber, brick, stone, asphalt, plaster, concrete, roofing materials and any other items or substances accumulated as the result of repairs or additions to existing buildings or structures, the construction of new buildings or structures, or the demolition of any existing building or structure. 
    Bulk container. The term "bulk container" shall mean a metal container of not less than two cubic yards capacity constructed so as to be watertight but with drain plugs located therein and designed so that it can be emptied mechanically by trucks with lifting equipment designed for such a purpose. Notwithstanding the foregoing, when used solely for the disposal of waste building materials, may include an open container. 
    Business tenant. The term "business tenant" shall refer to any commercial, industrial or professional establishment renting or leasing space, or otherwise occupying, by agreement, part or all of a building which they do not own. 
    Dwelling unit. The term "dwelling unit" shall mean the individual, private premises contained in any building intended, whether occupied or not, as the residence for one household, regardless of the number of individuals in the household. A building may contain more than one dwelling unit. 
    Garbage. The word "garbage" shall mean the waste produced by the handling, processing, preparation, cooking and consumption of animal and vegetable products used for human consumption. 
    Litter. The word "litter" includes "garbage", "refuse", and "rubbish" as defined herein. 
    Over-filling. The term "over-filling" refers to the condition in which the volume of garbage, refuse and rubbish exceeds the intended capacity of the bulk container, thereby preventing a secure closing of all lids and doors. 
    Over-flowing. The term "over flowing" refers to a bulk container so over-filled that the excess has fallen out of the container or container users, being unable to further fill the container, leave garbage, refuse and rubbish adjacent to the container. 
    Owner. The word "owner" shall mean every "person" who alone or jointly or severally with others either (1) has legal title to a parcel of land; or (2) has the apparent authority over the care, charge and control of a parcel of land including, but not limited to an officer or agent of the legal title holder, attorney in fact, trustee, mortgagee in possession, executor or administrator. 
    Person. The word "person" includes a natural person but also includes all forms of business organizations and charitable and fraternal associations of natural persons, including, but not limited to, corporations, partnerships, trusts, labor unions, churches and fraternal organizations. 
    Property. The word "property" as used herein refers to that area of a parcel of real property exterior to any building or structure located thereon. 
    Residential complex. The term "residential complex" shall, without regard to form of ownership, refer to a parcel of property with no less than four separate dwelling units, each unit intended for occupancy by separate households, that provides on said parcel off street parking for residents of the complex. 
    Refuse. The word "refuse" means a putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes (except human body wastes), including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals, and solid market and industrial wastes. 
    Rubbish. The word "rubbish" shall mean nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes such as paper, wrappings, newsprint, cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, leaves, glass and bedding. 
(Ord. No. 1364,  8-3, 12-4-03) 
Sec. 8-154. - Bulk containers; required. 
(a)  The owner, and each business tenant, of every commercial, industrial or professional property or establishment and the owner of each residential complex shall be responsible for the lawful and proper removal of garbage, refuse and rubbish generated at its premises. 
(b)  In the event that such an establishment or such a complex is not served by municipal solid waste and recycling collection services, each such establishment or complex shall arrange for the lawful use of a bulk container in which to deposit the garbage, refuse and rubbish generated at its premises. 
(Ord. No. 1364,  8-4, 12-4-03) 
Sec. 8-155. - Property to be kept clean. 
    Each owner of a commercial, industrial or professional property or establishment and each owner of a residential complex must maintain the property at which the establishment or complex is located and any adjacent sidewalks, grass strips and alleys, in a clean and litter-free manner. Rubbish, refuse or other litter on any property must be removed by the owner and/or the business tenants and lawfully and properly disposed of. 
(Ord. No. 1364,  8-5, 12-4-03) 
Sec. 8-156. - Accumulated building materials, garbage, refuse or rubbish. 
(a)  Any accumulation of building materials, garbage, refuse or rubbish, not properly placed in a bulk container, on or about any commercial, industrial or professional property or establishment or on or about any residential complex is prohibited. 
(b)  Bulk containers shall be emptied with sufficient frequency so as to avoid over-filling and so as to avoid creating such noxious or putrid odors as are offensive to the general public in those areas where the public is entitled to free access. 
(c)  An over-flowing bulk container shall be considered a violation of this section. 
(Ord. No. 1364,  8-6, 12-4-03) 
Sec. 8-157. - Improper disposal of household appliances. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to leave outside any building, in a place accessible to children, any household appliance which has an airtight door or cover, such as a refrigerator, without first removing each airtight door or cover from the appliance. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place a household appliance on the treebelt or within the right-of-way of a way over which the public has a right or travel unless that person has first arranged for the collection of the appliance by the city or a proper appliance removal contractor and the appliance is placed on the treebelt or within said right-of-way no more than 24 hours in advance of its scheduled removal. 
(Ord. No. 1364,  8-7, 12-4-03) 
Sec. 8-158. - Placing building materials, garbage, refuse or rubbish on property of another. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place waste building materials, garbage, refuse or rubbish on the property of another person without that other person's authorization. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place waste building materials, garbage, refuse or rubbish in a bulk container without the authorization of the owner of the property on which the bulk container is located. 
(Ord. No. 1364,  8-8, 12-4-03) 
Sec. 8-159. - Violations; penalty. 
(a)  The board of health, through its authorized agents and employees, is hereby empowered to enforce the provisions of this section pursuant to M.G.L.A. c. 40,  21D. 
(b)  Whoever violates the provisions of section 8-158 shall be penalized by a non criminal penalty of $50.00 for the first offense, $100.00 for the second offense and $300.00 for the third and each subsequent offense. 
(c)  Each and every day of the violation shall constitute a distinct and separate offense. 
(d)  Upon failure to pay said penalty, such further enforcement action as permitted by law may be initiated. An unpaid penalty shall be considered an "overdue obligation" in accordance with the terms of Code of Ordinances, section 2-144 and is subject thereto. The board of health through the director of public health may take such other, further and different action to enforce the provisions hereof as the law permits, including initiating a civil action seeking injunctive or other relief. 
(Ord. No. 1364,  8-9, 12-4-03) 
ARTICLE VI. - SMOKE-FREE CLEAN AIR ACT FOR THE CITY OF WESTFIELD 

Sec. 8-160. - Title and introduction. 
    This article shall be known as the Smoke-Free Clean Air Act for the City of Westfield. 
    Exposure to Environmental Tobacco Smoke ("ETS") otherwise known as second-hand smoke presents a serious and substantial hazard to the public health and safety of citizens of the City of Westfield. Of particular concern is the exposure of non-smokers, children, asthmatics, and elderly to ETS in outdoor places of recreation within the city. Scientific evidence indicates that there is no risk-free level of exposure to secondhand smoke. Furthermore, ETS has been shown to cause disease and premature death in children and adults. 
(Ord. No. 1560, 12-1-11) 
Sec. 8-161. - Purpose. 
    The purpose and intent of this Act is to: 
(1)  Protect the public health and welfare by restricting smoking in all outdoor places of recreation, and 
(2)  Assure smoke-free air for non-smokers, and 
(3)  Recognize that the need to breathe smoke-free air shall have priority over the desire to smoke in public places. 
(Ord. No. 1560, 12-1-11) 
Sec. 8-162. - Authority. 
    This Act is promulgated pursuant to M.G.L.A. Chapter 270  22(j), which allows for the commonwealth or any department, agency or political subdivision of the commonwealth to set prohibitions which further limit smoking. 
(Ord. No. 1560, 12-1-11) 
Sec. 8-163. - Definitions. 
    [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
    Applicant refers to any person(s) applying for, or requesting use of, any outdoor public place. 
    Cigar means any roll of tobacco that is wrapped in leaf tobacco or any substance containing tobacco with our without a tip or mouthpiece not otherwise defined as a cigarette under M.G.L.A. c. 64C,  1. 
    E-cigarette means any electronic nicotine delivery product composed of a mouthpiece, heating element, battery and/or electronic circuits that provides a vapor of liquid nicotine. This term includes such devices whether or not they are manufactured as e-cigarettes, e-cigars, e-pipes or under any other product name. 
    Nicotine delivery product means any article or product made wholly or in part of a tobacco substitute or otherwise containing nicotine that is expected or intended for human consumption, but not including a tobacco substitute prescribed by a licensed physician or a product that has been approved by the United States Food and Drug Administration for sale as a tobacco use cessation or harm reduction product or for other medical purposes and which is being marketed and sold solely for that approved purpose. Nicotine delivery product includes, but is not limited to, e-cigarettes. 
    Outdoor public place means many city-owned, operated, or leased area which is or may be open to and used by the general public, including but not limited to: outdoor areas surrounding any city-owned, operated or leased building which is or may be open to and used by the general public, gardens, bike trails, fields, parks, beaches, swimming pools, outdoor sports arenas and athletic fields. Sidewalks and streets are not applicable under this ordinance unless they are designated for any special event such as, but not limited to a parade route or holiday festivity. 
    Smoking means the lighting of a cigar, cigarette, pipe or other tobacco or non-tobacco product or possessing a lighted cigar, cigarette, pipe or non-tobacco product designed to be combusted or inhaled. 
(Ord. No. 1560, 12-1-11; Ord. No. 1659 , 12-15-16) 
Sec. 8-164. - Prohibition of smoking on city-owned, operated or leased spaces. 
    Smoking shall be prohibited on all city-owned, operated and leased outdoor public places. 
(Ord. No. 1560, 12-1-11; Ord. No. 1659 , 12-15-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1659 , adopted Dec. 15, 2016, changed the title of  8-164 from "Prohibition of smoking on outdoor places of recreation" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 8-165. - Enforcement. 
(a)  This article shall be enforced by the Westfield Police Department and Westfield Health Department or authorized designees. 
(b)  Notice of the provisions of this article shall be given to any and all applicants for private use of outdoor places of recreation. 
(c)  Any applicant allowed use of an outdoor place of recreation shall be notified of this article and be responsible for notifying all persons in their party of this Act. 
(Ord. No. 1560, 12-1-11) 
Sec. 8-166. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person who violates this Act shall be subject to a fine of $50.00 for the first violation, and $100.00 for a second violation and each subsequent violation that occurs within one year of any prior violation. The authority enforcing this Act may use discretion on a case-by-case basis to issue a warning without fine for a first offense. 
(b)  Each instance of violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  Violations of this article shall, in accordance with the Code of Ordinances of the City of Westfield Massachusetts section 1-9.1 and Chapter 40  21D of the Massachusetts General Laws, be disposed of by Non-Criminal Disposition. 
(Ord. No. 1560, 12-1-11) 
Sec. 8-167. - Severability. 
    If any clause, section, or other part of this article shall be held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, the remainder of this article shall not be affected thereby but shall remain in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 1560, 12-1-11) 
ARTICLE VII. - MARIJUANA[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1687, adopted Sept. 20, 2018, repealed the former art. VII,  8-168-8-175, and enacted a new art. VII as set out herein. The former art. VII pertained to controlled substances and medical marijuana and derived from Ord. No. 1600, adopted May 15, 2014. 

Sec. 8-168. - Purpose. 
    The purpose and intent of this article is to protect the public health and insure that the sanctioned presence and use of marijuana (Cannabis sativa) is properly integrated with the public welfare. This article is not intended, nor shall it be construed, to apply to industrial hemp or hemp products. 
(Ord. No. 1687, 9-20-18) 
Sec. 8-169. - Authority. 
    This article is adopted pursuant to Chapter 369 of the Acts of 2012, Chapter 334 of the Acts of 2016 and M.G.L.A. c. 94G of the commonwealth and regulations promulgated by the Massachusetts Department of Public Health, 105 CMR 725.000 and Cannabis Control Commission, 935 CMR 500. The board of health may promulgate any additional rule or regulation concerning the administration of this ordinance provided it is not inconsistent with aforementioned provisions. 
(Ord. No. 1687, 9-20-18) 
Sec. 8-170. - Limitation on the quantity of marijuana retailers. 
    No marijuana facility shall be allowed to operate within the city if such facility would cause the quantity of marijuana retailers, as defined by the cannabis control commission, to exceed the greater of four or 20 percent of the number of licenses issued within the city for the retail sale of alcoholic beverages not to be drunk on the premises where sold under M.G.L.A. c. 138 15, except that for calculation purposes fractions shall be rounded up to the next whole number. 
(Ord. No. 1687, 9-20-18) 
Sec. 8-171. - Prohibition of marijuana in certain locations. 
    No person shall consume, display, nor cause odors to emit from, marijuana in any form nor any accessory device associated with same, within, into or visible from any street, sidewalk, way in which the general public is afforded access, nor on or in any city owned, operated, or leased buildings or lands. 
(Ord. No. 1687, 9-20-18) 
Sec. 8-172. - Regulation of accessory devices. 
    No appliance or accessory device customarily intended specifically for use in the application or administration of marijuana shall be displayed for sale to consumers except in a manner consistent with regulations of the board of health, who may impose limits on shelf space and restrict visual and physical access to such items from minors. 
(Ord. No. 1687, 9-20-18) 
Sec. 8-173. - Performance standards. 
    A registered marijuana dispensary, medical marijuana treatment center, marijuana shop, marijuana retailer, marijuana production operation, marijuana cultivator or similar facility wherein marijuana, in any form or product, is present shall comply with the following standards. 
(1)  No facility shall acquire, cultivate, possess, process, transfer, transport, sell, distribute, dispense, or administer marijuana, or products containing marijuana, unless possessing a valid and current registration issued by the state department of public health and/or cannabis control commission, where required. 
(2)  Each facility operating as of January 1 shall maintain a valid local registration with the board of health by submission of an annual report not later than January 31, which shall consist of a copy of all current applicable state licenses for the facility, personnel contact information and demonstrated compliance with any conditions of operation. Any changes of ownership or management staff shall be reported within 30 days. 
(3)  All such facilities shall be ventilated in such a manner that: 
a.  No pesticides, insecticides or other chemicals or products used in the cultivation or processing are dispersed into the outside atmosphere. 
b.  Any return air exhausted to the outside shall be passed through commercially available odor scrubbers. 
(4)  All aspects of the use/facility relative to the acquisition, cultivation, possession, processing, sales, distribution, dispensing, or administration of marijuana, products containing marijuana, related supplies, or educational materials must be fully enclosed and shall not be visible from the exterior of the building or delivery vehicle. No materials shall be stored out-of-doors. 
(5)  No public access to any facility, retail sales or other consumer distribution of marijuana shall occur upon the premises or via delivery from the premises, between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(6)  On-site use or consumption of marijuana is prohibited. 
(7)  No facility shall be permitted to sell Massachusetts lottery tickets, alcohol, tobacco products or nicotine delivery products. 
(8)  The provisions of section 8-171 shall be clearly posted within any publicly accessible facility under a title having text not less than one inch in height and reading "City of Westfield Ordinance Sec. 8-171" 
(Ord. No. 1687, 9-20-18) 
Sec. 8-174. - Enforcement and penalty. 
(a)  This article shall be enforced by the city police department and city health department or authorized designees thereof. 
(b)  Any person who violates this article shall be subject to a fine of $500.00 for the first violation, and $1,000.00 for a second violation and each subsequent violation that occurs within one year of any prior violation, or by revocation of the facility's local registration by the board of health. Each instance or each calendar day of a violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  Violations of this article shall, in accordance with the Code of Ordinances of the city section 1-9.1 and M.G.L.A. c. 40,  21D, be disposed of by non-criminal disposition. 
(d)  The authority enforcing this article may use discretion on a case-by-case basis to issue a warning without fine for a first offense. 
(Ord. No. 1687, 9-20-18) 
Sec. 8-175. - Severability. 
    If any clause, section, or other part of this article shall be held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, the remainder of this article shall not be affected thereby but shall remain in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 1687, 9-20-18) 
Chapter 9 - LICENSES, PERMITS AND MISCELLANEOUS BUSINESS REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Obstructing streets and sidewalks with merchandise,  16-6; parking vehicles for sale prohibited,  17-129. 
State Law reference- Licenses generally, M.G.L.A. c. 140,  1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 9-1. - Display of fruits, vegetables, foodstuffs. 
    No person shall display fruits, vegetables or foodstuffs except in the interior portion of his place of business, except as otherwise provided in this Code. 
(Code 1971,  8-1) 
Sec. 9-2. - Site approval for racing. 
(a)  In accordance with M.G.L.A. c. 128A,  13A, the mayor and the city council shall not approve a site for racing unless the following provisions are met in all regards: 
(1)  The area for a site must be zoned industrial. 
(2)  The area for a site must not be within two miles of a church, cemetery or burial ground, school, playground, public park or recreational area, housing development, fire station, hospital or public water supply. 
(3)  The area for a site must have a frontage on a public way of at least 200 feet. 
(4)  An engineering plan complete in detail as to elevations, drainage, sewerage, water and building layout must be first filed with the office of the building inspector along with a complete building plan by a certified architect as are necessary for the issuance of a building permit. 
(5)  Approval of the engineering plan and architectural plan must be given by the planning board, department of public health, and the engineering department of the city. 
(b)  It shall take a three-quarters vote of the total membership of the city council favoring the site for approval to be submitted to the state racing commission. 
(c)  The mayor shall have the right to approve or disapprove such vote and such disapproval shall be considered a veto. 
(d)  Failure to act on any of these provisions shall not constitute an affirmative action or otherwise be construed to be acceptance of the application for a site. 
(e)  These provisions shall apply to any site location in the city relating to the industry of the pari-mutuel system of betting now in existence or hereafter permitted by the state legislature. 
(Ord. No. 818,  8-210, 12-10-79) 
Sec. 9-3. - Council to grant licenses, permits. 
    The city council shall grant the licenses and permits as are required in this chapter in accordance with the provisions of law except for permits to be granted by the chief of police pursuant to section 9-73. 
(Code 1971,  8-13; Ord. No. 953,  8-13, 8-31-87) 
Sec. 9-4. - City clerk as issuing authority. 
    All licenses or permits provided for in this chapter or this Code, unless otherwise provided, shall be issued by the city clerk. 
(Code 1971,  8-14) 
Sec. 9-4.1. - Adjustment of fees. 
    The city clerk, with the approval of the mayor and with proper notification to the city council, shall from time to time, but not within the same 12-month period, review fees for permits, licenses, certified copies and other records issued from the clerk's office. 
    Following review the clerk shall adjust existing fees or establish new fees, as required. The clerk shall then submit the adjusted or newly-established fees to the city council for its approval, or revision and approval. The city clerk shall turn over all fees collected for deposit to the general fund. 
(Ord. No. 1208, 4-16-98) 
Sec. 9-5. - Expiration date of permits, licenses. 
    All licenses and permits granted under this Code or any city ordinance shall be in force until May 1 annually, unless otherwise provided by law or ordinance. 
(Code 1971,  8-15) 
Sec. 9-6. - Application to be in writing; payment of fees. 
    Applications for licenses or permits shall be made in writing. All fees therefor, including recording fees, shall be paid to the city clerk when the application is filed. 
(Code 1971,  8-16) 
Sec. 9-7. - Effective term of council authorization of license, permit issuance-Generally. 
    All licenses or permits granted or ordered by vote of the city council shall become null and void unless exercised within one year of the date of such vote granting or ordering the same. 
(Code 1971,  8-17) 
Sec. 9-8. - Same-When issued by another governmental agency. 
    All votes of the city council approving or authorizing the issuance of any permit by any other governmental agency shall become null and void unless such permit is exercised within one year of the date of such vote approving or authorizing the same. 
(Code 1971,  8-18) 
Sec. 9-9. - Return of license, permit fees. 
    In case any license or permit is not granted, the fee therefor shall be returned to the applicant therefor. 
(Code 1971,  8-19) 
Sec. 9-10. - Clerk to furnish police department with list. 
    The city clerk shall furnish the police department with a list of all licenses and permits granted. 
(Code 1971,  8-20) 
Sec. 9-11. - Schedule of fees generally. 
    The schedule of license fees for licenses required under this chapter is on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1971,  8-21) 
State Law reference- Auctioneer's license fee, M.G.L.A. c. 100,  2; hawker and peddler of fruit and vegetable license fee, M.G.L.A. c. 101,  22; fee for innholders' and common victualers' licenses, M.G.L.A. c. 140,  2; fees for lodging house license, M.G.L.A. c. 140,  23; fee for intelligence office license, M.G.L.A. c. 140,  203; fee for bartering in junk, old metal, etc., license, M.G.L.A. c. 140,  202; secondhand goods dealer's license fee, M.G.L.A. c. 140,  202; secondhand motor vehicles license fee, M.G.L.A. c. 140,  59; pawnbroker's license fee, M.G.L.A. c. 140,  202; sale of firearms license fee, M.G.L.A. c. 140,  122; license fee for billiard and pool hall and bowling alleys, M.G.L.A. c. 140,  202. 
Sec. 9-12. - Fee schedule for licenses to store, sell, etc., flammable fluids. 
    The fees to be charged for licenses under the provisions of M.G.L.A. c. 148 are hereby established. The fee required for licenses for keeping, storing and selling in a designated building or structure gasoline or other volatile flammable fluid shall be set from time to time by the council, and a schedule of such fees is on file in the office of the city clerk. The fees to be charged for a registration of a certificate under the provisions of M.G.L.A. c. 148 shall be one-half of the fee established in this section for a license for like use of the designated building or structure. 
(Code 1971,  8-22) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 7. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to make and enforce ordinances on fire prevention, M.G.L.A. c. 148,  9; licenses for inflammable materials, M.G.L.A. c. 148,  13; keeping and use of inflammable fluids in or near dwellings, M.G.L.A. c. 148,  23. 
Sec. 9-13. - Storage and registration of flammable solid materials. 
(a)  Licenses. Licenses for the storage of chlorine and other flammable solid materials may be granted by the city council. 
(1)  Applicant's conformance with NFPA 43A and M.G.L.A. c. 148 must be certified by the Westfield Fire Department at time of license application, and at time of renewal. 
(2)  The fees to be charged for licenses under the provisions of M.G.L.A. c. 148 shall be set from time to time by the council, and a schedule of such fees is on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(3)  The fees to be charged for annual registration of a license under the provisions of M.G.L.A. c. 148 shall be one-half of the application fees established herein. 
(b)  Liability insurance coverages. In addition to the above, each applicant and/or licensee must carry liability insurance in the following amounts: 
From 101 pounds to not more than 10,000 pounds ..... $  300,000.00 From 10,001 pounds to not more than 100,000 pounds .....  1,000,000.00 For more than 100,000 pounds .....  5,000,000.00  
(Ord. No. 1017, 10-19-89) 
Sec. 9-14. - Tag sales. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct a tag sale, estate sale, cellar sale, attic sale, garage sale, lawn sale or any equivalent by whatever term so designated without having first obtained a permit from the office of the city clerk. Each day, or portion thereof, on which such sale is held without a permit constitutes a separate violation. 
(b)  The fee for each permit shall be $10.00. The permit shall be issued in triplicate. One copy shall be retained and kept on file by the office of the city clerk for a period of no less that three years from date of issue. One copy shall be delivered to the police department prior to the sale. One copy shall be prominently displayed at the site of the sale by the applicant. 
(c)  Each permit as issued shall, at the applicant's discretion as specified at the time of application, be valid for up to three consecutive days. The permit shall specify the address at which the sale is permitted. No address shall receive a permit unless three days have elapsed since the expiration of a prior permit. No more than two such sales shall per permitted at a single address per calendar year. All units in a multi-family dwelling may have two such sales per unit. 
(d)  Such sales, once lawfully permitted, may be advertised by signs placed at the permitted address or by lawn signs placed on the tree belt adjacent to a public way in such a fashion as not to interfere with the traveling public, all signage to otherwise conform to the requirements of city ordinances. The prohibitions of Code of Ordinances Chapter 3, section 3-1 shall apply. The person to whom a permit is granted is required to remove, or otherwise cause to be removed, signs that advertised the sale within 24 hours after the permit for the sale expires. Failure to remove an advertising sign as required hereby is unlawful. 
(e)  In the event that the conduct of such a sale interferes with the safe flow of motor vehicle traffic, the chief of police or his designee may order that the sale cease and the permit be suspended until such time as the unsafe traffic conditions abate. Failure to suspend such a sale after such an order shall be unlawful. 
(f)  Violation may be penalized pursuant to Code of Ordinances section 1-9.1 
(g)  The city clerk may refuse to issue a permit to any applicant found to have violated the terms of this ordinance within the previous 12 months or in the event that public safety would be impaired by the issuance of the permit. 
(Code 1971,  9-26; Ord. No. 1299, 12-6-01; Ord. No. 1494, 3-19-09) 
Sec. 9-15. - Flea markets. 
(a)  Permit required. It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct a flea market or its equivalent without having first obtained a permit from the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  Issuance of permit; permit fees. Upon application by any person for a permit to conduct a flea market, the city clerk shall issue such permit in triplicate. One copy shall be retained by the city clerk for a period of three years from the date of issue; one copy shall be delivered to the chief of the police department; and one copy shall be prominently displayed by the permittee at the site of the flea market. The fee for the issuance of a flea market permit shall be $50.00 for each day of the flea market. 
(Code 1971,  9-29, 9-30; Ord. No. 1494, 3-19-09) 
Sec. 9-16. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1371, adopted March 18, 2004, repealed former  9-16 of the Code, which pertained to automatic amusement devices and derived from the 1971 Code,  9-27.

(12)  Montgomery Road from Montgomery Street to Turnpike Bridge. 
(13)  Holyoke Road-entire length. 
(14)  Pontoosic Road-entire length. 
(15)  Little River Road-entire length.

(18)  West Silver Street-entire length. 
(19)  Granville Road from Western Avenue to intersection of Granville Road and Loomis Street. 
(20)  Shaker Road-entire length. 
(21)  Mill Street-entire length. 
(22)  Washington Street-entire length. 
(23)  Smith Avenue-entire length. 
(24)  King Street Extension-entire length. 
(Code 1971,  9-28; Ord. No. 939, 3-5-87) 
Cross reference- Traffic and motor vehicles, ch. 17. 
Sec. 9-18. - Distribution of handbills, circulars, advertising. 
    No person shall distribute, or cause to be distributed, any handbill, circular, program or advertising slip, in or upon any street in the city, unless such handbill, circular, program or advertising slip is placed within the doors of stores, offices and business houses, and at the doors of residences or to a person on the street who is willing to accept the handbill, circular, program or advertising slip. 
(Code 1971,  3-4) 
Secs. 9-19-9-25. - Reserved.

(Code 1971,  8-187)
