ARTICLE III. - TRANSIENT MERCHANTS, PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1110,  A, adopted June 3, 1993, deleted, in effect repealed, art. III of this chapter and enacted similar new provisions as herein set out. Formerly, art. III pertained to hawkers, peddlers and solicitors, consisted of  9-71-9-81, and derived from  8-167-8-176 of the city's 1971 Code as amended by Ord. No. 953,  8-167-8-176, adopted Aug. 31, 1987. 
State Law reference- Hawkers and peddlers, M.G.L.A. c. 101,  13-30. 

Sec. 9-71. - Definitions. 
    The following words shall for the purpose of this article have the following meanings, unless the context requires otherwise: 
    Bona fide charitable organization means each organization lawfully registered as a charitable organization with the division of public charities of the attorney general of the commonwealth pursuant to M.G.L.A. c. 68,  18 et seq.; or any religious corporation, trust, foundation, association or organization otherwise subject to the registration requirements of M.G.L.A. c. 68,  18 et seq., but exempt therefrom by virtue of M.G.L.A. c. 68,  20; or any purportedly charitable organizations that do not receive or anticipate receiving contributions in excess of $5,000.00 on an annual basis otherwise subject to the registration requirements of M.G.L.A. c. 68,  18 et seq., but exempt therefrom by virtue of M.G.L.A. c. 68,  20. 
    Business opportunities means the opportunity to participate, for a fee, in any ongoing or contemplated business, franchise, distributorship or investment or the opportunity to participate, for a fee, in any seminar offering information about the same. 
    Consumer means an individual who purchases goods, wares, services or business opportunities for his own use, the use of members of his immediate family or for delivery as a gift; not a person engaged in business who purchases goods, wares, services or business opportunities for resale. 
    Immediate family means any individual and his/her spouse, and their parents, children, brothers and sisters. 
    Noncommercial solicitor means any person, either as principal or as employee or agent of a principal, and whether a resident of the city or a nonresident, who travels from place to place within the city for the purpose of soliciting sales of goods or wares on behalf of or donations on behalf of bona fide charitable organizations; or for the purpose of distributing, without charge, informational literature concerning religious or political beliefs. 
    Peddler means any person, either as principal or as employee or agent of a principal, and whether a resident of the city or a nonresident, who travels from place to place within the city, transporting with him/herself his/her goods or wares for retail sale and delivery to consumers then and there. Also known as "hawker." 
    Permit means the license as issued by the chief of police of the city necessary to conduct the activities as regulated in this article. 
    Retail sale means the sale of goods, wares or services at whatever price to a consumer of goods, wares or services thereby excluding the sale of goods and wares to a dealer in such goods or wares for resale. 
    Solicitor means any person, either as principal or as employee or agent of a principal, and whether a resident of the city or a nonresident, who travels from place to place within the city for the purpose of soliciting retail sales of goods, wares or services to be delivered to the consumer at a future time. Also known as "canvasser." 
    Special peddler's permit means the license as issued by the chief of police of the city granted to any person who, being a veteran of World War I, World War II, the Korean conflict or the Vietnam conflict, has first obtained a special state peddler's license pursuant to M.G.L.A. c. 101,  24. 
    Special transient merchant permit means the license as issued by the chief of police of the city, not to exceed four consecutive days in duration in any one calendar year, to any charitable organization or to a post of any incorporated organization of veterans who served in the armed forces of the United States of America in time of war or insurrection, to conduct a transient business for a period of four or fewer consecutive days. 
    Temporary business means any retail sales activity or the sale of business opportunities that is conducted (a) out of doors in a portable structure without foundation such as a trailer, tent or shed; and (b) no more than ten calendar days out of a calendar month not to exceed 60 calendar days out of a calendar year; and which is not a customary incidental use accessory to an existing nontemporary business engaged in the sale of similar and like goods or services. 
    Transient merchant means any person, either as principal or as employee or agent of a principal, and whether a resident of the city or a nonresident, who engages in a temporary business of the retail sales of goods, wares, services or the sale of business opportunities to consumers and who conducts such business at one fixed location within the city. Also known as "transient vendor." 
(Ord. No. 1110,  A, 6-3-93) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally,  1-2. 
Sec. 9-72. - Classification of permits. 
(a)  A transient merchant permit shall be known as a class I permit. 
(b)  A peddler permit shall be known as a class II permit. 
(c)  A solicitor permit shall be known as a class III permit. 
(d)  A special transient merchant permit shall be known as a class I-S permit. 
(e)  A special peddler permit shall be known as a class II-S permit. 
(f)  Any applicant may apply for a multiple classification permit without payment of any additional fee, if otherwise required. The chief of police shall have the discretion to issue a permit for more than one classification if not contrary to the terms of this article but shall not be required to do so. 
(Ord. No. 1110,  A, 6-3-93) 
Sec. 9-73. - Protection of public safety and private rights from unreasonable interference. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the activities of transient merchant, peddler, solicitor or noncommercial solicitor without having first filed, as required, application or registration with and, if required, secured a permit from, the chief of police of the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the activities of transient merchant, peddler, solicitor or noncommercial solicitor if such activities are conducted: 
(1)  Within 25 feet of the intersection of any public streets, roads or highways, such 25 feet to be measured at a 90-degree angle from the area of the activity as regulated by the terms of this article to the edge of the pavement of such street, road or highway nearest the activity in question. 
(2)  With the use of sound amplification devices which cause the sound to be audible at a decibel level greater than 65 decibels at (a) a distance greater than 100 feet from the activity in question between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m.; or (b) a distance greater than 50 feet from the activity in question at all other times. 
(3)  From any vehicle that is double-parked on a public street, road or highway. 
(4)  From any vehicle while the vehicle is traveling in reverse or engaged in a U-turn on a public street, road or highway. 
(5)  While allowing any person to hang onto the outside of any vehicle while it is traveling on a public street, road or highway. 
(6)  While any persons engaged in the activity or attracted to the activity are obstructing the free passage of pedestrian or vehicular traffic on any public street, road, highway or sidewalk. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the activities of peddler, solicitor or noncommercial solicitor at any residence or place of business either (a) clearly posted as a premises upon which "No Soliciting" is allowed; or (b) between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the activity of transient merchant without first having secured the written permission of an individual with the authority to grant to such transient merchant permission to engage in such activity on the site where such transient merchant seeks to engage in business, such written permission to be promptly provided to any city police officer upon request. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person who has been granted a permit as (1) a transient merchant to engage in the activity of a transient merchant for more than ten calendar days in any one calendar month or for more than 60 calendar days in any calendar year; or (2) a special transient merchant to engage in the activity of a special transient merchant for more than four days in any calendar year. 
(f)  The provisions of subsections (a), (b), (d) and (e) of this section shall apply to special transient merchant permits and those applying therefor. 
(g)  The provisions of subsections (a), (b) and (c) of this section shall apply to special peddlers' permits and those applying therefor. 
(Ord. No. 1110,  A, 6-3-93) 
Sec. 9-74. - Permit requirements. 
(a)  Each transient merchant, peddler or solicitor shall file application for a permit prior to engaging in any activity regulated under this article. Application for such permit shall be made to the chief of police of the city. The applicant shall: 
(1)  Present personal photographic identification such as a driver's license. 
(2)  If applying for a transient merchant permit, shall present written documentation identifying the parcel of real estate upon which the applicant intends to engage in the activities regulated hereunder, signed by the owner of such parcel or a person authorized to act on behalf of the owner, granting to the applicant the right to enter upon and use the real estate for the purposes regulated hereunder. In the event that the applicant is also the owner of the real estate upon which the activity regulated hereunder is to be conducted, a written statement to that effect, which identifies the real estate in question, shall be sufficient. 
(3)  Complete and sign the written application form provided by the city stating: 
a.  The name, residence address, business address, telephone number and social security number or federal employer (FID) number of the applicant. 
b.  The same information as in subsection (a)(3)a. above for any corporation, trust, partnership, association or individual upon whose behalf the applicant is filing the application. 
c.  The permit classification desired (see section 9-72). 
d.  The kind of goods or services to be offered. 
e.  For transient merchant permits, the address of the real estate where the activity is to be conducted with the name and address of the owner of same. 
f.  The description of any and all motor vehicles to be used by the applicant in the course of engaging in the regulated activity. 
g.  The names of all persons, whether relatives, employees or agents, who are to participate or assist in conducting the regulated activity. 
h.  A statement pursuant to M.G.L.A. c. 62C,  49A, signed under the pains and penalties of perjury, reciting that the applicant is and shall remain in compliance with the laws, ordinances and regulations of the commonwealth and of the city relative to the payment of sales taxes and such other duties applicable to the goods or services which the applicant intends to offer. 
(4)  Submit to fingerprinting, the results of which shall be maintained with the applicant's application; this requirement may be waived by the chief of police upon satisfactory proof of the personal identity of the applicant. 
(5)  Each transient merchant, peddler or solicitor shall pay a nonrefundable administration fee of $100.00 for the processing of the required application. This fee shall be waived if the application is for a special transient merchant permit or a special peddler's permit as defined herein. 
(b)  The application shall be either approved or denied within 48 hours of the date of filing the application unless the application is first submitted on a Friday or Saturday, in which case the application shall be approved or denied by 5:00 p.m. the Monday next following. In determining whether or not to grant the application and issue a permit, the chief of police shall conduct such reasonable investigation as he/she deems necessary to assure the protection of the public including, but not limited to, inquiry of the director of standards of the commonwealth executive office of consumer affairs, inquiring of the city collector as to whether or not the applicant owes a debt to the city, and inquiry of appropriate public officials as to the record of the applicant for violations of the criminal law. 
    The chief of police may deny the application and refuse to issue the permit for any of the reasons enumerated in section 9-80. Such denial shall be in writing, shall set forth the reason or reasons for the denial, shall refer to the appeal rights of the applicant as contained in sections 9-80 and 9-81 and shall be delivered to the applicant in person, or by mailing in the U.S. Mail, first class, postage prepaid, addressed to the applicant at the address as set forth on the applicant's application, or by any other means reasonably designed to assure delivery of the denial to the applicant. 
    Should the chief of police grant the application and issue the permit, the chief of police shall endorse on the application his approval, execute the permit and deliver it to the applicant in person or by mailing in the U.S. Mail, first class, postage prepaid, addressed to the applicant at the address as set forth on the applicant's application. 
(c)  Each noncommercial solicitor shall file registration with the chief of police of the city prior to engaging in any activity regulated under this article. The registrant shall: 
(1)  Present personal photographic identification such as a driver's license. 
(2)  Present proof of registration with the division of public charities of the attorney general of the commonwealth, if any. 
(3)  Complete and sign a written registration form provided by the city stating: 
a.  The individual's name, residence address and telephone number. 
b.  The name and address, if any, of the organization or individual on whose behalf he/she is soliciting with the name and telephone number of a contact person, other than him/herself, for such organization or individual. 
c.  The names of all individuals to participate in the solicitation. 
d.  The dates during which the solicitation will be conducted within the city. 
e.  A description of any motor vehicles to be used in the course of the solicitation. 
f.  A statement that the solicitation is being engaged in for charitable, religious or public purposes and not for the personal financial gain of any individual. 
g.  A sample of such identifying badge or other emblem as those engaged in the solicitation shall use so as to identify themselves as a person soliciting on behalf of the registered organization or individual. 
h.  The requirements of subsections (c)(3)c. and e. above may be waived by the chief of police if submission of this information constitutes a hardship to the applicant which will interfere with the applicant's proposed noncommercial solicitation. 
(d)  Upon filing the required registration form, the organization or individual thus registered as noncommercial solicitor shall be entitled to engage in the activity in question without payment of any fee except as may be otherwise required below. The chief of police shall, nonetheless, be entitled to inquire of the division of public charities of the attorney general of the commonwealth as to whether the individual or organization is duly registered therewith and, whether or not he/she or it is so registered, to investigate the character and reputation of the individual or organization by such further investigation as he deems necessary. 
    Should the investigation result in a determination by the chief of police that the registrant has violated any criminal law, has been found liable for or enjoined from any violation of any state statute intended to protect the public from unfair or deceptive trade practices or has otherwise failed to follow the requirements of this or any similar law, ordinance or regulation, the chief of police may issue an order to the registrant to cease and desist from further activities within the city. 
    A failure to cease and desist after notification shall be unlawful. A registrant subject to a cease and desist order may challenge it through the process set forth at section 9-81 but must cease and desist from further solicitation pending the conclusion of that process. In the event that the individual or organization seeking to register as a noncommercial solicitor fails to have the identifying badges or emblems referred to at section 9-73(c)(3)g. above, the chief of police shall issue to the registrant a sufficient number of "verification of registration" forms as shall be necessary to give each individual soliciting in conjunction with the registrant one copy. The chief of police may charge a fee, not in excess of $1.00 per form, to defer the cost of providing such form. Such forms shall be provided to the registrant, as required, upon completion of the registration process. 
(Ord. No. 1110,  A, 6-3-93) 
Sec. 9-75. - Duration of permits and registration. 
(a)  Transient merchant, peddler, solicitor permits. Permits granted hereunder shall be valid in the calendar year in which they are issued. Should an individual desire to renew a permit as granted for any subsequent calendar year, the applicant must file a new application pursuant to this article. 
(b)  Special transient merchant permit. Permits granted hereunder shall be valid for the time period as stated therein and no other. 
(c)  Special peddlers' permit. Permits granted hereunder shall be valid in the calendar year in which they are issued. Should an individual desire to renew a permit as granted hereunder for any subsequent calendar year, the applicant must file a new application pursuant to this article. 
(d)  Noncommercial solicitor registration. Registration shall be valid for the period of time set forth in the registrant's registration form, not to exceed 30 days. Each noncommercial solicitor shall separately register for each period of time subsequent to the date of expiration of any prior registration. 
(e)  Expired permit, registration. It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct activity as regulated by this article with an expired permit or pursuant to an expired registration. 
(Ord. No. 1110,  A, 6-3-93) 
Sec. 9-76. - Records. 
    The chief of police shall file any record of fingerprints of permittees, together with a permit number, and shall keep a record of all such permits and of complaints and convictions for violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1110,  A, 6-3-93) 
Sec. 9-77. - Food vendors. 
    The chief of police shall refer all food vendors to the board of health for a mobile food service license. 
(Ord. No. 1110,  A, 6-3-93) 
Sec. 9-78. - Exhibiting permit or registration. 
(a)  Transient merchant. The original of the permit as issued shall be posted in a conspicuous location, accessible to the general public, at his/her place of business. This requirement applies to those granted a special transient merchant permit. 
(b)  Peddler and solicitor. Each person to whom such permit is granted shall carry on his/her person at all times while engaged in the activity regulated under this article the original of the permit as issued to be displayed to any person upon request. Each individual acting as employee or agent for the person to whom such permit is granted shall carry on his/her person at all times while engaged in the activity regulated under this article a photostatic copy of the permit as issued to be displayed to any person upon request. This requirement applies to those granted a special peddlers' permit. 
(c)  Noncommercial solicitor. Each person engaged in this activity as regulated by this article shall either (a) display upon his/her person a facsimile of the badge or emblem as provided to the chief of police at time of registration at all times while engaged in the activity regulated under this article; or (b) carry on his/her person at all times while engaged in the activity regulated under this article an original verification of registration form as provided by the chief of police at the time of registration, such form to be displayed to any person upon request. 
(Ord. No. 1110,  A, 6-3-93) 
Sec. 9-79. - Permits nontransferable. 
    A permit issued pursuant to section 9-74 may not be transferred or assigned to any other person, or used by any party other than the person to whom it has been issued except as otherwise provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 1110,  A, 6-3-93) 
Sec. 9-80. - Permits revocable for just cause. 
(a)  Any permit issued pursuant to this article may be revoked for just cause. Just cause shall include police or court record of violation of this or similar ordinances, laws or regulations or for violation of any Sunday and holiday business restriction ordinances or laws, or for violation of any trespass, or unfair or deceptive business practices, ordinances, laws or regulations. 
(b)  The permits issued pursuant to this article may be revoked by the chief of police of the city, after notice and opportunity for hearing for any cause set forth in section 9-81(a) or for the following causes: 
(1)  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for license; 
(2)  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement made in connection with the selling of goods, wares or services; 
(3)  Any violation of this article; 
(4)  Conviction of the licensee of any felony or of a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; or 
(5)  Conducting the business licensed under this article in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public. 
(c)  Notice of hearing for revocation of a license shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of revocation and the time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the permittee, at the address set forth on his/her application at least five days prior to the date set for the hearing or may be hand-delivered to the permittee at least 48 hours prior to the date set for hearing. Failure to attend the hearing shall constitute a waiver thereof and of appeal rights set forth in section 9-81. The hearing shall be informal in nature and strict rules of evidence shall not apply. The permittee shall be entitled to be represented by an attorney and to present such relevant evidence as the chief of police allows. Cross examination of witnesses shall be allowed only as permitted by the chief of police, and no official record of the proceedings shall be maintained. Any party thereto may audiotape the same, provided that a duplicate recording is provided, at the expense of the party recording same, to the chief of police. The chief of police shall announce his decision at the conclusion of the hearing, which decision shall take effect immediately. A written decision shall be provided by the chief of police within seven days thereafter to be mailed, postage prepaid, to the permittee at the address as set forth on the permittee's application or such other address as shall be designated by the permittee at the time of the hearing. 
(d)  The procedure as set forth in subsection (c) shall also apply to decisions by the chief of police to refuse to issue a permit after application therefor. In such instances, the chief of police shall conduct the hearing within 14 days of his receipt of a written request by the applicant for a hearing, such written request to be filed with the chief of police no later than 14 days after the date of issuance of denial of the application in question. 
(e)  No aggrieved person otherwise entitled to invoke the appeal rights as contained in section 9-81 shall be entitled to do so without first exhausting his/her right to a hearing before the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 1110,  A, 6-3-93) 
Sec. 9-81. - Appeal rights. 
    A person aggrieved by (a) a final action of the chief of police to deny an application for any permit required under the terms of this article; or (b) final action of the chief of police to revoke any permit granted under the terms of this article; or (c) the issuance by the chief of police of a cease and desist order shall have the right to appeal to the city council of the city. Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the city clerk a written notice of appeal within 14 days of the date of issuance by the chief of police of the written decision or order appealed from. The notice of appeal shall set forth the date of the decision or order appealed, the name, address and telephone number of the aggrieved party, a statement setting forth the grounds for appeal and shall be signed by the aggrieved party. 
    The city council shall hear the appeal within 35 days of the date of filing of the notice of appeal and shall notify the aggrieved party of the date and time for hearing by notice of date, time and location of hearing mailed, postage prepaid, to the address set forth on the notice of appeal at least five days prior to the date of hearing. At such hearing the chief of police or his/her designee shall set forth his/her position on the matter, presenting such evidence as the city council president shall deem relevant. The aggrieved party shall be entitled to speak on his/her own behalf and shall be entitled to be represented by an attorney and present such evidence, including witnesses, as the city council president shall deem relevant. The hearing shall be nonadversarial in nature, strict rules of evidence shall not apply and matters of procedure and the conduct of the hearing not otherwise addressed herein shall be reserved for the determination of the city council president whose rulings and decisions thereon shall be final. 
    At the conclusion of the evidence, the city council shall by majority vote of those present and voting vote to affirm or reverse the decision of the chief of police. The decision of the council shall be based upon a substantial evidence. The requirements and exceptions of M.G.L.A. c. 39,  23A-23C (Open Meeting Law) shall apply to these proceedings. The vote of the city council shall be final, with a written decision to be prepared by the city council president with delivery to the chief of police and to the aggrieved party by mailing, postage prepaid, or by such other means as is reasonably designed to assure delivery thereof, within a reasonable period of time. The minutes of the city council proceeding, together with any documentary or other physical evidence as submitted, shall constitute the record and shall be maintained by the city clerk. 
    The city council president may call upon the city law department for its counsel throughout the proceedings including its assistance in the preparation of the written decision. Failure of the aggrieved party to attend the hearing shall constitute a waiver of appeal rights, and the appeal shall be summarily dismissed by the city council president with the action of the chief of police thereby affirmed without further action by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1110,  A, 6-3-93) 
Sec. 9-82. - Inapplicable to tag sales and garden stands. 
    Section 9-74 shall not be construed so as to require the obtaining of a permit by residents of the city who apply for and receive a tag sale license pursuant to section 9-14 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1110,  A, 6-3-93) 
Sec. 9-83. - Exemptions. 
(a)  This article shall not apply to any of the following: 
(1)  Any person, whether principal or as employee or agent therefor, who engages in temporary or transient business in the city upon whose stock in trade the city has assessed taxes in the current calendar year. 
(2)  Any person who would otherwise be regulated as a peddler by the terms of this article who has a fixed, nontemporary place of business within the commonwealth, who regularly delivers goods, services or wares to customers within the city and who does not customarily solicit direct sales from place to place within the city. 
(3)  Any person who would otherwise be regulated as a transient merchant or peddler who engages in the sale of: 
a.  Fish obtained by his/her own labor or the labor of his/her immediate family. 
b.  Fruits, vegetables, flowers, flowering plants and other farm products raised or produced through his/her own labor or the labor of his/her immediate family. 
c.  Wild or uncultivated flowers, flowering plants, fruits, nuts and berries which are collected by virtue of his/her own labor or the labor of his/her immediate family. 
d.  Dairy products, other than the sale of frozen desserts, who has a valid license pursuant to M.G.L.A. c. 94,  40. 
(b)  No person whose activities are otherwise regulated by the terms of this article shall be relieved or exempted from the provisions and requirements of this article by reason of associating him/herself temporarily with any dealer, trader or merchant who maintains a nontemporary place of business within the city or by conducting temporary or transient business in connection with, as part of the business of, or in the name of any local dealer, trader or merchant. 
(c)  It shall be the responsibility of any person whose activities appear to the chief of police of the city to be regulated hereunder to provide, upon reasonable request, such material as the chief of police deems sufficient, to establish an exemption from the terms of this article. Failure to produce such information may result in a finding by the chief of police that the activity is subject to the requirements of this article. A continued exercise of activity that the chief of police has determined to be regulated hereunder by such person, after notice and without obtaining the necessary permit, shall be unlawful. 
(Ord. No. 1110,  A, 6-3-93) 
Sec. 9-84. - Reporting of changes. 
    Should any information as originally filed on the applicant's initial application change during the term of the permit, the person to whom a permit has been issued shall, as soon as practicable, report the change in writing to the chief of police who shall note the change in his records. A reported change which would not have affected the decision of the chief of police to issue the permit shall be deemed immaterial and shall not serve as the basis for revocation of the permit. Certain changes may be deemed material and require new application. 
    A change in the physical location where a transient merchant has been permitted to do business shall always be deemed material. The chief of police shall waive the requirement of filing a new application for a transient merchant who seeks to change physical locations provided: 
(1)  Written proof of permission to use real property is submitted in accordance with the requirements of this article; and 
(2)  There are, otherwise, no violations of this article. 
    The failure of a transient merchant to promptly report to the chief of police a change in physical location shall be grounds for revocation of his/her permit. 
(Ord. No. 1110,  A, 6-3-93) 
Sec. 9-85. - Penalties for violation. 
    Each and every separate violation of this article shall be punished by a fine of $100.00. Each day of continuing violation of this article shall be considered a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 1110,  A, 6-3-93) 
State Law reference- License required for hawker, peddler, M.G.L.A. c. 101,  17. 
Sec. 9-86. - Relationship to other laws. 
    This article is adopted pursuant to the police power of the city to protect the public health and welfare, its powers under its Charter and the Massachusetts General Laws and its home rule powers pursuant to the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, Amendment Article 89 as implemented at M.G.L.A. c. 43B,  13. Grant of a permit hereunder shall not be deemed a waiver of or license to violate any law, regulation or ordinance including, without limitation, city zoning and subdivision ordinances and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1110,  A, 6-3-93) 
Secs. 9-87-9-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - JUNK, JUNK DEALERS AND JUNK COLLECTORS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Junk collector defined, M.G.L.A. c. 140,  56; authority of city to license and regulate junk dealers and collectors, M.G.L.A. c. 140,  54; licensing of junk dealers and collectors, M.G.L.A. c. 140,  202 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 9-101. - Definitions. 
    When used in this article, the terms defined in this section shall be construed as defined in this section unless the context requires a different meaning. 
    Junk collector means every person who collects, by purchase or otherwise, junk, old metal or secondhand articles, barrels, boxes, bags and other receptacles from place to place within the corporate limits of the city, whether or not such person resides or has a principal or usual place of business therein. 
    Junk dealer means every person who keeps a shop within the corporate limits of the city for the purchase, barter or sale of junk, old metals or secondhand articles. 
(Code 1971,  8-125) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally,  1-2. 
State Law reference- Junk collector defined, M.G.L.A. c. 140,  56. 
Sec. 9-102. - Separate licenses required; granting separate licenses to same person. 
    A license to be a junk dealer shall not authorize the licensee to be a junk collector, nor shall a license to be a junk collector authorize the licensee to be a junk dealer, but the city council may grant separate licenses to the same person to be both dealer and collector on payment of the required fee for each license. 
(Code 1971,  8-126) 
Sec. 9-103. - Hours of operation. 
    No junk dealer nor junk collector shall purchase any junk, old metal or secondhand articles between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m., and no such shop shall be kept open for such purpose during such hours. 
(Code 1971,  8-127) 
Sec. 9-104. - Purchases from minors prohibited. 
    No junk dealer nor junk collector shall directly or indirectly either purchase or receive by way of barter or exchange any junk, old metal or secondhand articles from a minor knowing or having reason to believe any person to be such. 
(Code 1971,  8-128) 
Sec. 9-105. - Provisions of General Laws and this article to be printed on license. 
    Every license to be a junk dealer or a junk collector shall have printed thereon the provisions of M.G.L.A. c. 140,  54, 55 and 56 and the provisions of this article relative to junk dealers and junk collectors, and such license shall state that it is granted upon the condition that the licensee conforms to the rules, regulations and restrictions contained in such statutes and provisions. 
(Code 1971,  8-129) 
Sec. 9-106. - Premises to be kept in clean and orderly condition; disposal of articles. 
    Every junk dealer and junk collector shall, at all times, keep the premises used by him in his business in a clean and orderly condition, and the articles thereon shall be so disposed of as not to constitute a nuisance, or to be offensive to persons owning or occupying adjoining real estate, or to endanger property on such real estate by fire. 
(Code 1971,  8-130) 
Sec. 9-107. - Storage of rags, wastepaper and inflammable articles. 
    Rags, wastepaper and inflammable articles collected by a junk dealer or junk collector shall not be kept or stored within the corporate limits of the city except in a substantial brick, stone, cement or fireproof building. 
(Code 1971,  8-131) 
Sec. 9-108. - Examination of shop or premises. 
    Every junk dealer and junk collector shall, at all times, allow his shop or premises to be examined by the mayor or any member of the city council, or by any person authorized by the mayor or the city council to make such examination or any regular member of the police department. 
(Code 1971,  8-132) 
Sec. 9-109. - Revocation of licenses. 
    Any license granted under this article may be revoked by the city council at its pleasure. 
(Code 1971,  8-133) 
State Law reference- Licensing, M.G.L.A. c. 140,  202 et seq. 
Secs. 9-110-9-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - JUNK DEALERS 

Sec. 9-131. - Subject to provisions of article. 
    Every junk dealer shall be subject to the provisions of article I of this chapter relative to junk dealers and junk collectors. 
(Code 1971,  8-139) 
Sec. 9-132. - Council may license. 
    The city council may license persons whom they deem suitable to be junk dealers. 
(Code 1971,  8-140) 
Sec. 9-133. - Record book-To be kept. 
    Every junk dealer shall keep a book in which shall be written the time of every purchase of any junk, old metal or secondhand articles, and there shall be inscribed therein the name, age and residence of the person from whom and the date and hour when such purchase was made. 
(Code 1971,  8-141) 
Sec. 9-134. - Same-Inspection. 
    Every book kept pursuant to section 9-133 shall be at all times open to the inspection of the mayor, or any councilman, or the chief of police or any police officer of the city, or in any particular instance, such book shall be open to the inspection of any person duly authorized by the city council by order or resolution, or authorized by the mayor in writing. 
(Code 1971,  8-142) 
Sec. 9-135. - Examination of shop, premises and merchandise. 
    Every junk dealer shall permit his shop and premises and all articles of merchandise therein to be examined at all times by any person specified in section 9-142. 
(Code 1971,  8-143) 
Sec. 9-136. - Name and occupation to be displayed on sign. 
    Every junk dealer shall put in a suitable and conspicuous place on his shop over the main entrance a sign having his name and occupation legibly inscribed thereon in letters not less than six inches in height. 
(Code 1971,  8-144) 
Sec. 9-137. - Articles not to be sold for 30 days. 
    No articles purchased or received by any junk dealer shall be sold until at least 30 days from the date of its purchase or receipt shall have elapsed. 
(Code 1971,  8-145) 
Secs. 9-138-9-160. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - JUNK COLLECTORS 

Sec. 9-161. - Persons subject to chapter. 
    Every person who is a "junk collector" as defined in this article shall be subject to article I relative to "junk dealers and collectors." 
(Code 1971,  8-151) 
Sec. 9-162. - Council may license. 
    The city council may license persons whom they deem suitable to be junk collectors. 
(Code 1971,  8-152) 
Sec. 9-163. - Articles not to be sold for 14 days. 
    No person licensed as a junk collector shall sell any junk, old metals or secondhand articles until 14 days from the date of their purchase or receipt shall have elapsed. 
(Code 1971,  8-153) 
Sec. 9-164. - Name and license number to appear on vehicles. 
    Every junk collector shall have, on the side of every vehicle used by him in the collection of junk, old metals or secondhand articles, when engaged in collecting, transporting or dealing in such articles, his name and the words "Junk Collector, City of Westfield, License No. _____," with the number of the license of such collector. All such shall be in letters painted thereon not less than 11/2 inches in height. 
(Code 1971,  8-154) 
Sec. 9-165. - Badges required; information to be shown. 
    Every junk collector shall wear in plain sight on the front of his outside coat a badge which shall be of metal, circular in shape, not less than two inches in diameter, which shall have plainly inscribed thereon the words "Junk Collector, City of Westfield, License No. _____," with the number of the wearer's junk collector license. 
(Code 1971,  8-155) 
Sec. 9-166. - Badge to be furnished by chief of police; cost. 
    The chief of police shall have badges made of the kind described in section 9-165 and shall furnish the same to junk collectors at cost. 
(Code 1971,  8-156) 
Secs. 9-167-9-185. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - OPERATION OF BOWLING ALLEYS ON SUNDAY[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- License to operate bowling alley on Sunday, M.G.L.A. c. 136. 

Sec. 9-186. - License required. 
    No person shall operate a bowling alley on Sunday without first obtaining a license therefor from the city council. The issuance of such license shall be approved by the mayor. 
(Code 1971,  8-90) 
Sec. 9-187. - Granted only to those operating alleys on secular days. 
    Licenses to operate bowling alleys on Sunday may only be granted to persons licensed to operate bowling alleys on secular days. 
(Code 1971,  8-91) 
Sec. 9-188. - Hours effective; operation not allowed on Easter or Christmas if on Sunday. 
    Licenses granted pursuant to this article shall be effective between the hours of 1:00 p.m. and 11:00 p.m. No such license shall authorize the operation of bowling alleys on Easter or on Christmas Day if such day falls on Sunday. 
(Code 1971,  8-92) 
Sec. 9-189. - License fee. 
    The fee for licenses granted under this article shall be set from time to time by the council, and a schedule of such fees is on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1971,  8-93) 
Sec. 9-190. - Revocation. 
    The licensing authorities may at any time and without previous notice revoke licenses granted under this article if they have reason to believe that any provision of this article is being violated. 
(Code 1971,  8-94) 
Secs. 9-191-9-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PAWNBROKERS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- For authority of city, M.G.L.A. c. 140,  78. 

Sec. 9-211. - Application of article. 
    This article shall apply only when the property mentioned in section 9-213 is deposited with the party making the loan. Nothing contained in this article shall apply to loans made upon stocks, bonds, notes or other written or printed evidences of ownership of property, or of indebtedness to the holder or owner of any such securities. 
(Code 1971,  8-105) 
Sec. 9-212. - Rules and regulations. 
    The city council shall, from time to time, establish such rules and regulations as it shall see fit with reference to the business carried on by pawnbrokers. 
(Code 1971,  8-106) 
Sec. 9-213. - License required. 
    No person shall, in the city, engage in or carry on the business of loaning money upon mortgages, deposits or pledges of wearing apparel, jewelry, ornaments, household goods or other personal property, or of purchasing such property on condition of selling the same back again at a stipulated price, unless such person is licensed as a pawnbroker by the city council. 
(Code 1971,  8-107) 
Sec. 9-214. - License fee. 
    The fee for a pawnbroker's license shall be in such amount as is set forth in section 9-11 of this Code. 
(Code 1971,  8-108) 
State Law reference- License fee, M.G.L.A. c. 140,  77. 
Sec. 9-215. - Bond. 
    At the time any pawnbroker receives a license to conduct a pawnbroker's business pursuant to this Code, he shall file with the city a bond in the sum of $300.00, written in favor of such city, with two sureties approved by the city, and conditioned for the faithful performance of the duties and obligations pertaining to such business. 
(Code 1971,  8-109) 
State Law reference- Pawnbroker's bond, M.G.L.A. c. 140,  77. 
Sec. 9-216. - Provisions of article and rules and regulations incorporated into licenses. 
    The provisions of this article and the rules and regulations established under section 9-212 shall be incorporated into every license granted under the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1971,  8-110) 
Sec. 9-217. - Records to be kept; inspection. 
    Every pawnbroker shall keep a book in which shall be legibly written in the English language, at the time of making a loan, an account and description of the goods, articles or thing pawned or pledged, the amount of money loaned thereon, the time of pledging the same, the rate of interest to be paid on such loan and the name and residence of the person pawning or pledging such goods, articles or thing. Such book shall at all reasonable times be open to the inspection of the mayor, any member of the city council, any regular member of the police department or of any person who shall be duly authorized in writing for the purpose by the mayor and who shall exhibit such written authority to such pawnbroker. 
(Code 1971,  8-111) 
State Law reference- Right of entry of certain officers for purpose of making examination, M.G.L.A. c. 140,  73; record of pledges, etc., M.G.L.A. c. 140,  79; books open for inspection, M.G.L.A. c. 140,  81. 
Sec. 9-218. - Person pawning or pledging goods to receive memorandum; charge for same. 
    Every pawnbroker shall, at the time of making any loan, deliver to the person pawning or pledging any goods, articles or thing, a memorandum or note signed by him, containing the substance of the entry required to be made in his book by section 9-217 of this chapter. No charge shall be made or required by any pawnbroker for any such entry, memorandum or note. 
(Code 1971,  8-112) 
Sec. 9-219. - Establishing interest rate; compliance with rate. 
(a)  The city council shall establish the rate of interest to be charged by pawnbrokers. No pawnbroker shall charge or receive upon any loan a greater rate that that fixed by city council. 
(b)  No pawnbroker in the city shall charge interest on loaned monies, as a result of a pawning agreement or otherwise, in excess of 18 percent per annum. All loan or pawning agreements shall be in writing and shall clearly state the annual percentage rate. No pawnbroker shall charge or receive any greater rate of interest and interest shall be determined on the precise sum advanced by the lender. 
(Code 1971,  8-113; Ord. No. 1377, 4-15-04) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to limit rate of interest, M.G.L.A. c. 140,  72, 78. 
Sec. 9-220. - Receipt of articles from minors. 
    No pawnbroker shall, directly or indirectly, receive any article in pawn from a minor. 
(Code 1971,  8-114) 
Secs. 9-221-9-240. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - POOL TABLES, SHOOTING GALLERIES, BOWLING ALLEYS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Billiard tables and bowling alleys, M.G.L.A. c. 140,  177. 

Sec. 9-241. - License required. 
    No person shall operate or maintain any billiard, pool or sippio room or table, shooting gallery or bowling alley without first obtaining a license therefor from the city council. 
(Code 1971,  8-76) 
Sec. 9-242. - Inspection of licensed premises; report. 
    The chief of police shall inspect all premises for which licenses have been issued for the keeping of billiard, pool or sippio tables, shooting galleries or bowling alleys, and shall report on the findings of such visits to the city council at the meeting following such visits. Such visits shall be made not less than twice in one year. 
(Code 1971,  8-77) 
Sec. 9-243. - Copy of article to be posted in licensed premises. 
    A copy of this article shall be given to each owner, keeper or manager of a billiard, pool or sippio room or table, shooting gallery or bowling alley, and such copy shall be placed in a conspicuous place in the room for which the license has been granted. 
(Code 1971,  8-78) 
Sec. 9-244. - Closing hours. 
    A keeper, owner or manager of a billiard, pool or sippio room or table or shooting gallery shall close his place of business at 12:00 midnight on each secular day. A keeper, owner or manager of a bowling alley shall close his place of business at 12:00 midnight on each secular day. 
(Code 1971,  8-79) 
Secs. 9-245-9-265. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - SALE OF CERTAIN NONINTOXICATING BEVERAGES 

Sec. 9-266. - License required. 
    No person shall keep open a place of business for the retail sale of beverages derived wholly or in part from cereals or substitutes therefor, and containing less than one-half of one percent of alcohol, such as unfermented grape juice, ginger ale, root beer, sarsaparilla, pop, artificial mineral waters, carbonated waters or beverages, and other so-called soft drinks, until a license therefor has been obtained from the board of license commissioners. 
(Code 1971,  8-33) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, M.G.L.A. c. 140,  21A. 
Sec. 9-267. - Persons, premises exempt. 
    The license required by section 9-266 for the retail sale of carbonated beverages shall not be required of the following: 
(1)  Innholders. 
(2)  Common victualers. 
(3)  Druggists. 
(4)  Dealers whose principal business is the sale of groceries and meats or either of such products. 
(5)  Premises where such beverages, when sold, are to be consumed off such premises. 
(Code 1971,  8-34) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, M.G.L.A. c. 140,  21C, 21D. 
Sec. 9-268. - Fee. 
    No fee shall be charged for the license required by the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1971,  8-35) 
Sec. 9-269. - Location of licensed premises. 
    Licenses granted under the provisions of this article shall specify the street or place and the number, if there be any, of the licensed premises, and if there is no number, then the location of the place of business in which the license is to be exercised. The license shall not be valid in any other place. 
(Code 1971,  8-36) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, M.G.L.A. c. 140,  21B. 
Sec. 9-270. - Revocation; suspension of license. 
    Any license issued pursuant to the provisions of this article may be suspended or revoked at any time after a hearing by the board of license commissioners. 
(Code 1971,  8-37) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, M.G.L.A. c. 140,  21B. 
Secs. 9-271-9-290. - Reserved.

Sec. 9-331. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of conveying or transporting wood, coal, lumber, stone, brick, sand, gravel, dirt, goods, wares, furniture, merchandise, building materials or any article or thing whatsoever, for hire, within the city, without a license therefor from the city council.

Sec. 9-334. - Record of licenses.

Sec. 9-335. - License plates; attachment; information thereon. 
    Every vehicle used in a business regulated by this division shall have placed on the outside thereof, in a conspicuous place on each side, the license plate required by this division. Such plate shall be furnished at cost by the city clerk, and shall bear the name of the city, the license number and the date of expiration of the license. 
(Code 1971,  8-64) 
Sec. 9-336. - Transferability. 
    No license issued pursuant to this division shall be transferable. 
(Code 1971,  8-65)

Sec. 9-461. - Number of licenses outstanding.
