ARTICLE XII. - AUTOMATIC AMUSEMENT DEVICES[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1371, adopted March 18, 2004, set out provisions intended for use as Art. I,  9-19-9-22, of this chapter. For purposes of classification and for ease of indexing, these provisions have been included as Art. XI,  9-491-9-494, of this chapter at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 9-491. - Regulated, purpose and authority. 
(a)  By virtue of M.G.L.A. c. 140,  177A, the license commission may grant a license to operate an automatic amusement device, as defined therein, for hire, gain or reward, and, after written notice to a licensee, may suspend or revoke such a license. It is the purpose and intent of this article to prohibit the license commission from issuing a license for any automatic device that is intended to be used as a gaming device or which, although meeting the definition of an automatic amusement device, may reasonably be considered to present a risk of misuse as a gaming device. 
(b)  This article is adopted in accordance with the authority granted, inter alia, by Amendment Article 89 to Article II of the Massachusetts Constitution, Chapter 294 of the Acts of Massachusetts 1920, as amended, and the powers granted, and reserved, to cities in the Massachusetts General Laws. 
(Ord. No. 1371,  9-19, 3-18-04) 
Sec. 9-492. - Annual license required. 
(a)  In accordance with M.G.L.A. c. 140,  177A, as amended from time to time, hereafter, any individual or business desiring to keep and operate an automatic amusement device for hire, gain or reward shall secure an annual license from the license commission which shall design a license application to be completed by the applicant for each device and each location where such device is to be kept and operated. The fee for each device licensed pursuant to this article shall be $100.00. 
(b)  The license commission shall not grant a license for any device that is intended for use as a gaming device nor for any automatic amusement device which may reasonably be considered to present a risk of misuse as a gaming device. Automatic amusement devices which may reasonably be considered to present a risk of misuse as gaming devices are those devices which simulate actual gaming devices, including so-called "video poker" and games which involve matching forms, shapes or random number combinations. 
(Ord. No. 1371,  9-20, 3-18-04) 
Sec. 9-493. - Restrictions, conditions. 
(a)  The maximum number of automatic amusement devices allowed on any single business premises shall be four unless the license commission, after a duly noticed public hearing, has issued its written authorization for a greater number of such devices. 
(b)  No automatic amusement device shall be licensed which is designed to accept currency of a value greater than a U.S. $1.00 bill. 
(c)  Automatic amusement devices shall be so installed on the premises described in the license as to be in open view at all times while in operation, and shall at all times be available for inspection. Unlicensed automatic amusement devices are prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 1371,  9-21, 3-18-04) 
Sec. 9-494. - Enforcement, penalty. 
(a)  The Westfield Police Department shall serve as agent to the license commission for the enforcement of this article. 
(b)  All licenses for automatic amusement devices granted by the license commission shall be subject to inspection by the Westfield Police Department to ensure conformance with submitted application information and the requirements of this article and M.G.L.A. c. 140,  177A. 
(c)  Any unlicensed automatic amusement device or any licensed automatic amusement device used in violation of this ordinance or of M.G.L.A. c. 140,  177A shall be subject to immediate seizure by the Westfield Police Department. In the event of such seizure, the police department shall promptly provide a written report to the license commission. Upon receipt of the report, the license commission shall schedule a hearing at its next following regular meeting to which the owner, if known, of the automatic amusement device and the licensee at whose premises said device was seized, shall be summoned to appear. Failure to appear after receipt of notice shall be deemed a waiver of the right to challenge the seizure of the automatic amusement device. 
(d)  A violation of this article or M.G.L.A. c. 140,  177A shall be ground for revocation of any license issued by the City of Westfield and held by the violator, including a license to sell alcoholic beverages and may otherwise be punished as allowed by law. 
(Ord. No. 1371,  9-22, 3-18-04) 
ARTICLE XIII. - MOBILE FOOD VENDORS 

Sec. 9-495. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Board . City of Westfield Board of Health. 
    Mobile food vendor . Any mobile operation that stores, prepares, packages, serves, sells or otherwise provides for human consumption any prepared or packaged food or beverages from a truck or a cart. This definition does not include "ice cream truck" as defined and permitted under M.G.L.A. c. 270,  25. 
(Ord. No. 1630 , 5-21-15) 
Sec. 9-496. - Mobile food vendor license required. 
(a)  No person or business entity shall operate as a mobile food vendor in any public, private or restricted space without obtaining a license from the board. Said license shall be conspicuously posted in a place that is visible to all customers. 
(b)  The applicant must complete an application form and pay an application fee of $60.00 in the business license office. All applicants will need a state hawker/peddler license and a City of Westfield hawker/peddler license. 
(c)  In the event either the state hawker/peddler license or the City of Westfield hawker/peddler license is revoked, the mobile food vendor license shall automatically become void. Failure to notify the board within ten days that such license has been revoked shall constitute a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1630 , 5-21-15) 
Sec. 9-497. - Renewal. 
    Every mobile food vendor license may be renewed annually upon payment of the fee, provided that the mobile food licensee is in compliance with the applicable requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1630 , 5-21-15) 
Sec. 9-498. - Conditions of operation. 
(a)  Unless otherwise specified, no mobile food vendor may operate between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. on any public property. 
(b)  Mobile food vendors shall not be allowed to remain in one location for more than eight hours on any given calendar day. 
(c)  The mobile food licensee shall comply with all applicable rules, regulations and ordinances, including but not limited to the board of health regulations, traffic and parking regulations and the noise ordinance. 
(d)  Mobile food vendor licenses are not transferable. 
(e)  Permitting of mobile food vendors does not supersede approvals required for special events on public property or within the public right of way. 
(Ord. No. 1630 , 5-21-15) 
Sec. 9-499. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Any mobile food vendor operating in violation of any provision within this section or any other rules and regulations promulgated by the board may be subject to a fine of $100.00 per day, enforced by noncriminal disposition under M.G.L.A. c. 40,  21D. The board or their designee, the police department, fire department or superintendent of buildings may enforce any provision of this article. Each day of violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  The board may revoke, suspend or modify a mobile food vendor license after reasonable notice to the licensee of the grounds for the proposed revocations, suspension or modification and the time and place of the hearing regarding such proposed action. 
(Ord. No. 1630 , 5-21-15) 
Secs. 9-500-9-519. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - OUTDOOR DINING[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1686, adopted Sept. 6, 2018, enacted provisions designated as  9-500-9-9-503, however to conform to the style of the code, said provisions have been redesignated as  9-520-9-523 at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 9-520. - Purpose. 
(a)  To provide for the licensing of outdoor dining areas of appropriate design and configuration that will be an amenity to the city during the spring, summer and fall. 
(b)  The health department shall impose such conditions on each permit as deemed in the best interest of the city and may enact further regulations to carry out the purpose of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1686, 9-6-18) 
Sec. 9-521. - Permit required, fee and conditions. 
(a)  No person or entity shall cause to be placed within the public ways (sidewalks) any furniture without applying for and receiving an outdoor dining permit. Permits shall be issued by the health department for the period of April 1 through October 31 and must be reapplied for annually. The permit application will be sent out with all food service applications or renewals and shall include a description and diagram of the sidewalk area where the service will be provided, the number and type of tables, chairs, umbrellas or other appurtenances. 
(b)  Insurance. The applicant shall furnish a certificate of insurance providing commercial insurance coverage in sin the amount not less than $1,000,000.00 per occurrence for bodily injury, death, disability and property damage liability. The city shall be named as an additional insured on a primary, noncontributory basis for any liability arising directly or indirectly from the operation of the outdoor dining permit. In the event the insurance is cancelled, the permit holder has 24 hours to reinstate the insurance or the permit shall be revoked. The permit holder shall immediately inform the city if the insurance is revoked and shall not use the permit until insurance is restated in accordance with this chapter. 
(c)  Indemnity and hold harmless agreement. The applicant shall sign an indemnification and hold harmless agreement which shall be submitted with the application. 
(Ord. No. 1686, 9-6-18) 
Sec. 9-522. - Prohibitions, requirements and standards. 
(a)  The location of the outdoor dining area shall be appurtenant to and contiguous with a licensed restaurant facility located on street level and may not extend beyond the frontage and/or side faces of the licensed premises. The area must be enclosed by a fence, rope or other means to prevent access from the public right of way. 
(b)  There shall be a minimum of four feet of free, unimpeded pedestrian passageway on the sidewalk. Tables, chairs, benches, food equipment, etc. shall be located so as not to obstruct the four feet of passageway. The city reserves the right to require more than four feet of sidewalk be made available during certain hours of the day or days of the week or for specific events. At all times, the permit holder must be compliant with all applicable federal, state and local laws and regulation, including the Americans with Disabilities Act and the building and fire codes. 
(c)  No appurtenances, including but not limited to tables, chairs, umbrellas, fencing, bollards and planters, shall be affixed to public property. There will be no permanent fixtures in the public right of way. The property owner shall be responsible for any damage to public property. From the period from November 2 to March 30, all appurtenances shall be removed from the public right of way. At all times, all fixtures and appurtenances shall be removed upon 24 hours' notice by the city. 
(d)  Lighting for outdoor dining areas is subject to approval during the permitting process but in no event shall any lighting be affixed to public property. 
(e)  No appurtenances, including but not limited to tables, chairs, umbrellas, fending, bollards and planters shall be erected, installed used or maintained within five feet of any marked or unmarked crosswalk or handicapped ramp, fire land, fire hydrant, fire department connection, call box or bus stop. 
(f)  No refuse or refuse containers are allowed within the outdoor dining area. The outdoor dining area must be maintained in good order in a neat and sanitary condition. The permit holder is solely responsible for the removal of all trash from the outdoor dining area as well as sweeping of the outdoor dining area. 
(g)  There shall be no smoking in the outdoor dining area nor shall the outdoor dining area be used solely for the purpose of serving alcohol. 
(h)  The city is not required to make any improvements to the public right of way encompassing the outdoor dining area and the permit holder is accepting the premises as is. 
(i)  The outdoor dining area shall operate the same hours as the establishment to which it is attached unless it is in or within 100 feet of a residential zone, in which case the outdoor dining shall cease at 11:00 p.m. 
(j)  Permit holder is responsible for supervision of the outdoor dining area. 
(k)  Approval of an outdoor dining permit shall not be construed as an approval of any other license or an approval for the alteration or extension of premises where alcoholic beverages are served. 
(Ord. No. 1686, 9-6-18) 
Sec. 8-523. - Violation/penalty and enforcement. 
(a)  The outdoor dining permit may be revoked for failure to maintain the standards required for the initial permit. 
(b)  In the event that any provision of this article shall be deemed illegal or otherwise unenforceable by a court of competent jurisdiction, then only that specific provision shall not be enforced and all other sections and provisions shall remain in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 1686, 9-6-18) 
Chapter 10 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Abandoned refrigerators. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner or former owner of a container originally used for refrigerative purposes to fail to remove the door or doors from such container before discarding, setting aside, failing to use, keeping for sale or abandoning such container, in a place accessible to unattended children, unless such container may be easily opened from the inside. 
(Code 1971,  9-1) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, M.G.L.A. c. 271,  46. 
Sec. 10-2. - Bathing in state of nudity. 
    No person shall bathe or swim in a state of nudity in any of the waters within the city, in places exposed to the public view or in the immediate sight of the occupants of any dwelling house, shop or factory. 
(Code 1971,  9-2) 
State Law reference- Indecent exposure, M.G.L.A. c. 272,  53. 
Sec. 10-3. - Boat speed limit. 
    Except as provided in section 10-4, it shall be unlawful to operate on any public lakes, ponds, rivers or other public waters within the territorial limits of the city any boat propelled by power other than muscular power at a speed greater than 12 miles an hour. 
(Code 1971,  9-3) 
Sec. 10-4. - Boat speed races. 
    Permits for speed races of boats described in section 10-3 may, upon application therefor, be granted by the city council in its discretion with the approval of the mayor, subject to such restrictions and regulations as it may see fit to impose. 
(Code 1971,  9-4) 
Sec. 10-5. - Curfew for minors. 
    No person under the age of 15 years shall be or remain in or upon any street or public place in the city at night after the hour of 9:00 p.m., between April 1 and September 30, both inclusive, of each year, or, at night, after the hour of 8:00 p.m. October 1 and March 31, both inclusive, of each year, unless such person is actually employed in some work that makes such necessary, or is accompanied by a person properly having general care and custody of him or by a person to whom he has been particularly entrusted by someone who properly has general care or custody of him, or is engaged in the performance of some mission or duty directed by a person having his general care or custody. 
(Code 1971,  9-5) 
Sec. 10-6. - Injuring drinking fountains; depositing substances therein. 
    No person shall in any manner injure any of the drinking fountains in any street or public place in the city, or throw or place any substance in such. 
(Code 1971,  9-7) 
Sec. 10-7. - Marking, mutilating posters, etc. 
    No person shall mark or mutilate any poster, advertisement, sign or notice so as to render it profane or obscene. 
(Code 1971,  3-2) 
Sec. 10-8. - Defacing, removing, etc., notices or advertisements. 
    No person shall deface, remove or destroy any notice or advertisement posted for a lawful purpose. 
(Code 1971,  3-3) 
Cross reference- Advertising, ch. 3. 
State Law reference- Injuring legal notices, show bills, M.G.L.A. c. 266,  124, 125. 
Sec. 10-9. - Keeping, storing explosives. 
    No person shall keep in any store, shop or other building within the city, which shall be within the distance of 25 rods from any other building, more than 50 pounds of gunpowder, dynamite or other explosive compound, and no person shall keep in any store, shop or other building, within the city, within ten rods of any other building, more than 25 pounds of gunpowder, dynamite or other explosive compound. No person shall keep in any store, shop or other building within the city more than one pound of gunpowder, dynamite or other explosive compound unless the same is well secured in copper, tin or brass canisters holding not exceeding five pounds each, and which canisters are closely covered with copper, brass or tin covers. No person shall keep any gunpowder, dynamite or other explosive compound unless the same shall be well secured in tight casks or canisters. 
(Code 1971,  9-8) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 7. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to establish, by ordinance, rules for explosives, M.G.L.A. c. 148,  9. 
Sec. 10-10. - Exploding explosives in city. 
    No person in the city shall fire, detonate or otherwise explode any explosive compound or explosive, except by written permission by the chief of the fire department, or in the exercise of a duty required or justified by law, or on July 4 or other special occasions permitted by the chief of the fire department, and then only within such limits and hours as he prescribes. 
(Code 1971,  9-9) 
Sec. 10-11. - Discharging firearms. 
    No person shall, except in the performance of some duty required by law, or upon permission from the chief of the police department, discharge any air gun or gun, pistol or other firearm in or upon any street or public place, or within 100 yards thereof, or in any building, or within 100 yards of any building in the city. 
(Code 1971,  9-11) 
Sec. 10-12. - Selling firearms, ammunition to minors. 
    No person shall sell to any child under the age of 15 years any cartridge or fixed ammunition of which any explosive is a part, or any gun, pistol or other mechanical contrivance or firearm arranged for the explosion of such cartridge or ammunition, except as may be permitted by state law. 
(Code 1971,  9-12) 
State Law reference- Sale, etc., of firearms, M.G.L.A. c. 140,  121-131C. 
Sec. 10-13. - Gambling prohibited in bowling alleys, poolrooms. 
    A keeper, owner or manager of a bowling alley or poolroom shall not allow slot machines, which are games of chance, or gambling in any form on the premises. 
(Code 1971,  9-13) 
State Law reference- Gambling on premises of bowling alley, etc., M.G.L.A. c. 271,  4, M.G.L.A. c. 140,  177. 
Sec. 10-14. - Games of skill and chance; unlawful games. 
    No person shall expose any table or device for the playing of any game of chance or skill, and no person shall play at the same, or at any unlawful game, in any street or public place. 
(Code 1971,  9-14) 
State Law reference- Gaming generally, M.G.L.A. c. 137,  1-7, M.G.L.A. c. 271,  1-42. 
Sec. 10-15. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1310, adopted Feb. 7, 2002, repealed former  10-15 of the Code, which pertained noise generally and derived from the 1971 Code,  9-15. 
Sec. 10-16. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1310, adopted Feb. 7, 2002, repealed former  10-16 of the Code, which pertained merchants shouting wares and use of loudspeakers and derived from the 1971 Code,  9-17. 
Sec. 10-17. - Obstructing passage to and from public building; sitting on walls, fences. 
    No person shall be or remain upon any sidewalk, doorway, stairs, public passageway or way to any church or public hall or office, or upon any steps, portico or other projection from any house or other building, to the disturbance or obstruction of any person lawfully entitled to pass, inhabit or resort thereto, and no person shall sit or be upon any wall, fence, railing, bank or doorsteps facing upon any street or public place, not being the occupant or owner thereof, without the consent of the owner or occupant of the premises, or after being requested by the owner or any occupant of the premises, or any constable or police officer to remove therefrom. 
(Code 1971,  9-18) 
State Law reference- Unlawful assembly, M.G.L.A. c. 269,  1 et seq. 
Sec. 10-18. - Injuring or defacing poles, fences, signs, sidewalks, buildings. 
    No person shall deface, break, post signs upon, or injure in any manner any fence, post, pole, sign, electric street lamp, sidewalk, tree belt, building or structure, nor shall advertising of any nature be affixed thereto without the permission of the lawful owner thereof secured in advance. 
(Code 1971,  9-19; Ord. No. 1173, 10-9-96; Ord. No. 1299, 12-6-01) 
Sec. 10-19. - Distribution of lighters and tobacco to and possession thereof by minors. 
(a)  No person under the age of 16 may smoke or possess in public a lighted cigarette, cigar, or pipe made in whole or part of tobacco. 
(b)  No person under the age of 16 may possess a lighter. For purposes of this section, the word "lighter" means a mechanical, chemical or electrical device that a person can use to light a cigarette, cigar or pipe. 
(c)  No person may distribute to any person under the age of 16 a cigarette, cigar, pipe or lighter as defined in subsection 10-19(b). 
(Code 1971,  9-20; Ord. No. 946, 6-4-87; Ord. No. 1173, 10-9-96) 
State Law reference- Selling or giving tobacco to minors, M.G.L.A. c. 270,  6. 
Sec. 10-20. - Smoking in buses. 
    No person shall carry or smoke a lighted pipe, cigar or cigarette on a bus. However, this section shall not apply to a chartered or private bus or motor vehicle or that part of a bus where smoking is permitted by the company operating such. 
(Code 1971,  9-21) 
State Law reference- Smoking in public conveyance, M.G.L.A. c. 272,  43A. 
Sec. 10-21. - Throwing, shooting stones, snowballs, missiles; playing games in streets. 
    No person shall, without the written consent of the chief of police, on any street of the city used for purposes of business or residence, throw or shoot a stone, arrow, snowball, ice, stick, brick or other hard substance, or other missile, or be concerned in any game, exercise or amusement in any street where such act interferes with the safe and convenient use thereof, or where such act disturbs the safety of persons or property or the peace or quiet of any person. 
(Code 1971,  9-22) 
Sec. 10-22. - Spitting in public. 
    No person shall spit upon any sidewalk which is covered with any substance other than earth or ashes, or upon the floor or platform of any bus, or public conveyance or vehicle, or upon the floor, steps, stairs, passageways or hallways of any church, theater, hall or other building to which the public resorts. 
(Code 1971,  9-23) 
Cross reference- Health and environmental regulations, ch. 8. 
Sec. 10-23. - Consumption of alcoholic or malt beverages in public; open container. 
    No person shall drink or consume any alcoholic beverage or any malt beverage, or possess an open container full or partially full of any alcoholic beverage or of any malt beverage, while on, in, or upon any municipal sidewalk or any public way or other sidewalk or way to which the public has a right of access unless authorized by a lease, license agreement, outdoor dining permit or any other type of agreement duly executed by the body having care, custody and control of said parcel. Any lease, license agreement, outdoor dining permit or other agreement granted shall be subject to full compliance with all permitting as may be required by the liquor license commission. 
    The city council may, by majority vote, grant an exemption to this section for site-and date-specific civic events. Any exemption granted shall be subject to full compliance with all permitting as may be required by the liquor license commission. 
(Code 1971,  9-24; Ord. No. 1362, 11-16-03; Ord. No. 1702, 4-4-19) 
Sec. 10-24. - Possession or consumption of alcoholic or malt beverages by persons under 21 years of age. 
    No person who has not attained the age of 21 shall possess any alcoholic beverage or malt beverage, while on, in, or upon any municipal sidewalk or any public way or on any other sidewalk or way to which the public has a right of access. In addition, it shall be unlawful for a person who has not attained the age of 21 to possess or consume any alcoholic beverage or malt beverage at any place not open to the public, unless in connection with the consumption of the alcoholic beverage, the underage person is being supervised by his or her parent or legal guardian as set forth in M.G.L.A. c. 138,  34. 
(Ord. No. 1373, 4-1-04; Ord. No. 1504, 10-7-09; Ord. No. 1550, 8-18-11) 
Sec. 10-25. - Urinating in public. 
    No person shall urinate in public areas or in any area where the public has a view or access thereto. 
(Ord. No. 1372, 4-1-04) 
Sec. 10-26. - Private motor vehicle sales. 
(a)  No person shall conduct the sale of a private motor vehicle, other than a licensed motor vehicle sales agency, except as follows: 
(1)  The seller is the owner of the vehicle. 
(2)  The vehicle is shown for sale at property owned by or the legal residence of the seller. 
(3)  The seller has obtained a private motor vehicle sales permit issued by the Westfield Police Department. 
(b)  Permits authorizing the sale of private motor vehicles shall be obtained from the police department. There is no fee for the first permit issued in each calendar year and each permit is valid for a period not exceeding 21 consecutive days. A fee of $10.00 shall be charged for a second permit. A fee of $10.00 shall be charged for a third permit. The permit shall specify the vehicle identification number, the address and dates upon which the sale is permitted. No address shall receive a permit within three months of the expiration of the prior permit. No more than three permits may be issued within any 12-month period. All multifamily units may have up to two such sales per unit. All permits, once issued, shall be prominently displayed as directed by the police department. 
(c)  The city council hereby authorizes the police department to establish, from time to time, such rules and regulations as it shall see fit with reference to the procedures and permits used by the police department. 
(d)  Signs for any permitted sale shall only be placed on the windshield of the vehicle at the permitted address along with the permit authorizing the sale. The permit must be clearly visible to a passing officer. 
(e)  If the police department determines that any permitted sale has interfered with the safe flow of motor vehicle traffic, the police department may order the sale to cease and the permit is suspended until such time as the unsafe traffic condition abates. Failure to suspend a sale after being ordered to do so shall constitute a violation of this section. 
(f)  Each duly appointed city police officer is hereby empowered to enforce the provisions of this section pursuant to M.G.L.A. c. 40,  25D. Whoever violates the provisions of section 10-26 shall be penalized by noncriminal penalty of $100.00. 
(g)  The police department shall not issue a permit to any person found to be in violation of this section within the previous 12 months. 
(Ord. No. 1405, 10-5-05) 
Sec. 10-27. - Camping or sleeping in public. 
    No person shall anywhere within the city limits either camp or sleep while on public property without the express permission of the owner, agent, or lessee thereof. Any person violating the aforementioned ordinance shall be subject to a $50.00 fine for each offense. 
(Ord. No. 1593, 11-7-13) 
Sec. 10-28. - Nuisance house. 
    This section permits the City of Westfield to impose liability on owners and other responsible parties for properties that have become a nuisance by exhibiting an atmosphere of criminal and/or other disturbing activity and harm caused by loud and unruly gatherings on private property that unreasonably interfere with the common good and welfare of a specific neighborhood or the City of Westfield in general. 
(1)  Definitions . 
a.  Alcoholic beverage . All liquids intended for human consumption as a beverage which contain one half of one percent or more of alcohol by volume, including malt beverages. 
b.  Eviction . Actively trying to evict a tenant from a premises by delivery of a notice to quit and subsequent court proceedings, if a tenant fails to vacate the premises. 
c.  Gathering . A party or event where a group of persons have assembled or are assembling for a social occasion or social activity. 
d.  Premises . Any residence or other private property, place or location including any commercial or business property. 
e.  Property owner . The legal owner of record as listed by the tax assessor's records. 
f.  Public nuisance . A gathering of persons on any premises in a manner which constitutes a violation of law or creates a substantial disturbance of the quiet enjoyment of private or public property in a neighborhood. Unlawful conduct includes, but is not limited to, excessive noise, excessive pedestrian and vehicular traffic, obstruction of public streets by crowds or vehicles, illegal parking, public urination, furnishing of an alcoholic beverage to a minor, fights, disturbances of the peace, litter and allowing an unsafe number of persons at the premises and exceeding the safe capacity of the premises. 
g.  Response costs . Costs associated with the responses by law enforcement, fire and other emergency response providers to a gathering will be equivalent to a minimum of one hour's pay for any responding officer. 
(2)  Hosting, permitting or allowing a disorderly house or party, gathering, event where underage persons consuming alcoholic beverages prohibited . 
a.  It is the duty of any person having control of any premises who knowingly hosts, permits or allows a gathering at said premises to take all reasonable steps to prevent the consumption of alcoholic beverages by any underage person at the gathering. Reasonable steps include, but are not limited to, controlling access to alcoholic beverages at the gathering; controlling the quantity of alcoholic beverages at the gathering, verifying the age of persons attending the gathering by inspecting a government-issued license or identification card; and supervising the activities of underage persons at the gathering. 
b.  A gathering constituting a public nuisance may be abated by all reasonable means including, but not limited to, an order by the police requiring the gathering to be disbanded and citations and/or arrests of any persons under any applicable provision of local ordinances or state law. 
c.  This section shall not apply to conduct involving the use of alcoholic beverages that occurs exclusively between an underage person and his or her parent or legal guardian. 
d.  This section shall not apply to any Massachusetts Alcoholic Beverages Control Commission licensee at any premises regulated by the Massachusetts Alcoholic Beverage Control Commission. 
(3)  Mailing of notice to property owner . 
a.  In the event the police department or other local official has responded to a gathering, notice of a response shall be mailed within ten days of the incident to the property owner of the premises and all tenants and co-signors listed on a lease, if available, and shall advise the property owner, tenants and co-signors that the third such response on the same premises within a one-year period, as measured from the date of the first notice, shall result in liability of the property owner, tenants and co-signors for all penalties associated with such response as more particularly described below. 
(4)  Persons liable for a first and second response to a gathering constituting a disorderly house . 
a.  If the police department or any other authorized local official is required to respond to a gathering constituting a public nuisance on the premises, the following persons shall be jointly and severally liable for fines as set forth below. Response costs may also be assessed. 
1.  The person or persons residing on or otherwise in control of the property where such a gathering took place, whether present or not. 
2.  The person or persons who organized or sponsored such a gathering. 
3.  All persons attending such gatherings who engage in any activity resulting in the public nuisance. 
(5)  Persons liable for a third and subsequent response to a gathering constituting a disorderly house . 
a.  If the police department or any other authorized local official is required to respond to a gathering constituting a public nuisance on the premises more than twice in any one-year period, as measured from the date of the first response, the following persons shall be jointly and severally liable for the fines as set forth below. Response costs may also be assessed. 
1.  The person or persons residing on or otherwise in control of the property where such a gathering took place, whether present or not. 
2.  The person or persons who organized or sponsored such a gathering. 
3.  All persons attending such gatherings who engage in any activity resulting in the public nuisance. 
4.  All persons listed as tenants on the lease, including all co-signors on said lease, provided that the notice of the first and second responses has been mailed to the co-signors of said lease as set forth herein and the gathering occurs at least 14 days after the mailing of the second such notice. 
5.  The person, persons or business entity who own the property where the gathering constituting the public nuisance took place, provided that the notice of the first and second responses has been mailed to the owner of the property as set forth herein and the gathering occurs at least 14 days after the mailing of the second such notice. The owner of the property shall not be held responsible for any violation and penalties if they are actively trying to evict a tenant from the property. The one-year time period for violations for a property shall pertain only to the same residents occupying the property who have had the prior violation(s). New residents shall start a new time cycle of one year should they violate the provisions of this section. 
(6)  Enforcement and severability . 
a.  This section may be enforced by the noncriminal disposition process of M.G.L. c.40, section 21D. For the purpose of noncriminal enforcement, the enforcing persons shall be any police officer, fire officer, building department superintendent and/or health department official. 
b.  If enforced pursuant to noncriminal disposition, the fine shall be $300.00 for each offense. The city may additionally seek response costs associated with this section through all remedies or procedures provided by state or local law. 
c.  The provisions of this ordinance shall not limit the authority of police officers to make arrests for any criminal offense arising out of conduct regulated herein, nor shall they limit the City of Westfield's ability to initiate and prosecute any criminal offense arising out of the same circumstances necessitating the application of any provision of this section. 
d.  If any provision of this ordinance, or the application thereof to any person or circumstance, is declared invalid, that invalidity shall not affect the other provisions or applications of this section which can be given effect without the invalid provisions or application. 
(Ord. No. 1621, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 10-29. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - NOISE 

Sec. 10-30. - Purpose. 
    This article is enacted to protect, preserve, and promote the health, safety, welfare, peace, and quiet of the inhabitants of Westfield through the reduction, control, and prevention of such loud or raucous noise that unreasonably disturbs, injures, or endangers the comfort, privacy, repose, health, peace or safety of reasonable persons. 
(Ord. No. 1310, 2-7-02) 
Sec. 10-31. - Land use zones and sound levels. 
(a)  Except as specifically provided for elsewhere in this article, no person shall cause, generate or permit sound, which exceeds the limits set forth below in section 10-31(b), to extend beyond the property line. 
(b)  The sound levels established below are before any adjustments are applied: 
Zoning District Time of Day Max. 
Sound 
Level 
(dBA) All Residential 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. 55 7:00 p.m. to 10:00 p.m. 50 10:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. 45 All Commercial 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. 60 7:00 p.m. to 10:00 p.m. 55 10:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. 50 All Business 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. 65 7:00 p.m. to 10:00 p.m. 65 10:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. 60 All Industrial 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. 75 7:00 p.m. to 10:00 p.m. 75 10:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. 70 Airport 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. 80 7:00 p.m. to 10:00 p.m. 80 10:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. 75  
(c)  Adjustments to maximum sound levels. 
(1)  Agricultural uses shall conform to Industrial District standards. 
(2)  The following uses are exempt from the second levels established in section 10-31(b) above, but may be subject to other sound limitations as set forth elsewhere in this article: 
a.  School-related activities on school property and any organized athletic events or activities occurring on state/municipal athletic fields, playgrounds, parks, or other state/municipal recreation facilities owned or operated by a the state/city, from 8:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m.; 
b.  Church-related activities (including church bells) occurring on church property, from 8:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m.; 
c.  Special events for which city permits have been issued (the issuing authority may impose a maximum sound level (dBA) greater or lesser than in subsection (b) above; 
d.  Operation of aircraft and railroads; 
e.  Public safety or national defense activities conducted by authorized public safety or national defense personnel. 
(3)  Commercial recreational property. 
a.  Definitions. 
Commercial recreational property. The term "commercial recreational property" means any non-residential privately owned non-church, non-school premises that is used primarily for the purpose of open air recreational activities regardless of whether or not a fee is charged. 
Open air recreational activities. The term "open air recreational activities" means activities conducted out-of-doors or under an open-sided structure for the enjoyment or entertainment of participants or spectators. 
b.  Owners of commercial recreational property used for open air recreational activities may apply to the chief of police for a license to exceed the maximum permissible sound levels established at section 10-31(b). 
c.  The application for such license shall be in writing on such form as the chief of police requires. The application shall be filed at the police department between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. Monday through Friday, legal holidays excepted, and shall be accompanied by a fee of $5.00. Each license shall be valid for the calendar year for which it is issued. Renewal licenses shall be processed in the same manner as initial applications for a license. Renewal applications for the upcoming calendar year may be submitted after November 30. 
d.  The chief of police may deny the application for a license in which case he shall set forth his reasons in writing to be mailed or otherwise delivered to the applicant within 30 days of the date of application. In the event that the chief of police grants the license, he shall include specific limitations on time, sound level and manner of sound reproduction as he deems appropriate. The chief of police shall not issue a license requiring a reduction of sound levels below levels that are otherwise allowed pursuant to section 10-31(b). 
(4)  Nonconforming use. The maximum permissible sound level that may be emitted from any lot containing a nonconforming use, i.e. a grandfathered use under the zoning ordinance, shall be the same as that permitted for the most restrictive zone in which the use would be conforming. 
(Ord. No. 1310, 2-7-02) 
Sec. 10-32. - Common activities subject to alternate limitations. 
(a)  Home equipment and powered tools. 
(1)  Powered tools and equipment and any powered tools used in lawn and garden maintenance for home use, excepting such tools and equipment used as part of a home occupation (which must comply with the standards below), are exempt except as set forth below. 
(2)  When used inside a building/structure between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., the sound levels generated by all such equipment shall not exceed the maximum sound level for residential zones as set forth in section 10-31(b). 
(3)  No person shall operate any such equipment or tools outside of a building/ structure in any residential zoned area between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
(4)  Sound levels generated by tools and equipment as part of a home occupation shall not exceed 50 dBA, as measured at the lot line. 
(b)  Construction activities and equipment. 
(1)  Commercial construction activities are subject to the alternate limitations at (b)(2), below, and are not subject to section 10-31(b) except as set forth herein. Such activities may only occur from 7:00 a.m. to 9:00 p.m. Monday through and including Saturdays, and on Sundays from noon until 9:00 p.m. except as set forth below. 
(2)  Maximum sound levels. No person shall operate any equipment or appurtenances thereto in commercial construction, nor undertake activities, to erect, construct, demolish, excavate for, alter or repair any building or structure, which exceeds 85 dBA, when measured at 50 feet (15.2 meters) from the source. This standard shall not apply to trucks, pile drivers, pavement breakers, scrapers, concrete saws and rock drills. 
(3)  Night, weekend and legal holidays limitation. For purposes of this section, "legal holidays" means Christmas Day and Thanksgiving Day. Such activities are prohibited on legal holidays and outside of the days and times specified at section 10-32(b)(1) unless permitted in conformity herewith. A permit for out of hours commercial construction activities must be granted in advance by application to the superintendent of building and the police chief. 
a.  In granting such permit, the city shall consider whether: 
1.  The construction noise in the vicinity of the proposed work site would be less objectionable at night than during the daytime because of different population densities or different neighboring activities; 
2.  Obstruction and interference with traffic particularly on streets of major importance, would be less objectionable at night than during the daytime; 
3.  The type of work to be performed emits noises at such a low level as to not cause significant disturbances in the vicinity of the work site; the character and nature of the neighborhood of the proposed work site; 
4.  Great economic hardship would occur if the work were spread over a longer time; 
5.  Proposed night work is in the general public interest. 
b.  In granting such permits the city may prescribe such conditions, working times, types of construction equipment to be used, and permissible noise levels as it deems to be required in the public interest. 
(4)  In no case may the noise level permitted exceed the maximum sound levels for the zoning district in which the work is occurring, except for reasons of emergency. 
(5)  The equipment exempted in section 10-32(a) above are not exempted during these hours. 
(6)  For purposes of this section, construction activities on a public road within a zone shall be considered as taking place on private property within that zone. 
(c)  The adjustments to permissible sound levels established in section 10-31(c) apply to subsections (b)(2) and (b)(3) above. 
(1)  All equipment used in commercial activities shall have sound control devices no less effective than those provided on the original equipment, and no equipment shall have an unmuffled exhaust. 
(2)  All equipment used in commercial construction activities shall comply with all other pertinent standards of all state and federal agencies and regulations. 
(3)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to construction equipment used in connection with emergency work, provided the city is notified within 12 hours after commencement of work. 
(Ord. No. 1310, 2-7-02) 
Sec. 10-33. - Disturbing, excessive, offensive noises which constitute general public nuisance noise prohibitions; prima facie violations. 
(a)  The unreasonable making of, or knowingly and unreasonably permitting to be made, any unreasonably loud, boisterous or unusual noise, commotion or vibration upon any street, park or other premises open to the public; or upon any municipally owned property, whether open to the public or not; shall be unlawful. The ordinary and usual sound, noise or vibration incidental to the operation of these places when conducted in accordance with the limitations placed upon sound levels specified at section 10-30(b), or as may otherwise be permitted elsewhere under the terms of this article, are exempted from this prohibition. 
(b)  The use or operation of a radio, television, stereo, boom box, amplified musical instrument or similar device that produces or reproduces sound in a manner that is plainly audible to any person other than the player(s) or operator(s) of the device, and those who are voluntarily listening to the sound, and which unreasonably disturbs the peace, quiet, and comfort of neighbors or passer-by is unlawful. Sound levels found to exceed the levels specified at section 10-31(b) when measured in accordance with section 10-33(e) shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section. 
(c)  The use or operation of any of motorized dirt bike, motorcycle, all terrain vehicle or similar off road motorized device that produces sound in a manner that is plainly audible to any person other than the operator of the device, and those who are voluntarily participating in or witnessing the operation of the device, and which unreasonably disturbs the peace, quiet, and comfort of neighbors and passers-by is unlawful. Sound levels found to exceed the levels specified at section 10-31(b) when measured in accordance with section 10-33(e) shall be prima facie evidence of a violation of this section. 
(d)  This provision shall not apply to any participant in a licensed parade, or to any person who has been otherwise duly authorized by the city to engage in such conduct. 
(e)  Enforcement of prima facie violations. 
(1)  The characteristics and conditions which should be considered in determining whether a prima facie violation of the provisions of this section exists should include, but not be limited to the following: 
a.  The level of the noise; 
b.  Whether the nature of the noise is usual or unusual; 
c.  Whether the origin of the noise is natural or unnatural; 
d.  The level of the ambient noise; 
e.  The proximity of the noise to sleeping facilities; 
f.  The nature and zoning of the area from which the noise emanates and the area where it is received; 
g.  The time of day or night the noise occurs; 
h.  The duration of the noise; and 
i.  Whether the noise is recurrent, intermittent, or constant. 
(2)  Any peace officer who is authorized to enforce the provisions of this section and who encounters evidence of a prima facie violation of this section is empowered to confiscate and impound as evidence, any or all of the components creating, amplifying or transmitting the sound. 
(Ord. No. 1310, 2-7-02) 
Sec. 10-34. - Time for compliance. 
    Non-residential operations in existence prior to the date of adoption of this article shall be granted a three-month period within which to comply with provisions of this article. Any facility not in compliance by the end of such three-month period may apply for a temporary permit, as described in section 10-35. This section shall apply only to non-residential facilities already in existence or for which work of improvement had commenced prior to the date this article went into effect. 
(Ord. No. 1310, 2-7-02) 
Sec. 10-35. - Temporary permits. 
    An applicant that qualifies as an existing non-residential facility under section 10-34 may request a temporary permit from the city council. If the applicant can demonstrate that a diligent investigation of available noise abatement techniques indicates that immediate compliance with the requirements of this article would be impractical or unreasonable, the city council may issue a permit to allow an exclusion from the provisions contained in all or part of this article with appropriate conditions to minimize the public detriment caused by such exclusions. Such a permit shall expire at the end of the calendar year in which it is granted. A permittee that desires to renew the permit may apply to do so by filing with the city clerk an application for renewal by November 30. Renewals are subject to the same standards and conditions as an initial application. 
(Ord. No. 1310, 2-7-02) 
Sec. 10-36. - Administration/enforcement. 
(a)  The chief of police, or his or her authorized designees, shall administer and enforce the provisions of this article, except where expressly provided otherwise. All other officers and employees of the city shall assist and cooperate in the administration and enforcement of this article. Notwithstanding the foregoing, for purposes of enforcement, sound level readings must be taken by personnel authorized to enforce this article. 
(b)  First time violators will be warned and required to cease the violation. Subsequent violations of the provisions of this article shall be punished by non-criminal disposition as provided in section 1-9.1 of this Code and enjoined pursuant to section 1-9 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1310, 2-7-02) 
Secs. 10-37-10-44. - Reserved.

ARTICLE I. - PARKS AND RECREATION[2] 

Footnotes:

Sec. 11-1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1627 , adopted May 7, 2015, repealed  11-1, which pertained to department of parks and recreation, established, and derived from Ord. No. 1526, adopted Sept. 2, 2010.
