Sec. 11-11. - Parks and recreation commission established. 
    There shall be established the parks and recreation commission which shall serve as the successor to the parks and recreation commission as previously existing under the ordinances of the city and which shall have the powers and responsibilities as set forth hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 1526, 9-2-10) 
Sec. 11-12. - Membership; appointment; terms of office; vacancy. 
(a)  The parks and recreation commission shall consist of one member from each ward of the city and two at-large members. Each member shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation by the vote of the city council, for a term of three years or until a successor is duly qualified or otherwise removed in accordance with section 7 of the City Charter. 
(b)  The term of office shall commence the first Monday of February of the year of appointment. Those incumbents serving as of the date of adoption of Ordinance No. 1526 shall continue to serve through the expiration of their respective terms. 
(c)  The mayor, subject to confirmation by vote of the city council, may fill any vacancy for the unexpired term. 
(Ord. No. 1526, 9-2-10) 
Sec. 11-13. - Qualifications. 
(a)  Each member shall be an adult resident of the city and, for members serving as ward representatives, shall be domiciled within the ward for which the member serves. 
(b)  No member of the city council, nor the city clerk, city treasurer, city collector, city auditor, city solicitor, mayor or member of the mayor's department shall be a member of the commission. 
(c)  No member shall have been convicted of a felony and any member convicted of a felony while serving on the commission shall forfeit the appointment and vacate the office. 
(Ord. No. 1526, 9-2-10) 
Sec. 11-14. - Duties. 
(a)  The parks and recreation commission shall meet no less frequently than once a month with the deputy superintendent of parks to review the operation of the department of parks and recreation and to approve policy, park and playground improvements and recreation programming. The parks and recreation commission shall review the annual budget prepared by the director prior to its submission to the mayor and make such recommended changes as it deems appropriate, which recommendations will be submitted to the mayor with the director's budget proposal. 
(b)  The parks and recreation commission shall have charge and control of the city parks, playgrounds, recreation facilities and cemeteries other than such recreation facilities and playgrounds as are under the charge and control of the school committee. The commission shall exercise its charge and control through the deputy superintendent of parks. The commission shall approve each new use of, or new program offered at, the parks, playgrounds, recreation facilities and cemeteries under its charge and control. 
(Ord. No. 1526, 9-2-10; Ord. No. 1627 , 5-7-15) 
Sec. 11-15. - Organization. 
    The commission shall, annually in the month of February, organize by electing a chairman and secretary. The chairman shall serve as the presiding officer within the meaning of M.G.L.A. c. 39,  23C, and, in the event of the chairman's absence from a meeting of the commission at which a quorum is present, a chairman pro tempore shall be elected by vote of the members in attendance. 
(Ord. No. 1526, 9-2-10) 
Secs. 11-16-11-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC PARKS; IN GENERAL[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1526, adopted Sept. 2, 2010, redesignated Art. III, Div. 3, Public Parks; In General as Art. II. 
Cross reference- Playground commission,  8(10). 
State Law reference- Public parks and playgrounds, M.G.L.A. c. 45. 

Sec. 11-66. - Public park defined. 
    Whenever the words "public park" are used in this chapter they shall be understood as including: Apremont Park, Chauncey Allen Park, Clay Hill Park, Grandmothers Garden, General Shepard Park, General Wareham Park, Holcomb Park, Islands on the corner of Broad and West Silver Streets, Islands on Court Street east of Washington Street, including Soldiers Monument, Kane Park, Half Mile Falls Park, Parker Memorial Park, Park Square, Tekoa Park and Wojtkiewicz Park. Also included are the historic cemeteries, East Mountain Cemetery, Mechanic Street Cemetery and Mundale Cemetery. All public park boundaries are shown on the city assessor's map. 
(Ord. No. 1387, 7-1-04) 
Sec. 11-67. - Littering in parks or playgrounds. 
    No person shall, in or upon any public park or playground, drop, place or throw and suffer to remain on the ground any paper, waste, refuse, empty container or offensive matter of any kind. 
(Ord. No. 1387, 7-1-04) 
Sec. 11-68. - Consumption, possession of alcoholic beverages. 
    No person shall possess, drink or consume any alcoholic beverage or any malt beverage upon any school, park or playground property of the city unless authorized by a lease, license agreement or any other type of agreement duly executed by the body having care, custody and control of said parcel. Any lease, license agreement or other agreement granted shall be subject to full compliance with all permitting as may be required by the liquor license commission. 
    The city council may, by majority vote, grant an exemption to this section for site-and date-specific civic events. Any exemption granted shall be subject to full compliance with all permitting as may be required by the liquor license commission. 
(Ord. No. 1387, 7-1-04; Ord. No. 1472, 7-14-09; Ord. No. 1510, 1-14-10; Ord. No. 1700, 2-7-19) 
Sec. 11-69. - Injuring trees, grass; picking flowers. 
    No person shall, in any public park, injure or destroy any tree, grass or turf, or injure, dig up or destroy any shrub, vine or plant, or pick any flower. The requirements of Chapter 16, Article IV, Trees shall apply to all public trees and public shade trees in any public park. 
(Ord. No. 1387, 7-1-04) 
Sec. 11-70. - Sleeping in chairs, on benches. 
    No person shall, in any public park, sleep on any seat, settee or bench. 
(Ord. No. 1387, 7-1-04) 
Sec. 11-71. - Removing benches; writing on, cutting, defacing benches. 
    No person shall remove from the fixed position in which it shall have been placed in any public park any settee, seat, bench or other article provided by the city for the use of persons resorting to such park. No person shall cut, write or print any indecent or obscene marks, words or figures on such articles or in any way cut, deface or mark such. 
(Ord. No. 1387, 7-1-04) 
Sec. 11-72. - Posting signs, advertisements. 
(a)  No person shall, in any public park, post, place or erect any sign, notice or advertisement, except in accordance with a permit from the mayor. 
(b)  No permanent sign shall be erected in any public park, except in accordance with a permit from the mayor authorized by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1387, 7-1-04) 
Sec. 11-73. - Curfew. 
(a)  No person shall, in any public park or playground, all school grounds, be present after the closing time for such park or playground. 
(b)  Closing time for all nonlighted public parks or playgrounds, shall be dusk. 
(c)  Closing time for all lighted public parks or playgrounds, all school grounds, shall be 10:30 p.m. 
(d)  Closing time for parks and playgrounds, all school grounds, at which department sanctioned events take place shall be one-half hour after the sanctioned event terminates. 
(Ord. No. 1387, 7-1-04) 
Secs. 11-74-11-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DEPARTMENT OF ELDER AFFAIRS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1526, adopted Sept. 2, 2010, redesignated Art. IV, Elder Affairs Division, as Art. III and amended the title to read as herein set out. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 11-91. - Department of elder affairs established. 
    There shall be established a department of elder affairs which shall serve as the successor to the division of elder affairs of the former community services department. 
(Ord. No. 1387, 7-1-04; Ord. No. 1526, 9-2-10) 
Sec. 11-92. - Administration. 
(a)  The head of the department of elder affairs shall be the executive director of the council on aging who is appointed to office in accordance with section 2-367. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the executive director to prepare the annual budget of the department of elder affairs and administer the budget authorized. The executive director shall oversee and administer all grants and gifts and shall approve the contracts and expenditures of the department. 
(c)  The executive director shall attend the meetings of the council on aging and shall promote, oversee and direct the daily programs and services provided to senior citizens. The executive director shall develop and implement such senior citizen support services as recommended by the council on aging, including, but not limited to such services as information and referral, congregate meals, the companionship program, the SHINE program, wellness programs, tax preparation assistance and other appropriate educational and recreational opportunities for senior citizens. 
(d)  The executive director may appoint such assistants as are authorized in order to assist in carrying out the foregoing responsibilities and shall supervise their work. 
(Ord. No. 1387, 7-1-04; Ord. No. 1389, 11-4-04; Ord. No. 1526, 9-2-10) 
DIVISION 2. - SENIOR CITIZEN PROPERTY TAX WORK-OFF PROGRAM 

Sec. 11-93. - Established. 
    This article is hereby established upon acceptance by the city council of M.G.L.A. c. 59,  5K. 1 [] 
(Ord. No. 1433, 11-15-06) 
Footnotes: 
--- () --- 
M.G.L.A. c. 59,  5K was accepted by the city council on Oct. 18, 2006. 

Sec. 11-94. - Requirements, etc. 
(a)  Program goals. 
(1)  To assist senior citizens of the city with the payment of residential property tax bills. 
(2)  To increase the involvement of senior citizens in the municipal government and the school system of the city. 
(3)  To acknowledge and affirm the skills and abilities of Westfield senior citizens and the community's continuing need for their services. 
(b)  Eligibility requirements. 
(1)  An applicant must meet or exceed the following requirements to be eligible to participate in the program: 
a.  Must have attained the age of 60 years. 
b.  Must own and reside in a home in the city or be the current spouse of such a homeowner residing in the same household. Ownership means the assessed owner of the property on which the tax to be abated is assessed, or have acquired ownership before the work is performed and the abatement applied. If the property is subject to a trust, the senior must have legal title (be one of the trustees), on the applicable January 1 assessment date, or at the time the work is performed. 
c.  Must be a resident of the city. 
d.  Must own and occupy the residential property for which real estate taxes are paid to the city by the applicant and on which an abatement is requested. 
(c)  Employment opportunities. 
(1)  There must be a request for assistance under the program by municipal or school department offices based upon the needs of the municipal or school department offices. 
(2)  The employment opportunities include, but are not limited to municipal offices, schools and special projects. 
(d)  Selection process. 
(1)  An applicant must meet the eligibility requirements set forth in subsection (b). 
(2)  The applicant must have the appropriate skills necessary for the position. 
(3)  The department head and the applicant must agree and assent to the assignment of an applicant to a particular department. 
(4)  The elder services coordinator or her designee will coordinate and execute this program and shall develop an application for the senior tax work-off program. 
(e)  Abatement guidelines. 
(1)  The hourly rate for services cannot exceed the state's minimum wage or be lower than the federal minimum wage. Therefore, the rate shall be set to the state's minimum wage. 
(2)  The maximum abatement credited to an individual shall be $500.00 per fiscal year. The maximum abatement per household shall be $500.00. 
(3)  The maximum number of hours worked will be determined according to current state minimum wage, i.e. $500.00 divided by the state minimum wage. 
(4)  The abatements will be charges against the overlay account. No checks will be issued. 
(5)  Upon completion of the number of necessary to reach the maximum abatement allowed under this section off work service or fraction thereof an abatement in accordance with M.G.L.A. c. 184,  52, will be applied to the corresponding fiscal year tax bill. Earned reductions must be applied to the actual tax bills for the fiscal year. 
(6)  The maximum abatement to any senior during a program year shall be $500.00 per year (number of hours worked at state minimum wage). Applicants shall be aware that the abatement allowed shall be considered taxable income although the city is not obligated to issue an IRS Form 1099 for payments less than $600.00. The amount of the property tax abatement by the taxpayer under this program is not considered income or wages for the purposes of state income tax withholding, unemployment compensation or worker's compensation. The IRS has ruled that under current federal law the abatement amount is included in the taxpayer's gross income for both federal income tax and Federal Insurance Contribution Act (FICA) tax purposes. 
(f)  Applications. 
(1)  The city elder services coordinator or her designee shall monitor, supervise and administer the program. 
(2)  Applications for such program, including, but not limited to, the forms of application, required supporting documentation and limitations on time period for that application process for each fiscal year, shall be prepared by the elder services coordinator or her designee in coordination with the personnel director in a form suitable to meet the goals of this division. 
(g)  Applicant limitations. 
(1)  Participants from previous years are encouraged to apply, however their applications shall be considered after all new program applicants have participated in the program in order to permit more senior citizens an opportunity to participate in the program. 
(2)  Acceptance is based on the ability of the applicant to perform tasks required in available positions. 
(3)  Placements are decided by the elder services coordinator or her designee based on skills and interest of the applicants and needs of the various departments. Requests for certain positions by applicants will be considered, however applicants must be willing to accept a position when offered based on the offer made by the elder services coordinator or her designee. 
(4)  Applicants have the right to refuse placements, but each applicant will be taken on a maximum of two interviews. Applicants may have the option to defer placement in a position pending the possibility of other opportunities; however there is no guarantee that other positions will become available. 
(h)  Additional rules. 
(1)  The income guidelines for the program shall be three times the poverty rate as set by the United States Department of Health and Human Services. 
(2)  To start, the program will be limited to no more than 40 participants. Positions will be offered on the basis of qualification, availability, location and physical limitation. The program will be evaluated before continued implementation in FY 2009. 
(3)  To be credited in a given fiscal year, work must be completed by November 30 of the fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. 1433, 11-15-06; Ord. No. 1446, 3-14-07; Ord. No. 1544, 4-21-11) 
Secs. 11-95-11-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DEPARTMENT OF VETERANS SERVICES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1526, adopted Sept. 2, 2010, redesignated Art. V, Veterans Services Division, as Art. IV as titled herein and amended the article in its entirety. The former Art. V derived from Ord. No. 1387, adopted July 1, 2004. 

Sec. 11-101. - Department of veterans services established. 
    The department of veterans services is hereby created. This department shall be responsible for providing services and benefits to veterans and their dependents in accordance with state and federal law and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1526, 9-2-10) 
Sec. 11-102. - Veterans' agent. 
    The mayor shall appoint the veterans' agent annually, in the month of April. This appointment is pursuant to M.G.L.A. c. 115,  3. The veterans' agent shall act for the mayor in the disbursement of veterans' benefits. The veterans' agent shall perform all other duties as may be assigned or authorized by the commissioner of veterans services of the commonwealth. 
(Ord. No. 1526, 9-2-10) 
Sec. 11-103. - Administration. 
(a)  The veterans' agent shall perform all duties in disbursing and administering a program of cash benefits, medical care or other assistance to eligible veterans and their dependents. 
(b)  The veterans' agent shall act as a liaison between state and federal government and the veterans and their dependents. 
(c)  The veterans' agent shall prepare and process applications for veterans' ordinary benefits; prepare and process medical budgets; direct and conduct periodic investigation of claimants for continuation of benefits and perform all other tasks necessary to comply with all state and federal laws and regulations. 
(d)  The veterans' agent shall prepare and submit appeal cases for veterans and their dependents and appear before the board of veterans' appeals. 
(e)  The veterans' agent shall submit all reports required by the department of veterans' services. 
(f)  The veterans' agent shall serve as liaison to local veterans' organizations and shall manage the flag program. 
(Ord. No. 1526, 9-2-10) 
Sec. 11-104. - Oath of office. 
    The veterans' agent shall be sworn to the faithful discharge of the duties of the office. 
(Ord. No. 1526, 9-2-10) 
Sec. 11-105. - Bond required. 
    The veterans' agent shall furnish such bond for the full and faithful accounting of moneys received by him as may be required by the mayor and city council. 
(Ord. No. 1526, 9-2-10) 
Sec. 11-106. - Annual report. 
    The veterans' agent shall make an annual report to the city, in writing. 
(Ord. No. 1526, 9-2-10) 
Sec. 11-107. - Civil service laws not applicable. 
    The state civil service laws shall not apply to the appointment of the veterans' agent. 
(Ord. No. 1526, 9-2-10) 
Secs. 11-108-11-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - NAMING OF MUNICIPAL FACILITIES[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1526, adopted Sept. 2, 2010, redesignated Art. VI, Naming of Municipal Facilities, as Art. V. 

Sec. 11-121. - Naming of municipal facilities generally. 
    This article is adopted to set forth a standard procedure to be followed in the naming of municipal buildings, municipal parks and other municipal facilities. This shall not govern the procedure for naming streets. 
(Ord. No. 1387, 7-1-04) 
Sec. 11-122. - Facilities appropriate for naming. 
    Buildings, parks, squares and athletic fields may be nominated for naming. Portions of buildings and sections of parks that constitute a recognized, distinct and separate area within the larger structure or location to be named. Examples would include auditoriums, specialized rooms intended to be used throughout the useful life of a larger structure for a particular purpose such as a computer center and significant individual gardens within a larger park, such as a dedicated rose garden. 
(Ord. No. 1387, 7-1-04) 
Sec. 11-123. - Nomination. 
(a)  To be considered for naming, a facility appropriate for naming must be nominated. Nominations may be made: 
(1)  By the mayor; 
(2)  By the ward councilor of the ward in which the facility is located; 
(3)  By majority vote of the board or commission under whose charge the city council has placed in control of the facility; 
(4)  By written petition of 25 voters of the city. 
(b)  The nomination must be presented in writing to the city clerk who shall place the matter on the agenda for the regular city council meeting next following the date of receipt of the nomination provided, however, that said nomination is presented no less that five business days in advance of the city council meeting. If the nomination is not presented, the city clerk shall place the matter on the agenda for the second regular city council meeting next following the date of presentation. 
(Ord. No. 1387, 7-1-04) 
Sec. 11-124. - Receipt of nomination. 
    Upon presentation of the nomination before the city council, the council may vote to receive the nomination and place it on file or may vote to refer it to the city property and facilities committee for hearing and recommendation. 
(Ord. No. 1387, 7-1-04) 
Sec. 11-125. - Proceedings before the city property and facilities committee. 
    The city property and facilities committee shall hold a public hearing on each nomination referred to it. The date, place and time of the hearing shall be posted by the city clerk on the city council bulletin board outside city council chambers at the municipal building no less than five business days in advance of the hearing. The individual who initially presented the nomination to the city clerk shall receive written notice of the hearing date by copy of the bulletin board posting mailed in the U.S. mail postage prepaid no less than five business days in advance of the date of hearing. Mailing may be waived is the notice is hand delivered provided delivery is made no less than five business days in advance of the date of hearing. Such other and further notice shall be provided in the discretion of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1387, 7-1-04) 
Sec. 11-126. - Allowable names. 
    The use of geographic locations, compass directions, recognized city neighborhoods and names derivative of well-established street names is encouraged as names of this nature assist in locating the facility. The use of historic names, whether the name of a distinguished, deceased resident of Westfield or a significant historic event is appropriate as is the naming of a facility as a memorial to a deceased city resident whose significant contributions made over a number of years enriched the quality of life in the community. The naming of a facility for a living person should be limited to one without whose substantial financial contribution the facility would not have been so constructed. 
(Ord. No. 1387, 7-1-04) 
Sec. 11-127. - Acceptance. 
    At the conclusion of the hearing before the city property and facilities committee the committee shall deliberate and vote. The matter shall be reported to the city council by the committee with its recommendation. The city shall then by majority vote of the whole council adopt the name presented. Should the vote fail to secure the support of a majority of the city council, the name shall not again be considered as the name to be affixed to a municipal facility until after the expiration of 12 months from the city council vote. 
(Ord. No. 1387, 7-1-04) 
Sec. 11-128. - Existing names to be retained. 
    Municipal facilities, including the several parks and squares, shall retain the names as named by the city council. The city council may, by a two-thirds vote of the whole council, change the name of any park, square or other municipal facility in the city provided that, whenever renaming is considered, the matter is referred to the city property and facilities committee in accordance with the requirements of this ordinance and the vote of the city council is taken only after a public hearing, the time and place for which has been advertised once in a newspaper of general circulation within the city at least five business days before the date of such hearing. 
(Ord. No. 1387, 7-1-04) 
Chapter 12 - PERSONNEL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- City departments, boards and officers,  9; salary of mayor and council,  12. 
Cross reference- Officers and employees generally,  2-61 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 12-1. - Applicability of state civil service laws and regulations. 
    All provisions for the establishment and maintenance of the position classification for the municipal service and related personnel actions shall be in accordance with the laws and regulations of the commonwealth governing civil service administration. Provisions in this chapter with respect to required approval of the personnel administrator of the department of personnel administration and the civil service commission shall refer to positions in the "Official Service" subject to state civil service jurisdiction. Provisions in this chapter with respect to required approval of the local labor service director shall refer to positions in the "Labor Service" subject to state civil service jurisdiction. 
(Code 1971,  12-1) 
Sec. 12-2. - Department heads to be available to public during normal business hours. 
    Department heads shall be available to the public during the normal business hours of City Hall. A department head who leaves City Hall during business hours shall, when possible, inform staff members of his destination and time of return. 
(Code 1971,  12-3) 
Sec. 12-3. - Employee report of city expenditures. 
    All municipal employees attending any convention, seminar, educational course, or similar activity at the request of and expense of the city shall, within ten business days after the completion of such convention, seminar, educational course or similar activity, file with the office of the city clerk a written report of such convention, seminar, educational course or similar activity. Should more than one municipal employee attend the same activity, a joint report signed by all those in attendance may be filed. 
(Code 1971,  12-4) 
Sec. 12-4. - Advertising municipal positions. 
    Vacancies in all full-time positions in the municipal service, except those directly appointed by the mayor without confirmation, shall be posted in a prominent place in the municipal building in keeping with civil service requirements, affirmative action requirements, and collective bargaining agreements. Vacancies in full-time positions, other than positions under civil service, shall be advertised in a newspaper of local circulation at least 30 days prior to any appointment to such position. 
(Ord. No. 785, 7-20-78) 
Sec. 12-5. - Administrative heads of municipal departments vacancy and qualifications. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purposes of this section, the following words and phrases shall have the meaning ascribed to them by this section, except in those instances where the context clearly indicates that a different meaning was intended: 
    Appointing authority. The individual, board commission or legislative body empowered by law to hire the administrative head of a municipal department as defined below. 
    Administrative head of municipal department. That single individual who, by whatever designation, e.g., superintendent, director, chief, is appointed to serve as chief operating officer and day to day administrative head of a city department except law, fire, school department and the gas and electric light department. This definition does not change the powers of municipal boards or commissions which, by City Charter or other applicable law, are the final authority within their respective departments for those departments with a board or commission structure. 
(b)  Prior to filling a vacancy for administrative head of a municipal department, the appointing authority shall review the adequacy of the then existing job description for the administrative head of the department with the personnel director, shall make such changes as may be necessary to provide an appropriate description of the job and shall establish such qualifications as are required by law or as are otherwise appropriate so as to endure the selection of a candidate with the skills commensurate with the responsibilities of the job. 
(c)  Upon final approval of the job description by the appointing authority, it shall be presented to the city council and, if not rejected by the city council at the second regularly scheduled council meeting following council receipt of the job description as a communication, it shall have full force and effect. 
(d)  No appointment shall be made of an individual as permanent administrative head of a municipal department unless the appointee shall meet the minimum qualifications specified in the job description prepared as aforesaid. 
(Ord. No. 1198, 12-4-97; Ord. No. 1528, 9-2-10) 
Sec. 12-6. - Temporary appointment upon a vacancy in certain positions. 
(a)  In the absence of an applicable law, regulation or agreement, a vacancy in the municipal service may be filled by a temporary appointment by the appointing authority for a period of time not to exceed 60 days. The individual so appointed shall have the word "acting" included in the job title of the position to which he/she is appointed. No such acting appointment shall require city council confirmation. The temporary acting appointment may be extended by the appointing authority with council confirmation, however, no such appointment may be extended beyond six months. The individual appointed on an acting basis may be a candidate for the position when it is opened for applications. 
(b)  The appointment by the appointing authority shall be in writing and shall state the effective date of appointment and the duration of the appointment. The appointing authority may modify the duties of the position to conform to the scope of the duties expected to be performed during the stated temporary period of the appointment. Prior to making an appointment, the appointing authority shall consult with the personnel director who shall review the qualifications of the candidate for appointment to the acting position. 
(c)  Individual appointed in an acting capacity shall receive compensation greater than the rate received by the individual last filling the position on a permanent basis. The compensation set for the acting position shall be set at such rate as approved by the appointing authority in consultation with the personnel director with the approval of the city auditor. 
(Ord. No. 1453, 10-9-07; Ord. No. 1574, 5-17-12) 
Sec. 12-7. - Unclassified service. 
Salary of mayor: $100,000 annually, effective since January of 2014. Salary of the city council: $12,000 annually, effective January 1, 2018 $13,000 annually, effective July 1, 2018 $13,500 annually, effective January 1, 2020 $14,000 annually, effective January 1, 2022 $14,500 annually, effective January 1, 2024 $15,000 annually, effective January 1, 2026  
(Ord. No. 1663 , 2-16-17; Ord. No. 1678 , 12-21-17) 
Secs. 12-8-12-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PERSONNEL DIRECTOR[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Officers and employees,  2-61. 

Sec. 12-31. - Personnel department, created, appointment, term, staff. 
(a)  Personnel director: The personnel director of the city is to be appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation by the city council for a period of three years from the date of confirmation, or until a successor is duly chosen or is otherwise removed in accordance with Chapter 7 of the City Charter or such other acts as specified by law. 
(b)  Assistant personnel director: The assistant personnel director shall report to and assist the personnel director in the performance of the duties of the personnel office as outlined in sections 12-32 through 12-46 of this article. The assistant personnel director may, in the absence of a personnel director, perform the duties of the personnel office and act as the department head. 
(c)  Payroll supervisor: The payroll supervisor shall report to the assistant personnel director and shall be responsible for the input of payroll from all city and school departments as well as implementation of all payroll regulations and initiatives. 
(d)  Benefits coordinators: 
(1)  City-side coordinator: Shall report to the assistant personnel director on all city related benefit matters. 
(2)  School-side coordinator: Shall report to the assistant personnel director on all school related benefit matters. 
(e)  Financial analyst: The financial analyst shall report to the assistant personnel director and shall be responsible for the daily administration of the personnel office and payment of invoices. 
(f)  [Other staff:] Such other staff as authorized by the mayor in the annual budget submission to the city council for which appropriation is voted. 
(Ord. No. 875,  1, 9-15-83; Ord. No. 1074, 9-5-91; Ord. No. 1589, 8-15-13) 
Sec. 12-32. - Supervision of employees generally. 
    The personnel director shall supervise, under direction of the mayor and under the law and rules of the commonwealth, all the employees of the city except those employed by the gas and electric commission and the school committee. Such supervision shall include the duties which are outlined in this article. 
(Ord. No. 875,  2, 9-15-83) 
Sec. 12-33. - Approved application required for employment. 
    No employee shall be hired by the city after July 1, 1983, or paid unless the prospective employee shall have made application upon a form proscribed by the personnel department, and the personnel director has in writing approved the form of hiring and transmitted such approval to the auditor and department head. 
(Ord. No. 875,  3, 9-15-83) 
Sec. 12-34. - Salary adjustments. 
    No city employee shall have his salary adjusted except by ordinance, step raise or negotiated salary increase as provided by collective bargaining or individual service agreement unless the personnel director shall have approved such adjustment. The personnel director shall proscribe forms to undertake such adjustments. 
(Ord. No. 875,  4, 9-15-83) 
Sec. 12-35. - Approval of notices, correspondence posted on bulletin boards. 
    Copies of all notices to employees posted on bulletin boards concerning employees, together with all correspondence concerning employees, shall be transmitted to the personnel director for his information. No department may post upon its bulletin board a notice to employees if such notice has been disapproved by the personnel director. 
(Ord. No. 875,  5, 9-15-83) 
Sec. 12-36. - Prior approval of disciplinary action. 
    Prior to issuance of written disciplinary action or a suspension or discharge of an employee by the department head or commission, the department in which that employee works must consult with the personnel director, except for emergency suspension of 48 hours or less, which may be effected by the department head. No employee may be discharged by the city unless the personnel director shall have approved in advance and in writing that such action may be taken. Nothing in this section of law shall be interpreted to deprive boards or commissions of their authority to take final votes on actions relating to personnel matters under civil service law; however, no action may proceed except as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 875,  6, 9-15-83) 
Sec. 12-37. - Notice of grievances. 
    No employee grievance shall be heard or adjusted, whether under a collective bargaining agreement or not, unless the personnel director has been given notice of such hearing and been afforded an opportunity to be present. 
(Ord. No. 875,  7, 9-15-83) 
Sec. 12-38. - Proposal of personnel regulations. 
    The personnel director or personnel department may from time to time propose to the city council the adoption of personnel regulations which, if not rejected or amended by the city council within six days of presentment, shall have full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 875,  8, 9-15-83) 
Sec. 12-39. - Employee manuals for collective bargaining units. 
    The personnel director shall provide as soon as possible employee manuals for each collective bargaining unit in the city. Such manual shall outline personnel policy and provide for the administration of collective bargaining contracts affected. 
(Ord. No. 875,  9, 9-15-83) 
Sec. 12-40. - Meetings with department heads, programs for employee benefits. 
    It shall be the duty of the personnel director to advise and meet with the department heads of the city concerning the safety of employees, productivity of employees, assignment and disposition of employees, morale of employees and/or the implementation of city-wide employee programs. Subject to funding approval, the personnel director may propose for adoption programs involving individual employee health, well-being or productivity or such other programs as shall be a benefit to the employees of the city. 
(Ord. No. 875,  10, 9-15-83) 
Sec. 12-41. - Monthly report of leave taken, annual review of sick leave. 
    Each department in the city shall, monthly, in the manner prescribed by the personnel director, provide an accounting of the absences of each employee in the department for purposes of personal leave, vacation, sick leave, or other mandated leave or absence without leave. The personnel department shall yearly provide a department by department review of the use of such leave days. 
(Ord. No. 875,  11, 9-15-83) 
Sec. 12-42. - Administration of collective bargaining agreements. 
    If a department head requires or requests assistance in administering the collective bargaining agreements' terms and conditions, such requests, when answered in writing, shall be held in a central file and, where applicable to more than one department, shall be distributed. The opinions in writing of the personnel director shall be part of the personnel policy of the city and will become the policy of each department. 
(Ord. No. 875,  12, 9-15-83) 
Sec. 12-43. - City's representative before administrative agencies. 
    The personnel director of the city shall be the representative of the city in proceedings before the department of employment security, Massachusetts Commission Against Discrimination, Massachusetts Labor Relations Commission or equal employment opportunity commission or other administrative agencies concerning labor matters. The personnel director shall be the affirmative action officer of the city when the city is mandated by law to have such an officer. 
(Ord. No. 875,  13, 9-15-83) 
Sec. 12-44. - Advice to labor service director. 
    The personnel director shall be responsible for the preparation and maintenance of job descriptions for employees in the city service as provided in section 12-32, and shall advise the labor service director from time to time as to the duties of that position. No job description or qualification requisition shall be transmitted to the department of personnel administration of the commonwealth or any successor agency, unless it shall first have been approved by the personnel director. 
(Ord. No. 875,  14, 9-15-83) 
Sec. 12-45. - Central employee records. 
    The personnel director shall create, maintain and supervise, with such assistance as shall be provided, the central employee records of the city. The personnel director shall from time to time issue regulations for access to such records. Departments, boards or commissions of the city shall send to the personnel department for inclusion in the personnel records the following: 
(1)  Copies of the minutes of all meetings at which personnel matters are voted or discussed. 
(2)  Copies of all forms or documents relating to personnel matters. 
(3)  All correspondence to employees concerning their employment or any other personnel matter. 
(4)  Copies of all correspondence from outside the department or city including written grievances on personnel matters. 
(5)  Where possible, a monthly summary of oral warnings to employees. 
(Ord. No. 875,  15, 9-15-83) 
Sec. 12-46. - Study analyses, activities. 
    At the direction of the mayor, the personnel director may undertake study analysis and activities in such other areas as may benefit the city including, but not limited to, preparing reports assisting other department heads or city bodies or assisting in the resolution of employment matters. Whenever qualified, the personnel director shall without approval of the mayor assist the law department in preparation, trial or resolution of any employee-related litigation or any other litigation which the law department requests the assistance of the personnel director. 
(Ord. No. 875,  16, 9-15-83) 
Sec. 12-47. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1589, adopted August 15, 2013, repealed  12-47, which pertained to assistant personnel director and derived from Ord. No. 1566, adopted Dec. 1, 2011. The user's attention is directed to  12-31. 
Secs. 12-48-12-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TERMS OF EMPLOYMENT 

Sec. 12-61. - Applicability. 
    This article shall cover the terms and conditions of employment and standards of performance for employees not covered by a collective bargaining or personal service contract. Any provision of any municipal personnel ordinance which is in conflict with such contracts shall be superseded by such contracts. 
Sec. 12-62. - Leaves with pay. 
    All employees not covered under section 12-61 shall be entitled to leaves with pay for vacation, sickness, maternity, personal, or bereavement reasons which shall be as described in duly negotiated and executed collective bargaining contracts as described in section 12-61. Those employees not covered in section 12-61 shall enjoy benefits to the greater amount as specified by any of the above cited agreements. 
Sec. 12-63. - Compensation upon retirement. 
    All employees not covered under section 12-61 upon retirement from service with the city, shall be entitled to compensation for unused accumulated sick leave days to the greater number as described in duly negotiated and executed collective bargaining contracts as described in section 12-61. 
Sec. 12-64. - Holiday pay. 
    All employees not covered under section 12-61 shall receive the day off with compensation for holidays to the greater number as described in duly negotiated and executed collective bargaining contracts as described in section 12-61. 
Sec. 12-65. - Longevity. 
    All employees not covered under section 12-61 shall receive a longevity payment for continuous service with the city in a full-time capacity from the first day of employment to the greater amount as described in duly negotiated and executed contracts as described in section 12-61. 
Sec. 12-66. - Military leave. 
    Any employee in the service of the armed forces of the commonwealth under M.G.L.A. c. 133,  38, 40, 41 or 60, or during his annual tour of duty not exceeding 17 days as a member of a reserve component of the armed forces of the United States shall be allowed the difference between the municipal employees' active duty salary and municipal salary, and shall also be entitled to the same leaves of absence or vacation with pay given to other municipal employees. 
(Code 1971,  12-78) 
Sec. 12-67. - Jury duty. 
    An employee called for jury duty shall receive his full compensation on condition that such compensation as received by the employee from the county or the commonwealth for such duty shall be turned over to the city treasurer. Such leave shall continue so long as such jury duty shall continue. 
Sec. 12-68. - Special leave. 
(a)  An employee shall receive the benefit of unpaid leave with prior approval of the mayor and the board or commission for good cause shown for up to three months or to the greater amount as described in duly negotiated and executed collective bargaining contracts as described in section 12-61, whichever shall be greater. 
(b)  During such leave an employee's health insurance and other benefits shall continue, save for the accrual of sick leave, which shall be as described in section 12-61. Time on special unpaid leave shall not be counted for determining length of service but shall not constitute a break of service for purposes of continuous service. 
Sec. 12-69. - Mileage allowance. 
    An employee who uses his personal vehicle on city business shall be entitled to mileage at the prevailing rate paid to the greater amount as described in collective bargaining contracts listed in section 12-61. Tolls and parking fees shall be reimbursed upon the submission of approved vouchers and receipts. 
Sec. 12-70. - Hours of work. 
(a)  The work week shall consist of five consecutive eight-hour days, excluding lunch periods, Monday through Friday, inclusive, for all employees assigned to the labor and trades group, and all employees of the labor and trades supervision group, except as shall otherwise be provided in collective bargaining contracts as stated in section 12-61. 
(b)  The work week shall consist of five consecutive seven-hour days, excluding lunch periods, Monday through Friday, inclusive, for all employees in the clerical, accounting, and administrative groups, except as shall otherwise be provided in collective bargaining contracts as stated in section 12-61. 
(c)  Overtime shall be paid at the rate of time and one-half to employees assigned to the labor and trades groups for any hours worked in excess of eight hours in any work day or 40 hours in any work week. 
(d)  Overtime shall be paid at the rate of time and one-half to employees assigned to the clerical, accounting and administrative groups for any hours worked in excess of seven hours in any work day or 35 hours in any work week. 
(e)  Upon application to the department head, employees assigned to the clerical, accounting and administrative groups may be permitted, in lieu of overtime, to take compensatory time off during working hours for such time worked in excess of 35 hours weekly. 
Sec. 12-71. - Probation and advancements within a compensation schedule. 
    After initial employment or promotion to a position in the municipal service, each employee shall serve a probationary period of six months. At the completion of the first year of service, the employee shall advance to the next higher rate in the appropriate salary schedule as provided by ordinance, and provided that such service shall have been satisfactory. Such advancements shall be made yearly until the employee has reached the maximum rate of the schedule for his position. 
Sec. 12-72. - Initial compensation; advancement. 
    The original appointment to any position shall be made at the entrance rate as such rate is provided by ordinance, and advancement from the entrance rate to the maximum rate shall be by successive steps. Upon recommendation of the department head, the mayor may approve initial compensation at a rate higher than the entrance rate for the position when the needs of the service make such action necessary; provided that the position involves executive, administrative or professional duties, and provided that any such exception is based upon the outstanding and unusual character of the employee's experience and ability over and above the minimum qualifications specified for the position. 
Sec. 12-73. - Return to duty following separation. 
    Whenever an employee returns to duty in a position after a separation from the city service, which separation was not due to discreditable circumstances, such employee shall receive the rate of pay corresponding to the rate received at time of separation and shall subsequently serve there for at least such period as is normally required for advancement to the next step. 
Sec. 12-74. - Return from military service. 
    Any employee who leaves or has left the city service to enter the active service of the armed forces of the United States and who is subsequently reinstated within 90 days of discharge to a position previously held by him shall be entitled to receive a compensation at the rate he would have been entitled had his service with the city not been interrupted by service in the armed forces. 
Sec. 12-75. - Special leaves. 
    The respective department heads, with the approval of the mayor, may authorize special leaves of absence with or without pay for any period or periods not to exceed three calendar months in any one calendar year, provided it will benefit the employee and the city service. Such leave, when granted, shall not interrupt the employee's continuity of service, seniority, vacation or sick leave allowance. Leave under this section shall be for the following purposes: Attendance at college, university, business school, trade or technical school for the purpose of training in subjects related to the work of the employee. 
Sec. 12-76. - Limited duty. 
(a)  Definitions. For purposes of this section the following words and phrases in all grammatical forms shall have the following meanings: 
    Assigned duty means an employee's duties included in his job description or personal service agreement. 
    Employee means any person employed by the city whose salary or hourly wage is paid from the city treasury, excepting the mayor, the members of the city council and all members of boards and commissions. 
    Job-related injury or illness means any injury or illness suffered by an employee without fault on the employee's part while actually employed by the city, or as a result of such employment. 
    Limited duty means any part of an employee's assigned duties included in the employee's job description or personal service agreement. 
    Medically capable means an employee who, after having suffered a job-related injury or illness, is certified by the city physician, a hospital, or other qualified physician as being fit and able to perform limited duty which neither affects nor is affected by such injury or illness. 
    Partially incapacitated means any employee who has suffered a job-related injury or illness and is medically capable of performing limited duty. 
    Temporarily means the length of time during which an employee is required to perform limited duty, provided that such time is set by the city physician, a hospital or any qualified physician. 
(b)  Assignment. All heads of departments or their designees shall assign limited duties to their subordinates pursuant to the following. An employee who is partially incapacitated, because of a job-related injury or illness that may temporarily impair the performance of some of his duties, shall, when medically capable, be required to perform limited duty. 
(Ord. No. 1039,  12-79-12-81, 5-17-90) 
Chapter 13 - PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE II. - PLANNING BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions and committees,  2-256 et seq.; duties of superintendent of building with respect to planning board,  6-35. 

Sec. 13-21. - Acceptance of improved method of municipal planning act. 
    M.G.L.A. c. 41,  81A-81J, relating to an improved method of municipal planning, is hereby adopted by the city. 
(Code 1971,  13-16) 
Sec. 13-22. - Number of members. 
    The planning board shall consist of seven members, with four members constituting a quorum. Additionally, there shall be two associate members who, in the case of a vacancy or of a member's inability to properly act on specific business before the board, shall be designated by the chairperson to serve in that member's stead and act in full capacity and on all matters for the duration of said vacancy or business. 
(Code 1971,  13-17; Ord. No. 1233, 6-3-99; Ord. No. 1609, 11-20-14) 
State Law reference- Membership of planning board, M.G.L.A. c. 41,  81A. 
Sec. 13-23. - Appointment of members. 
    Members of the planning board shall be appointed in accordance with M.G.L. c. 41,  81A. All members of the planning board shall be appointed at large from among the qualified voters of the city; however, at no time shall there be more than two members of the planning board from any ward of the city. Planning board members shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation by the city council. 
(Code 1971,  13-18; Ord. No. 1609, 11-20-14) 
Sec. 13-24. - Term. 
    The term for membership on the planning board shall be for five years. The terms of the planning board members shall be arranged that the term of at least one member will expire each year. 
(Code 1971,  13-19; Ord. No. 1233, 6-3-99; Ord. No. 1609, 11-20-14) 
Sec. 13-25. - Filling vacancies. 
    A vacancy in any position of the planning board shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as in the case of the original appointment. 
(Code 1971,  13-21) 
Sec. 13-26. - Powers; duties. 
    The planning board shall have the powers, duties and responsibilities provided in M.G.L.A. c. 41,  81A-81J, inclusive and as amended, shall hear and decide applications for special permits as provided in MGL c. 40A and where designated by the Zoning Ordinance, and shall have other powers and duties as may be designated or assigned. The board may adopt, and from time to time amend, any rule or regulation not inconsistent with its powers or duties and which concerns the jurisdiction and conduct of its business. 
(Code 1971,  13-21; Ord. No. 1609, 11-20-14) 
Sec. 13-27. - Council to refer location of highways, public buildings, etc., to board; failure of board to act. 
    Before final action is taken by the city council with reference to the location or layout of any new public highway, the location or erection of any new public building or structure, park, playground or bridge, it shall submit such to the planning board for its report and recommendations. The planning board shall file its report with the council within 45 days after the matter has been submitted to it. If it fails to do so, the council may proceed to final action without reference to the report of the planning board. 
(Code 1971,  13-22) 
Secs. 13-28-13-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FLOOD CONTROL COMMISSION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions and committees,  2-256 et seq. 

Sec. 13-51. - Established. 
    There is hereby established in the city a commission to be known as the municipal flood control commission. 
(Code 1971,  13-33) 
Sec. 13-52. - Composition; terms of office. 
    The municipal flood control commission shall be composed of five members, who shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to city council confirmation. They shall serve from the first Monday in February following their appointment for terms for five years and until their successor is named. 
(Code 1971,  13-34; Ord. No. 1628 , 5-7-15) 
Sec. 13-53. - Filling vacancies. 
    If there is of a vacancy in the municipal flood control commission, the mayor with the confirmation of council shall make an appointment to fill the unexpired term. 
(Code 1971,  13-35) 
Sec. 13-54. - Expenditure of moneys. 
    The municipal flood control commission shall have the power to expend such sums of money as may be appropriated by the mayor and city council for flood control promotion. 
(Code 1971,  13-36) 
Sec. 13-55. - Chairman; meeting date. 
    Members of the municipal flood control commission shall elect their own chairman and establish a regular meeting date. 
(Code 1971,  13-37) 
Sec. 13-56. - Annual report. 
    The municipal flood control commission shall file at least one report annually. 
(Code 1971,  13-38) 
Sec. 13-57. - Powers and duties generally. 
    The municipal flood control commission shall meet with county, state and federal agencies regarding flood control projects affecting the city. The commission shall study and submit their recommendations to the mayor and the city council. The commission shall regularly inspect any existing dikes and waterways and any future dikes or flood projects in which the city has a vital interest. In cooperation with the engineering department, recommendations on repairs and any other pertinent matters should be made to the mayor and city council by the commission. Any repairs or construction will be under the supervision of the engineering department. 
(Code 1971,  13-39) 
Sec. 13-58. - Inspection of dangerous conditions; correction. 
    If the municipal flood control commission shall be informed, or has reason to believe, that any refuse or obstruction shall endanger or be likely to endanger the flood control program of the city, then the commission shall make or cause to be made an investigation of the facts and inspect the property where the suspected danger may exist. If the commission shall find that such danger exists, it shall give notice thereof to the owner or his duly authorized agent and to the occupant of the premises, and shall order that such danger be corrected. 
(Code 1971,  13-40) 
Sec. 13-59. - Enforcement of article; injunction relief. 
    The municipal flood control commission is hereby empowered to enforce the provisions of this article and to institute appropriate legal proceedings to restrain by injunction the continuance of any danger to the flood control program of the city. 
(Code 1971,  13-41) 
Secs. 13-60-13-80. - Reserved.
