ARTICLE IX. - BROWNFIELD DEVELOPMENT 

Sec. 13-249. - Established. 
    This article is hereby established upon acceptance by the city council of M.G.L.A. c. 59,  59A. 
(Ord. No. 1239, 9-16-99) 
Sec. 13-250. - Authority. 
    The mayor is hereby authorized to negotiate agreements regarding the payment of outstanding real estate taxes, interest penalties, including abatement of those amount needed to make a cleanup and redevelopment project economically feasible. Said agreement may also contain additional incentives financial and otherwise as may be deemed appropriate. 
(Ord. No. 1239, 9-16-99) 
Sec. 13-251. - Scope of authority. 
    The agreement may cover property contaminated with oil or other hazardous materials and must be zoned for commercial or industrial use. 
    Agreements may be entered into only with new, innocent purchasers who did not own the site at the time the oil or hazardous material was released and did not cause or contribute to its release. 
    Agreements must specify the details agreed to regarding payment of any outstanding obligations, including the amount owed, rate of interest to accrue if any, amount of monthly payments, payment schedule, late penalties and other terms. These obligations may consist of outstanding real estate taxes or other financing packages negotiated with the city. 
    Agreements must be signed by the mayor, president of the city council, property owner, and must be notarized and attested to by the city clerk. Copies must be notarized and attested to by the city clerk. Copies must be provided to the Massachusetts Commissioner of Revenue, Massachusetts Department of Environmental Protection, and the United States Environment Protection Agency. Additionally the property owner and the city council must receive copies. 
(Ord. No. 1239, 9-16-99) 
Sec. 13-252. - Approval of agreements. 
    The city council must approve, by majority vote, any agreements that reduce outstanding property taxes, penalties and interest that total over $100,000.00. All other agreements take effect upon execution by the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 1239, 9-16-99) 
Chapter 14 - POLICE[1] 
  
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- City departments, boards and officers,  9. 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; personnel, ch. 12; traffic and motor vehicles, ch. 17. 
State Law reference- Police generally, M.G.L.A. c. 147,  1 et seq.; powers and duties of police officers in cities, M.G.L.A. c. 41,  98 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Police commission-General authority. 
    The police commission of the city shall, subject to the provisions of this chapter, have the charge, management and control of the officers and members of the police department with power to make such lawful rules for their government and discipline, and for the regulation and repair of the police signal system, and the direction and control of the parties having charge and care thereof as they may deem proper. It shall be responsible for and have the charge and care of all property belonging to the department and shall see that such is maintained in proper manner. The commission shall approve all bills of the department, including the payroll. 
(Code 1971,  14-1) 
Cross reference- Boards, commissions and committees,  2-256 et seq. 
Sec. 14-2. - Same-Meetings; annual estimate of money needed by police department. 
    The police commission shall meet at least once a month. It shall annually, when information is available, prepare and communicate to the mayor an estimate of the amount of money necessary to be raised for the following fiscal year for the use of the police department. 
(Code 1971,  14-2) 
Sec. 14-3. - Composition of police department. 
    The police department shall consist of the police commission, chief of police, two captains, five lieutenants, nine sergeants, such number of police officers as the council may deem necessary, a civilian clerical staff as is deemed necessary, a reserve police force, and such number of school traffic supervisors as the council may deem necessary. 
(Code 1971,  14-3; Ord. No. 1516, 3-22-10) 
Sec. 14-4. - Promotions, appointments. 
    Promotions in the police department and all appointments as police officers, reserve police officers, and civilian clerical staff shall be made by the police commission, subject to the provisions of M.G.L.A. c. 31. 
(Code 1971,  14-4) 
Sec. 14-5. - Oath of office. 
    Before entering on his duty, each police officer shall be sworn to the faithful performance of the duties of his office. 
(Code 1971,  14-5) 
State Law reference- Powers and duties of police officers, M.G.L.A. c. 41,  98. 
Sec. 14-6. - Chief of police-To control all members; powers and duties generally. 
    The chief shall have precedence over all members and employees of the police department below the grade of chief. The members and employees shall at all times be subject to his command and control. He shall, subject to the rules and regulations of the board of police commissioners, from time to time, issue orders consistent with the laws of the commonwealth and the ordinances of the city as may be necessary for the maintenance of proper discipline in the department, for the detail and duties of its members and employees and for the use and disposition of its equipment. 
(Code 1971,  14-6) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees,  2-61 et seq. 
Sec. 14-7. - Same-Preferment of charges against members. 
    The chief of police may prefer charges against any member or employee of the police department. Such charges shall be specific, and in writing, and any hearing thereon and disposition thereof shall be in accordance with M.G.L.A. c. 31. 
(Code 1971,  14-7) 
Sec. 14-8. - Powers and duties of captain. 
    The captain, in the absence of the chief of police, shall have all the powers and perform all the duties of the chief of police. He shall at all times, under the direction of the chief of police and the police commission, aid in the performance of any and all the duties prescribed in this chapter, and other ordinances of the city for the chief of police. 
(Code 1971,  14-8) 
Sec. 14-9. - Replacement of cruisers. 
    Cruisers and police vehicles will be replaced as deemed necessary by the police commission and the police chief. 
(Code 1971,  14-10; Ord. No. 922, 9-18-86) 
Sec. 14-10. - First aid kits in emergency vehicles-Required. 
    All emergency vehicles shall carry an approved city first aid kit. This provision shall not apply to vehicles which must carry medical apparatus by state agencies. 
(Code 1971,  14-11) 
Sec. 14-11. - Same-Contents. 
    First aid kits required by section 14-10 shall be equal to a standard industrial first aid kit which will serve the needs of a facility in industry which will employ ten to 15 persons. The first aid kit shall contain the following: 
(1)  50 band-aids, 3/4?. 
(2)  Ten medium steri-pads. 
(3)  Ten large steri-pads. 
(4)  Two gauze bandages, 2?. 
(5)  One gauze bandage, 4?. 
(6)  One dermicil first aid tape, 1/2?. 
(7)  Ten cleansing wipes. 
(8)  Ten ammonia inhalants. 
(9)  Ten preptic antiseptic swabs. 
(10)  One tube first aid cream. 
(11)  One eye irrigation solution, one-half ounce bottle. 
(12)  One tourniquet. 
(13)  One pair scissors. 
(14)  One tweezer. 
(15)  One first aid booklet. 
(16)  One emergency disposable blanket. 
(17)  One triangular bandage. 
(18)  Two adaptic nonadhering dressings. 
(Code 1971,  14-12; Ord. No. 822, 3-21-80) 
Sec. 14-12. - Same-Examination. 
    The first aid kit required by section 14-10 shall be examined for completeness at the start of each tour of duty of such emergency vehicle, and if the items are missing they shall be replaced as soon as possible. 
(Code 1971,  14-13) 
Secs. 14-13-14-19. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TOWING AND STORAGE OF MOTOR VEHICLES 

Sec. 14-20. - Rules and regulations. 
    Unless inconsistent with the terms and conditions set forth in the Massachusetts General Laws, the duly adopted regulations of an agency of the commonwealth, or of this article, the rules and regulations adopted by the police commission shall govern towing and storage of motor vehicles lawfully seized and held by or by order of, the police department. 
(Ord. No. 1426. 6-28-06) 
Sec. 14-21. - Charges for towing and storage. 
(a)  The charges for towing and storage of motor vehicles when such towing is ordered by the police shall be the rate as set by the Massachusetts Department of Telecommunications and Energy as set forth in M.G.L.A. c. 159B,  6B. 
(b)  For each motor vehicle towed by order of the police, there shall be assessed a one-time administrative fee in accordance with the following schedule: 
(1)  Commercial motor vehicle with one or more than one of the following: (A) three or more axles; (B) a gross motor vehicle weight of 26,001 pounds or greater; (C) an unusually heavy, bulky or dangerous load which requires extensive handling-Fee of $100.00; 
(2)  Non commercial motor vehicle or commercial motor vehicle not subject to the above-stated criteria -Fee of $50.00. 
(c)  In addition to the administrative fee as assessed, there may be paid by such private contractor as is hired by the police department to tow and store such motor vehicles from the fees charged in accordance with M.G.L.A. c. 159,  6B such fee per vehicle as is established through a competitive bid process administered by the police department no less frequently than once each three years. 
(Ord. 1426, 6-28-06; Ord. No. 1615, 3-19-15) 
Sec. 14-23. - Reserved receipt fund, deposit and expenditure. 
(a)  All charges collected by the city in accordance with the charges imposed by section 14-22 shall be separately accounted for in a fund maintained separately from the city general fund and reserved for appropriation by the mayor as approved by the city council consistent with the restrictions on expenditures as set forth herein. 
(b)  The following activities, and no others, are eligible to be funded with monies appropriated from the fund: 
(1)  Purchase of cruisers and other police vehicles as authorized by the police commission. 
(2)  Purchase of parts, equipment and services necessary for the operation and maintenance of the said police vehicles. 
(3)  The purchasing of signs and enforcement tools used by the police to assist with traffic enforcement and safety. 
(Ord. No. 1426, 6-28-06; Ord. No. 1615, 3-19-15; Ord. No. 1696, 10-4-18) 
Chapter 15 - PURCHASING[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1398,  C, adopted May 5, 2005, deleted former ch. 15 of the Code in its entirety and added new provisions as ch. 15. Former ch. 15,  15-1-15-3, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 1269, adopted Dec. 7, 2000. 

Sec. 15-1. - M.G.L.A. c. 30B adopted, sound business practices. 
    The city shall comply with the requirements of M.G.L.A. c. 30B, as it may hereafter be amended, in the procurement and surplus disposition of those items to which said law applies. Procurement and surplus disposition of items not subject to M.G.L.A. c. 30B shall be undertaken in accordance with the applicable laws within which they fall, including M.G.L.A. c.30,  39M; M.G.L.A. c.149; and M.G.L.A. c.7,  38A1/2 to 38O. 
(Ord. No. 1398,  C, 5-5-05; Ord. No. 1508, 12-30-0-9) 
Sec. 15-2. - Designation of chief procurement officers. 
(a)  The chief procurement officer required by M.G.L.A. c. 30B shall, for all city departments, be the purchasing director/agent, with the exception of the gas and electric department. The chief procurement officer for the gas and electric department shall be that individual that has been appointed as manager pursuant to M.G.L.A. c. 164,  56; unless the Westfield Municipal Light Board votes, by a majority, to accept the provisions of M.G.L.A. c. 30B, in which event, the chief procurement officer shall be the purchasing director's delegate; which delegation is authorized and shall be made in accordance with M.G.L.A. c. 30B,  19. The official responsible for procurement within the school department shall be the purchasing director's delegate; which delegation is authorized by and shall be made in accordance with M.G.L.A. c. 30B,  19. 
(b)  There may be an assistant purchasing director and purchasing clerk who shall be subject to the direction and control of the purchasing director. The assistant purchasing director shall have had, prior to his/her appointment, at least three years' experience in purchasing with public or business enterprises. 
(c)  The purchasing director and the assistant purchasing director shall be bonded by the city for the faithful performance of their duties, to be approved by the city solicitor, in a sum to be determined by the mayor. In the absence, inability to serve, removal, resignation or death of the purchasing director, the assistant purchasing director shall carry out the duties of the purchasing director until his/her return or until his/her successor shall have been appointed, such appointment to be for the unexpired term of the purchasing director. 
(Ord. No. 1398,  C, 5-5-05; Ord. No. 1508, 12-30-09) 
Sec. 15-3. - Responsibility for M.G.L.A. c. 30B compliance. 
(a)  It shall be the responsibility of those positions designated as chief procurement officer to assure that all procurements and all dispositions of surplus that are subject to M.G.L.A. c. 30B be conducted in accordance therewith. 
(b)  It shall be the responsibility of those positions designated as chief procurement officer to assure that all procurements that are subject to M.G.L.A. c. 30,  39M be conducted in accordance therewith. 
(c)  It shall be the responsibility of those positions designated as chief procurement officer to assure that all procurements that are subject to M.G.L.A. c. 149 be conducted in accordance therewith. 
(d)  It shall be the responsibility of those positions designated as chief procurement officer to assure that all procurements that are subject to M.G.L.A. c. 7,  22A or 22B be conducted in accordance therewith. 
(Ord. No. 1398,  C, 5-5-05; Ord. No. 1508, 12-30-09) 
Sec. 15-4. - Powers and duties of purchasing director/agent. 
    The purchasing director/agent shall: 
(1)  Be responsible for the procurement and disposal of all supplies, materials, equipment and property for all departments and offices of the city, including contracts for the construction, reconstruction or alteration of city buildings and property, and any services or purchases incidental thereto, and all laws covered under the Uniform Procurement Act, M.G.L.A. c. 30,  39M, M.G.L.A. c. 30B, and M.G.L.A. c. 149,  44A-44J and M.G.L.A. c. 7,  38A1/2 to 38O. All city departments, boards or commissions seeking to award contracts regulated by M.G.L.A. c. 30,  39M; M.G.L.A. c. 149, 44A-44J; and M.G.L.A. c. 7,  38A-38O shall coordinate with the purchasing director/agent on all such contracts. 
(2)  Have authority to order or make inventories of the supplies, materials equipment and furnishing of any and all departments. Any department possessing excess or surplus personal property of any kind or description shall not sell, exchange, transfer or dispose thereof without first certifying such personal property as surplus to the purchasing director/agent; and, thereupon, the purchasing director/agent shall circularize all department and agencies as to their need for such surplus personal property, and if such need is determined, the purchasing director/agent may order transfer of such property from one department or agency to another, and inventory adjustments between the departments shall be made accordingly. Surplus property shall be disposed of by the purchasing director/agent. 
a.  If the value of the property being disposed of is estimated to be more than $500.00, the purchasing department shall advertise for bids in a daily paper having a general circulation in the city for at least two consecutive weeks and shall award the sale of such property to the highest responsible bidder. If it is in the best interest of the city, the director of purchasing may reject any and all bids. Whenever the estimated value of the property to be sold is less than $500.00, the purchasing director may, without advertising, dispose of such property in the best way for the city. 
b.  In the instance of disposal of vehicles donated to the vocational high school for training the students, the vocational high school may sell all vehicles with a value less than $5,000.00 using sound business judgment. 
(3)  Prior to filling a vacancy for purchasing director/agent the city council shall review the adequacy of the then-existing job description for the position with the city personnel director, shall make such changes as may be appropriate and shall establish such qualifications as it may require. The purchasing director/agent shall be appointed by the city council for a term of three years to serve until a successor be duly appointed and qualified. 
(Ord. No. 1398,  C, 5-5-05; Ord. No. 1508, 12-30-09) 
Sec. 15-5. - Procurement of goods and services; rules and regulations. 
    The purchasing director/agent may from time-to-time issue rules and regulations in looseleaf notebook form to guide city departments in the procurement of goods and services. Those rules and regulations, to the extent not inconsistent with M.G.L.A. c. 30B M.G.L.A. c. 30,  39M, M.G.L.A. c. 149,  44A-44J and M.G.L.A. c. 7,  38A1/2 to 38O, shall be administered by the purchasing director/agent. Within these rules and regulations the purchasing director/agent may delegate to specific positions within other department such duties of the chief procurement officer as may be delegated pursuant to M.G.L.A. c. 30B,  19. Each city department subject to procurement through the office shall comply with the rules and regulations as promulgated. No such rules and regulations shall be effective unless first presented to the standing committee for business systems for comment prior to implementation. 
(Ord. No. 1398,  C, 5-5-05; Ord. No. 1508, 12-30-09) 
Sec. 15-6. - Fiscal accountability. 
    Upon full approval of a purchase order, the city auditor shall certify that there are funds available to satisfy that purchase order. 
(Ord. No. 1508, 12-30-09) 
Sec. 15-7. - Dividing requisition of supplies, materials, etc. for the purpose of evading contract provisions prohibited. 
    It shall constitute official misconduct on the part of any public official or other employee to split or divide any requisition of supplies, materials, equipment or contractual services into two or more units for the purpose of evading the contract provisions of this chapter or to violate the procedure as outlined in any section hereof. 
(Ord. No. 1508, 12-30-09) 
Sec. 15-8. - Acceptance of gratuities prohibited. 
    In accordance with the provisions of M.G.L.A. c. 268A, 2, 3, no gratuities or gifts may be solicited and/or accepted by any person acting in a purchasing capacity on behalf of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1508, 12-30-09) 
Sec. 15-9. - Certification/approval of bills. 
    The purchasing director or his/her designee shall certify or approve all bills incurred by the city for funding and for applicability of the laws. The purchasing director or his/her designee shall forward all bills so approved as soon as possible, to the department for which the purchases were made for verification of the correctness of extensions and total amount and for departmental approval, scheduling and submission to the city auditor for his/her approval for payment. 
(Ord. No. 1508, 12-30-09) 
Sec. 15-10. - Contract procedures. 
    All procurements of $5,000.00 or more must be on an official city contract; the only exception to this rule will be for procurement made by the city off of the state official state contracts issued by the operational services division (OSD). These procurements will be allowed without an official city contract as long as the purchase order has proper documentation of the official state contract, including all provision of the contract. The director of purchasing must certify all purchases are in accordance with the state contract; and the city auditor must certify the availability of funds for the procurement. 
(Ord. No. 1508, 12-30-09) 
Sec. 15-11. - Applicability of chapter provisions. 
    This chapter will apply to all purchases and contracts only insofar as it does not conflict with any prevailing state or federal statute applicable to the city. 
(Ord. No. 1508, 12-30-09) 
Sec. 15-12. - Responsible employer. 
(a)  Purpose. 
(1)  The City Council for the City of Westfield finds and determines that there is a high rate of unemployment in the city, particularly among those employed in the construction industry, and that the effect of this high rate of unemployment has a negative effect upon the city as a whole. 
(2)  The city expends municipal funds for public works and public construction projects within the city and a large portion of said funds are derived from taxes paid by city residents and a large portion of workers employed on such projects do not live within the city. 
(3)  The city would like to establish a preference for hiring Westfield residents and/or Westfield companies who are qualified to perform the work to which the contract relates. 
(b)  Responsibilities. 
(1)  The city establish a preference for local hiring, whenever legally possible, for any public works or public construction project for which the cost is greater than $100,000.00. 
(2)  The city requires that all bidders on public works or public construction projects comply with the provisions of M.G.L.A. c. 149 in terms of prevailing wages, insurance coverage and classification of workers as employees rather than independent contractors for the purposes of treatment for worker's compensation, unemployment taxes, social security taxes and income taxes. 
(3)  The city of Westfield further requires that all bidders on public works or public construction projects comply with all of the provisions of Massachusetts General Laws, as they apply. 
(Ord. No. 1542, 3-3-11) 
Chapter 16 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- City departments, boards and officers,  9. 
Cross reference- Advertising, ch. 3; building and building regulations, ch. 6; fire prevention and protection, ch. 7; planning and development, ch. 13; zoning,  13-1; subdivision regulations,  13-2; traffic and motor vehicles, ch. 17; authority of police to close streets temporarily,  17-6; pedestrians playing in the streets,  17-292; water and sewers, ch. 18. 
State Law reference- Streets, M.G.L.A. cc. 81-92; jurisdiction of city over highways, M.G.L.A. c. 82,  17 et seq.; sidewalks, M.G.L.A. c. 83,  25-29, M.G.L.A. c. 85,  4 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Permit required for certain driveway, right-of-way construction. 
    No driveway or right-of-way shall be constructed to any paved or traveled portion of an accepted city way unless a written permit therefor is issued by the superintendent of the board of public works. 
(Code 1971,  15-1) 
Sec. 16-2. - Application for driveway, right-of-way construction permit. 
    Any person seeking the permit required by section 16-1 shall apply in writing to the board of public works in such form as the board shall from time to time prescribe. 
(Code 1971,  15-2) 
Sec. 16-3. - Inspection previous to driveway, right-of-way construction permit issuance. 
    Before issuing any permit required by section 16-1, the superintendent of the board of public works shall inspect and make proper provision for road drainage, grades, visibility, width and any other matters he deems necessary for proper and safe use of the way. He will then report such inspection with full particulars to the board of public works, so that action can be taken by the board on whether such permit shall be issued. 
(Code 1971,  15-3) 
Sec. 16-4. - Issuance, denial of driveway, right-of-way permit. 
    Permits for driveway and right-of-way construction shall be issued or denied pursuant to the decision of the board of public works by the superintendent of public works. 
(Code 1971,  15-4) 
Sec. 16-5. - Permit required to place or erect fixtures, banners or structures on streets and sidewalks. 
    No person shall place, erect or cause to be placed or erected within or over any sidewalk, street, highway or any way used by the public any fixture, banner, sign or structure unless a permit, issued by the board of public works, in the case of city ways, or by the commonwealth department of public works, in the case of state highways, authorizing such placing or erection has been granted, and is in effect. 
    The board shall develop rules and regulations for the issuance of said permit which shall include, among other things that it feels are required for the administration of this ordinance, instruction, application forms, supplemental materials and numbers of copies. All applications shall be accompanied by a $50.00 filing fee. The board may impose conditions on said permits including regulating their hours, terms, insurance and indemnification. Permits must be re-applied for each calendar year if there are any changes to the fixtures, banners or structures, including but not limited to size, content and location, or if there are any complaints on file with the board of public works. Otherwise the renewal will be automatic upon the payment of the yearly renewal fee to the board of public works. 
    Permits may only be issued for banners for noncommercial public announcements and displays. Prior to the issuance of a permit for a banner, the board shall conduct a public hearing to be held not less than 30 days from the date of the receipt of an application by the department of public works. No less than seven days prior to the date of public hearing the board shall cause notice of the public hearing, specifying the purpose of the public hearing, the location of the proposed banner(s) in question, and the date, time and location of the public hearing, to be posted in accordance with the state's open meeting law, to be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the city (the cost of which shall be borne by the applicant), and mailed to the applicant. The board shall render its decision on an application within 60 days following the close of the public hearing. Failure of the board to render its decision within the required 60 days shall not be deemed as a constructive granting of the permit. There are no local municipal appeals to the board's decision. 
(Code 1971,  15-5; Ord. No. 1533, 11-18-10; Ord. No. 1543, 12-16-10; Ord. No. 1573, 4-19-12) 
Cross reference- Advertising, ch. 3. 
Sec. 16-6. - Obstructing streets and sidewalks with wares, merchandise, etc. 
(a)  No street or sidewalk shall be used for the purpose of the display of any wares, merchandise or other materials or chattel or as a place of resort for amusement, recreation or business except as may be short term and temporarily necessary for the reasonable and expeditious loading or unloading of any of the aforementioned provided that the public right of passage is not obstructed. 
(b)  The chief of police may, upon application in such form as the chief of police may require, grant a temporary permit for such short term activities, subject to such conditions and limitations as the chief of police may require. Persons holding a permit issued pursuant to article II of chapter 9 of this Code are exempt from the conditions of this section. 
(c)  The city council, for certain events, may waive the provisions of this section. 
(d)  The provisions of this section may be enforced through noncriminal disposition pursuant to M.G.L.A. c. 40,  21D. Whoever violates the provisions of this section shall be penalized by a penalty of $25.00 for each offense. Each and every day of the violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1971,  15-6; Ord. No. 1414, 2-15-06; Ord. No. 1488,  A, 12-24-08) 
Cross reference- Licenses, permits and miscellaneous business regulations, ch. 9. 
Sec. 16-7. - Prohibition of placing snow, ice, stormwater and erosion, siltation, sedimentation within the public right-of-way. 
(a)  No person other than the one employed directly or indirectly by the city or by the commonwealth, and while in the performance of necessary public duties, shall at any time place or leave any snow, ice or any debris or other material within the public right-of-way. 
(b)  No work or activity shall be conducted on any property in such a manner so as to: 
(1)  Cause dirt or debris to enter a street, sidewalk or any common sewer, drain or other street drainage structure; 
(2)  Alter or increase the amount of surface stormwater runoff entering a street, sidewalk or any common sewer, drain or other street drainage structure. 
(c)  The board of public works may, upon application in such form as the board may require, grant a permit for such work or activities subject to conditions and limitations as the board may require. 
(d)  The provisions of this section may be enforced through noncriminal disposition pursuant to M.G.L.A. c. 40,  21D. Whoever violates the provisions of this section shall be penalized by a penalty of $25.00 for each offense. Each and every day of the violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1971,  15-7; Ord. No. 1110,  B, 6-3-93; Ord. No. 1161, 6-6-96; Ord. No. 1414, 2-15-06; Ord. No. 1488,  B, 12-24-08) 
Sec. 16-8. - Awnings. 
(a)  Every awning or shade shall be located and constructed so as not to inconvenience pedestrians or motorists. The lowest part of each awning shall be at least seven feet above the sidewalk, and no part thereof shall extend beyond the outer line of the sidewalk. 
(b)  Every awning or shade shall be safely and securely attached to its building. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the building inspector to inspect all awnings and shades from time to time. 
(Code 1971,  15-8-15-10) 
Cross reference- Hanging awnings,  9-26 et seq. 
State Law reference- Signs and other structures projecting into ways, M.G.L.A. c. 85,  8, 9. 
Sec. 16-9. - Removal of structures, property left illegally in streets, sidewalks; costs of same. 
    Any fixture, structure or property which has been erected, placed or left illegally in any street, highway or sidewalk may be moved by or under the direction of a police officer, and at the owner's expense. 
(Code 1971,  15-11) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 6. 
State Law reference- Authority of council to remove material from public ways at owner's expense, M.G.L.A. c. 86,  7. 
Sec. 16-10. - Permit required for moving buildings-Compliance with same. 
    No person shall move, or assist in moving, any building more than ten feet high, over any street or sidewalk in the city which the city is obliged to keep in repair, without the written permit of the board of public works being first obtained. Any person having obtained such a permit shall comply with the restrictions and provisions thereof. 
(Code 1971,  15-12) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 6. 
State Law reference- Moving buildings, M.G.L.A. c. 85,  18. 
Sec. 16-11. - Same-When not granted. 
    No permit to move any building shall be granted by the board of public works when such moving will cause the destruction or injury of any tree, shrub or plant standing in the street, or any tree, shrub or plant which is owned by any person and which projects over the street, unless the written consent of the person on or in front of whose premises such tree, shrub or plant may stand, shall be first obtained. No such permit shall be granted if such removal is apt to injure any trees, shrubs, plants or things of ornament or utility belonging to the public. 
(Code 1971,  15-13) 
Sec. 16-12. - Placing garbage, refuse and trash in streets and on sidewalks. 
(a)  For purposes of this section "trash" shall include, but not be limited to, garbage, rubbish, shavings, paper, filth, any decaying animal vegetable matter, or any other material a person intends to dispose of. 
(b)  No person shall place, or cause to be placed, trash in any street. 
(c)  No person shall place, or cause to be placed, trash on any sidewalk for more than 24 hours. 
(d)  No owner of property shall allow trash to remain on the sidewalk on or abutting his or her property for more than 24 hours. 
(Code 1971,  15-14; Ord. No. 1173, 10-9-96) 
Cross reference- Health and environmental regulations, ch. 8. 
Sec. 16-13. - Ashes, sand in streets and on sidewalks. 
    No person shall place or cause to be placed in any street any ashes, except in such place and manner as shall be directed by the board of public works, except on days designated for rubbish collection by the health department. Sand, or other proper material, may be placed upon a sidewalk or a driveway to prevent its being slippery. 
(Code 1971,  15-15) 
Sec. 16-14. - Removal of snow, ice. 
(a)  The tenant, occupant or owner of any premises abutting on any street in the city, within the limits of which street, and adjoining such premises, there is a sidewalk constructed of or covered with any paved or hardened material other than earth, ashes or gravel, shall, within 24 hours after any snow, sleet or ice has stopped falling, forming or drifting thereon, remove or cause to be removed such snow, sleet or ice. If such cannot be wholly removed, such person shall sprinkle or cause such sidewalk to be sprinkled with sand, sawdust, or another suitable substance so that such sidewalk shall not be slippery, and so that it shall be safe and convenient for public travel. 
(b)  The tenant, occupant or owner of any premises abutting upon any street in the city, within the limits of which street, and adjoining such premises, there is a sidewalk constructed of or covered with earth, ashes or gravel, shall, within 24 hours after snow, sleet or ice ceases to fall, form or drift on such sidewalk, remove or cause to be removed therefrom such snow, sleet or ice so that such sidewalk shall be reasonably safe and convenient for public travel. 
(c)  When any premises abutting on a street is occupied or used by more than one tenant, or by separate families, the owner or agent having charge of such premises shall cause the snow, sleet or ice to be removed as provided in subsections 16-14(a) and (b). 
(d)  No owner of a building, or agent of such owner having the care thereof, shall allow or permit any accumulation of snow or ice thereon which is likely to fall upon a sidewalk or street. Every such person shall erect, or cause to be erected, upon any building which he owns, or of which he has charge, and which is near the line of a sidewalk or street, a barrier or other suitable provision, sufficient to prevent snow and ice from falling from such building upon persons traveling on such sidewalk or street. 
(Code 1971,  15-16-15-19) 
State Law reference- Authority of city relative to removal of snow from sidewalks, M.G.L.A. c. 40,  21(3), (4), M.G.L.A. c. 85,  5. 
Sec. 16-15. - Numbering of buildings. 
    The board of public works may require and regulate the numbering of buildings on or near the lines of public or private ways, and shall, when requested in writing to do so by a majority of the residents or owners of the real estate on or near to the line of any such way, order in writing the owners of such buildings to place on such buildings such numbers as the board may require. The owner of a building upon receipt of such order shall comply therewith within ten days. 
(Code 1971,  15-20) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 6. 
Sec. 16-16. - Extinguishing street lights, lights denoting obstructions, etc. 
    No person, except one having authority to do so, shall extinguish or injure any street light, or extinguish, injure or remove any light placed to denote an obstruction or a defect in any street or sidewalk. 
(Code 1971,  15-21) 
Sec. 16-17. - Permit for cellar doors, coal holes, etc., in streets and sidewalks. 
    The board of public works may license excavations in any sidewalk or other portion of any street or way for cellar doors, passageways, coal holes, passages for light and air, and other necessary purposes, on such terms and conditions as they may deem reasonable. 
(Code 1971,  15-22) 
Sec. 16-18. - Specifications for cellar doors, coal holes, etc., in streets, sidewalks. 
    No cellar door, passageway, coal hole or other passage shall extend more than 31/2 feet into such street or sidewalk, and the same shall be made secure by such suitable platform, grate or other covering, as the board of public works shall determine. 
(Code 1971,  15-23) 
Sec. 16-19. - Leaving cellar doors and other openings from streets, sidewalks open. 
    No person having the legal control of any hatchway, cellar door or other opening from any street or sidewalk into any cellar or basement shall allow the same to remain open when not in immediate use. 
(Code 1971,  15-24) 
Sec. 16-20. - Trenching. 
(a)  Pursuant to the provisions of M.G.L. c. 82A, the city hereby adopts and incorporates by reference the regulations of the Division of Occupational Safety as promulgated under 520 CMR 14.00 as same may be from time to time amended. The building inspector, for private property, and the director of public works, for work within the public right-of-way or public lands, shall serve as the permitting authorities and may promulgate additional regulations consistent with such state enactments. 
(b)  If either the building inspector or the director of public works is notified of an unattended trench during a time in which a permit holder is unavailable, and the inspector or director determines that a police detail is required to make a trench safe for the protection of the general public, the permit holder shall be assessed and be responsible to the city for the cost of providing the police detail. 
(c)  In the event that the city determines that a trench is unsafe, the building inspector or director of public works may take such action to backfill, barricade or cover the trench and the permit holder shall be assessed the costs associated with the action, including any overtime costs associated with the action, including any overtime costs for the building or department of public works employees or the city-authorized contractors. 
(d)  Whenever the permit holder is making multiple trenches over the course of a single project, the city may choose to issue a blanket permit allowing the permit holder to add to the list of trench locations as the permit holder becomes aware that a trench is required. The permit holder shall advise the inspector and/or director of the addition of each new trench. 
(e)  The city shall charge a fee of $50.00 to recover the city's administrative costs incurred in permit processing; but a gas company, as defined in section 1 of chapter 164 or any corporation that is subject to the provisions of chapter 165, 166 or 166A which has already paid a fee in order to attain a permit to excavate a public way in the City of Westfield shall not be responsible for paying an additional fee for the same excavation. 
(f)  If any of the foregoing provisions are held to be invalid such invalidity shall not affect the validity of any remaining provision. 
(Ord. No. 1496, 3-19-09) 
Secs. 16-21-16-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STREETS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-41. - Gates or doors swinging over streets. 
    No person shall allow any gate or door belonging to any premises under his legal control and adjoining any street, to swing on, over or into such street. 
(Code 1971,  15-35) 
State Law reference- Signs and structures projecting into ways, M.G.L.A. c. 85,  8, 9. 
Sec. 16-42. - Scattering glass, nails, etc., in streets. 
    No person shall throw, scatter, drop or place or shall cause to be thrown, scattered, dropped or placed in or upon any street or other public place within the city, any glass, tacks, nails, pieces of metal or any other substance likely to damage any rubber tire. 
(Code 1971,  15-36) 
State Law reference- Throwing glass in streets, M.G.L.A. c. 265,  32. 
Sec. 16-43. - Street names generally. 
    All streets or ways laid out shall be named by the city council. 
(Code 1971,  15-37) 
State Law reference- Street names, M.G.L.A. c. 85,  3-3B. 
Sec. 16-44. - Changing street names. 
    The city council, by a two-thirds vote of the whole council, may change the name of any public street or way in the city. Whenever the council proposes to change any such name, it shall, before final action, give public notice and hold a hearing on such matter. 
(Code 1971,  15-38) 
Secs. 16-45-16-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - EXCAVATIONS AND OBSTRUCTIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1413,  A-P, adopted Feb. 15,2 006, amended div. 2 in its entirety and enacted similar provisions as set out herein. The former div. 2 derived from Code 1971,  15-44-15-48 and 15-50-15-52; and Ord. No. 782, adopted May 18, 1978. 

Sec. 16-66. - Public way excavation; permit required. 
    No work (except the commencement of emergency repair work in accordance with section 16-70) in or under a public way shall commence until the applicant shall have applied for, in accordance with section 16-67, and obtained from the superintendent of public works, a street opening permit. All work shall be done in accordance with (i) all applicable laws and regulations, (ii) all of the provisions of this division, (iii) any conditions contained in the street opening permit, and (iv) such reasonable supplemental instructions not inconsistent with the foregoing as the superintendent of public works or his designee may from time to time issue. A permit holder shall cause to be restored those portions of a public way disturbed by the permit holder to as good a permanent condition, in the reasonable judgment of the superintendent of public works or his designee, as they were in when permit holder made application thereunder. 
    No person or entity may perform any work (including street opening work or emergency repair work) in or under a public way unless it is a permit holder and (i) is a municipal department or public utility or their respective officers or employees (ii) is the holder of a current and valid public works construction license (licensed contractor), or (iii) has engaged such a holder and such holder performs all such street opening work or emergency repair work as agent of permit holder. 
(Ord. No. 1413,  A, 2-15-06) 
Sec. 16-67. - Application procedure. 
    The applicant shall file on forms designated by the superintendent of public works a completed and signed application at the office of the department of public works each time it desires to perform street opening work. The application shall be accompanied by any and all plans, certificates, certificates of insurance and other items specified in the application or reasonably requested by the superintendent of public works. If the applicant does not intend to perform the street opening work itself, it must in the application designate a licensed contractor to perform as its agent. The application shall also be accompanied by the application fee and the refundable deposit. 
    The department shall promptly review the application and make written recommendations concerning approval to the superintendent of public works and, if appropriate, shall include recommendations concerning permit conditions and supplemental instructions. 
    The superintendent of public works shall make a prompt determination on the application taking into account the following and such other facts as it may reasonably consider: 
(1)  The recommendation of the department; 
(2)  The reason for the street opening work; 
(3)  Whether the street is recently constructed or repaved; 
(4)  Whether there are other reasonable means adequate to accomplish the purpose for which the street opening permit is sought. 
    If the application is considered favorably, a street opening permit containing such conditions and supplemental instructions as the superintendent of public works reasonably deems appropriate shall promptly issue. If the application is not favorably considered, the superintendent of public works shall communicate in writing to applicant the reasons its application was not favorably considered. 
(Ord. No. 1413,  B, 2-15-06) 
Sec. 16-68. - Refundable deposit and account. 
    A refundable deposit to secure proper restoration of a public way after street opening work is required before the permit is issued in accordance with section 16-77. In the event that the applicant has provided an adequate bond acceptable to the city pursuant to a city council issued right-of-way permit, the superintendent of public works may waive this requirement. 
    Following notice that final permanent repairs to the public way have been completed, the superintendent of public works will make a final inspection. Once the superintendent of public works or his designee has concluded that permanent repair work is satisfactory and that applicant has no other uncured defaults under street opening permits, the unexpended balance of the deposit serving as security for the street opening permit related to the inspected work shall be released. 
    All refundable deposits that an applicant submits for street opening permits shall be held by the city in one account which shall be designated as the refundable deposit account. Applicants upon request may receive periodic reports as to the balance standing within this account. Should a deposit associated with a specific permit be insufficient to secure the proper repair of a public way following a default by the permit holder, the awarding authority without limitation to other remedies available to it can deduct the cost of the proper repair from applicant's refundable deposit for the purpose of funding the proper repairs. To the extent required by chapter 164 of the General Law applicable to gas companies, the provisions of this section and section 16-69 hereafter shall not apply to gas companies which affirmatively claim exemption in the application for street opening permits. 
(Ord. No. 1413,  C, 2-15-06) 
Sec. 16-69. - Fee and deposit changes; municipal exemption. 
    In extraordinary situations where extensive installation or renewal of utility lines overburden the normal capacity of the municipal departments to conduct inspections, the superintendent of public works can, after notice to permit holder, or as a condition of the permit, elect to treat all inspections as after-hours inspections and bill permit holder accordingly. Applicants which are municipal departments are exempt from payment of all fees and deposits hereunder. Public utilities to the extent exempted by state law are exempt from payment of fees except the application fee. 
(Ord. No. 1413,  D, 2-15-06) 
Sec. 16-70. - Emergency repair procedure. 
    If the conditions for emergency repair work exists, then an applicant after giving oral, faxed or electronic notice to the police and public works department may commence street opening work. All such emergency repair work shall be done in strict compliance with this division except for compliance with any notice provision inconsistent with such emergency action. 
    On the business day following the commencement of emergency repair work, the applicant shall file with the superintendent of public works (i) a written statement setting forth in detail the facts and circumstances constituting the conditions for emergency repair work, (ii) an application for a street opening permit covering the street opening work already commenced in accordance with section 16-67, (iii) the filing fee and required refundable deposit. If all of the materials such as plans, etc., are not then available to applicant, applicant will supply them as soon as available. Superintendent of public works will promptly process the application and grant the street opening permit with such conditions and supplemental instructions as it may reasonably require. 
(Ord. No. 1413,  D, 2-15-06) 
Sec. 16-71. - Hold harmless; insurance. 
    Each permit issued by the superintendent of public works shall contain as a condition that the permit holder does agree to indemnify and hold harmless the city, its officers, agents and employees, of and from any claim for damages by any party injured, inconvenienced or otherwise harmed during the course of the excavation, the work or restoration of the way up through the final inspection and approval by the superintendent of public works or his designee. 
    The permit holder and/or each licensed contractor shall acquire and continuously maintain while it possesses any street opening permits liability insurance coverage on all personnel and equipment to be used in the street opening work which insurance is to be with insurance companies licensed to do business in the commonwealth and shall contain the following coverages and be in the following minimum amounts: 
    Commercial general liability insurance -Including operation, independent contractors, complete operations for a period of one year from completing the street opening work, XCU hazards, broad form property damage and personal injury. 
General aggregate ..... $1,500,000.00 
Products and complete operations: 
Aggregate ..... 1,000,000.00 
Each occurrence ..... 1,000,000.00 
Combined single limit ..... 1,000,000.00 
Automobile liability insurance-Covers owned, nonowned and hired vehicles 
Bodily injury liability, each person ..... 500,000.00 
Each accident ..... $1,000,000.00 
Property damage liability, each accident ..... 50,000.00 
Combined single limit ..... 1,000,000.00 
Worker's compensation and employers liability 
Each accident ..... 100,000.00 
Disease-Policy limit ..... 100,000.00 
Disease-Each employee ..... 100,000.00 
    Certificates of insurance shall provide for at least 30 days' notice to the city of cancellation or material change. The name of the city shall be listed as an additional insured on the certificate of insurance. 
(Ord. No. 1413,  F, 2-15-06) 
Sec. 16-72. - Licensed contractors. 
    Any contractor or other person or entity that wishes to perform work on a public way and which is not either a city department or a public utility (including their respective officers or employees) must be licensed by the board of public works. Application for a public works construction license must be made by application filed with the board of public works on a yearly basis each December. 
(Ord. No. 1413,  G, 2-15-06) 
Sec. 16-73. - Terms of the street opening permit. 
(1)  Term of permit. All street opening permits shall be valid for 30 days and, upon written request to the superintendent of public works, renewable for an additional 30 days. Permits can be revoked by the superintendent of public works if the applicant is in default. 
(2)  Inspections. Inspections shall take place at the following events: 
(a)  Prior to backfilling the trench; 
(b)  Following completion of temporary patch placement; 
(c)  During permanent patch window; 
(d)  Following completion of permanent patch placement. 
    Permit holder or contractor will notify the superintendent of public works or his designee when an inspection is desired an coordinate the timing of such inspection. 
(3)  Working hours. Except in emergency situations, street opening work will occur between 7:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. The permit holder must give notice of the intended street opening work 72 hours in advance to the superintendent of public works and, unless the requirement for a police detail is waived by the police chief of the city, must arrange for an pay for a police detail to be present throughout the period of time that street opening work is conducted. 
(4)  Dig-Safe. The permit holder shall in accordance with all current laws of the commonwealth, notify the gas and electric light department and any public utilities 72 hours in advance of making any excavation in a street. Such notification shall be made by means of obtaining a DIG-SAFE number. Said number shall be provided on the street opening permit application. The permit shall not be issued until this information is provided. 
(5)  Existing utilities. Before starting any excavation, the permit holder or contractor must confer with the gas and electric light department and any public utilities to obtain information from each as to the horizontal and vertical locations of existing utilities and other conditions that may affect the excavation. The permit holder or contractor shall not interfere with any existing utility without written consent. If it becomes necessary to relocate an existing utility, this shall be done by its owner and the cost of such work shall be borne by the permit holder. The permit holder or contractor shall inform itself as to the existence and location of all underground utilities and protect the same against damage. 
(6)  Protection of existing lines and structures. The permit holder or contractor shall adequately support and protect by timbers, sheeting, etc. All pipes, conduits, poles, wires, cables or other appurtenances which may be in any way affected by the excavation work and shall do everything necessary to support, sustain and protect them under, over, along or across such work area. The excavation work shall be performed and conducted in such a manner that it shall not interfere with access to fire stations, fire hydrants, water gates, underground vaults, catch basins or any other public structure. 
(7)  Adjoining property. The permit holder or contractor shall, at all times and at its own expense, preserve and protect from injury any adjoining property by providing proper foundations and shall take such other precautions as may be necessary for this purpose. The permit holder or contractor shall at all time sand at its own expense shore up and protect all buildings, walls, fences, trees and other property likely to be damaged during the progress of the street opening work and shall be responsible for all damages to public or private property or streets resulting from its failure to properly protect and carry out said work. The permit holder or contractor shall not remove, even temporarily, any trees or shrubs which exist in planting strip areas without first obtaining the consent of the superintendent of public works. 
(8)  Damaged trees. In the event a tree is either accidentally destroyed by the permit holder or contractor or is authorized for removal by the superintendent of public works, the permit holder or contractor shall remove the tree, stump and debris from the work site, and replace the tree with a superintendent of public works approved species with a minimum caliper of two inches in the identical location. 
(9)  Pedestrian crossings, open trenches. The permit holder or contractor shall, where possible, maintain safe crossings for two lanes of vehicle traffic at all public intersections as well as safe crossings for pedestrians at intervals of not more than 300 feet. If any excavation is made across a public way, it shall be made in sections to assure maximum safe crossing for vehicles and pedestrians. An open trench may not exceed 300 feet. If the public way is not wide enough to hold the excavated material for temporary storage, the material shall be immediately removed from the location. 
(10)  Traffic. The permit holder or contractor shall take appropriate measures to assure that during the performance of the street opening work, so far as practicable, normal traffic conditions shall be maintained at all times so as to cause as little inconvenience as possible to the occupants of the adjoining property and to the general public. Superintendent of public works with the approval of the police chief may permit the closing of streets and walks to all traffic for a period of time. Unless the requirement for police detail is waived by the police chief, the permit holder shall engage a police detail to maintain traffic control and public safety at the project site while street opening work is in progress. 
(11)  Temporary repairs. At the end of each day, all trenches must be plated if repair work is not completed and/or back-filled, compacted and temporarily patched on the day repair work is completed. No open unplated trenches are permitted overnight and work in plated trenches must be continually prosecuted to completion to minimize the time trenches are plated. 
(12)  Noise. The permit holder or contractor shall conform to the requirements of the city noise ordinance. 
(13)  Debris and litter. All debris and litter remaining from the street opening work site shall be removed by the permit holder or contractor in a timely manner. 
(14)  Restoration of pavement markings. All permanent pavement markings (crosswalks, center lines, fog lines) which are damaged during street opening work shall be restored in kind by and at the expense of the permit holder. 
(15)  Lawn surfaces and plantings. All lawn surfaces which are disturbed during street opening work shall be replaced with sod or six inches of screened loam, lime, fertilized and reseeded with good quality lawn seed. Any areas containing plantings shall be restored to their original condition with the same or similar plantings. 
(16)  Erosion control. The permit holder shall be responsible for all erosion control and for obtaining any necessary permits from the conservation commission. The permit holder or contractor shall protect drainage structures from siltation by whatever means required including, but not limited to, the installation of hay bales and/or filter fabric. In the event that a drainage structure becomes damaged from the siltation as a result of the street opening work, the permit holder or contractor shall clean the structure before completing the temporary patch. 
(Ord. No. 1413,  H, 2-15-06) 
Sec. 16-74. - Required construction techniques. 
    All street opening work and materials used therein must conform to the Massachusetts Highway Department's Standard Specifications for Highway and Bridges 1995 Edition, and with the Americans with Disabilities Act and the architectural access board regulations as currently in effect. In addition, the following specific requirements also apply. Exceptions to these requirements may be made in the discretion of the superintendent of public works or his designee at the time that the street opening work is in progress. 
(1)  Excavation. Existing pavement shall be cut in neat, true lines along the area of the proposed excavation. Unstable pavement shall be removed over cave-outs and breaks and the subgrade treated as the main trench. Pavement edges shall be trimmed to a vertical face and neatly aligned with the center line of the trench. Cut-outs beyond the limits of the trench lines must be normal or aligned parallel to the center line of the trench. Excavations shall be made in open cut. Trenches and excavation shall be braced and sheathed in accordance with the requirements of the Occupation Safety and Health Act (OSHA). Sections of bituminous or cement concrete sidewalks shall be removed to the nearest scoreline or approved cut edge. 
(2)  Back-filling and compaction. Excavations shall be filled with approved backfill. Approved backfill consists of either controlled-density fill, suitable excavated material or gravel meeting M 1.03.0 or M 1.03.1 of the standard specifications. The superintendent of public works or his designee shall select which of these three to use in the excavation. Suitable excavated materials shall mean previously excavated granular material but which does not include blacktop, clay, silt, organic material, concrete, roots, boulders or stones larger than four inches in diameter. If the hole is to be filled with suitable excavated material, a backfill course shall be placed in approximately 12-inch lifts of maximum compaction to four inches below asphalt grade. A base course consisting of four inches of processed gravel or equivalent (i.e. suitable excavated material containing no stones larger than one and one-half inch in diameter) shall then be placed on tope of the backfill course. The backfill and base course shall be compacted to no less than 95 percent of maximum dry density as determined by the modified Proctor Test in accordance with ASTM 1557 method D. The permit holder if directed by the superintendent of public works or his designee will retain at its expense, a professionally qualified geotechnical consultant to perform this test. The results of this test shall be given to the department of public works. 
If controlled-density fill is used as back-fill material, it must contain a minimum of 250 pounds of class F fly ash or high air (25 percent plus) and be self-leveling. It must be type 1E or 2E (very flowable). Flowable fill is to be batched at a ready mix plant and is to be used at a high or very high slump (one inch to 12 inches). In lieu of the slump test, a six-foot long, three-inch diameter tube may be filled to the top and then slowly raised. The diameter of the resulting "pancake" may be measured and the range of the diameter shall be nine inches to 14 inches. It shall be flowable, require no vibration and after it is placed excavatable by hand tools and/or small machines. 
The ingredients shall comply with the following: 
Portland cement AASHTO M85 
Fly ash AASHTO M295 class F 
Sand M4.02.02-ASTM C33 sand 
Air M4.02.05 
Type 1E and 2E must meet the following requirements: 
Compressive 28 days 90 days 
Strength 30-80 psi 100 psi ma. 
Slump 10-12 inches 
Air 1-30 percent 
If controlled-density fill is used as back-fill material, it must fill the excavation to immediately below asphalt grade. The contractor must then plate the excavation with a heavy duty steel plate adequate to carry heavy traffic and wait twenty four hours for the CDF to cure prior to applying the permanent patch. 
If an excavation is back-filled with controlled density fill in accordance with ordinance, then a temporary patch need not be installed but a permanent patch may be installed immediately. Permanent patches installed over controlled-density fill shall consist of four inches of bituminous concrete applied in a two-and-one-half-inch base course and a one-and-one-half inch top course of bituminous concrete all installed in accordance with this ordinance for cement concrete surfaces, see [subsection] 5., below. 
(3)  Temporary patches. 
a.  Bituminous concrete. Following proper compaction, a temporary patch which shall be the thickness of the existing asphalt pavement or a minimum of four inches, whichever is greater, shall be applied. It shall consist of either cold patch or bituminous concrete plant-mixed hot asphalt aggregate. 
b.  Temporary patch to be maintained for one year. A temporary patch that has been back-filled and compacted shall be maintained by the permit holder or contractor so that the patched surface and the surrounding area remain a single smooth unbroken plane for a period of time no shorter than one year after placement of the temporary patch. 
(4)  Permanent patches. Except when installed over controlled-density fill as described in subsection (2) above, permanent patches shall be installed not less than 12 nor more than 18 months from the date of installation of the temporary patch. Upon request by the permit holder or contractor, the superintendent of public works will inspect the temporary patch and determine if final settlement of the trench has occurred and will notify the permit holder or contractor within seven days of the inspection whether the permanent patch can be installed. Public utilities or municipal departments may schedule permanent patches to replace all temporary patches without receiving prior approval from the superintendent of public works but must give the superintendent of public works or his designee not less than 72 hours' prior notice. 
A permanent patch shall consist of one of the following: (a) cold planing the temporary patch to a depth of one and one-half inches and then installing a minimum of one and one-half inches of top course of bituminous concrete, or (b) the excavation of the temporary patch in a bituminous concrete public way and replacement of this material with any additional processed gravel needed and two and one-half inches of base course and one and one-half inches of tope [top] course of bituminous concrete or (c) application of the infra-red process to the temporary patch or (d) the certification by the superintendent of public works or his designee that the temporary patch in his reasonable judgment meets fully the standard of a permanent patch and thus requires no further work. 
a.  Certification. If a permit holder seeks to qualify a temporary patch as a permanent patch, it must make the application for inspection set out above and specify in its request for certification. The superintendent of public works will notify the permit holder within 30 days of the request whether the temporary patch has been certified as a permanent patch. If it is not so certified, the permit holder shall forthwith cause a permanent patch utilizing one of the three remaining methods set out above to be utilized. 
b.  Newly paved roads. On newly paved roads, the superintendent of public works may require in addition to the placement of the permanent patch, that the permanent patch shall be treated by a process (infra-red, microwave or equivalent) that will ensure that the permanent patch is integrated into the existing bituminous surface in a seamless manner. No permit shall be issued for street openings of newly paved roads for a period of five years after the new pavement is installed, except in the case of an emergency as defined in this division. 
c.  Final inspection of permanent patch. Following completion of the permanent patch, the permit holder or contractor shall give notice thereof to the superintendent of public works or his designee who shall inspect the permanent patch. If the superintendent of public works or his designee is satisfied that the road has been restored to as good a condition as existed prior to the street opening work, he shall so note on the street opening permit and any refundable deposit securing that street opening work shall be refunded promptly to applicant. If the awarding authority representative determines that the permit holder is in default, the awarding authority may proceed in accordance with section 16-76, Remedies. 
(5)  Special rules for situations not otherwise specified. In the event that the surface to be cut and excavated is made of a material not delineated herein, the permit holder shall propose a method consistent with the goals and purposes of this division. No work shall be performed until approval by the superintendent of public works or his designee. Work shall thereafter be performed only in accordance with the approved methods. 
(6)  Shoulders. Suitable excavated material shall be placed in layers not to exceed six inches in depth and compacted shoulders shall be reconstructed to their existing condition and either loamed with six inches of loam, limed, fertilized and seeded with roadside grass mix or covered with four inches of wood chips as directed by superintendent of public works or his designee. 
(7)  Sidewalks. Any excavation in a concrete or bituminous concrete sidewalk shall require that the entire sidewalk area containing the trench be replaced. Any concrete sidewalk section that is excavated or damaged by the excavation must be replaced in its entirety. Suitable excavated material or gravel shall be placed in layers not to exceed six inches in depth and compacted. All sidewalk areas will be installed by the permit holder or contractor in conformance with the ADA and the architectural access board regulations currently in effect. Bituminous concrete sidewalks shall have two courses (two inches of binder and one inch of top) of bituminous concrete plant-mixed hot asphalt aggregate applied to and rolled to create a pavement surface consistent with the adjacent bituminous concrete surface. Concrete sidewalks shall have four inches of poured concrete applied to finish grade. The concrete shall be placed in alternate slabs 9 meters in length except as otherwise ordered. The slabs shall be separated by transverse preformed expansion joint filler 13 millimeters in thickness. Concrete driveway openings shall have six inches of poured concrete applied to finish grade. Preformed expansion joints will be installed against buildings, walls, steps, foundations or existing concrete block or brick. 
(8)  Curb and berm. Any curbing or berm which is damaged or removed as part of the street opening work shall be properly replaced in kind. The use of cast-in-place concrete curbing is prohibited. All salvageable granite curb that is removed from the public way and is excess is the property of the city and shall be delivered to the department of public works by the permit holder or contractor. 
(9)  Wheelchair ramps. Existing wheelchair ramps which are damaged or removed under street opening work shall be reconstructed in kind and in conformance with the ADA and the architectural access board regulations that are currently in effect. 
(10)  Curb cuts. Any curb cut within a public way cannot exceed the following dimensions unless specifically approved by the superintendent of public works: 
Single-family dwelling-16 feet; 
Multifamily dwelling-18 feet; 
Two-family dwelling-18 feet; 
Commercial property-24 feet. 
Driveway entrances into public ways must butt into and not overlap the edge of the existing roadway hardened surface. The driveway must be graded in such a manner to n [no] ponding of water occurs within the public way and in accordance with the architectural access board regulations. Driveways shall not be located on small radius curves and shall be positioned as to provide maximum sight distance and safety. 
(Ord. No. 1413,  I, 2-15-06) 
Sec. 16-75. - Suspension and revocation. 
    The superintendent of public works or his designee may, if he believes a default has occurred, suspend immediately for up to 21 days a street opening permit by communicating such suspension to any of the permit holder, licensed contractor or any of their respective representatives at the job site. 
    The superintendent of public works may revoke a street opening permit granted hereunder after notice and hearing if he shall reasonably determine that a default has occurred. Permit holder shall be given not less than five days' prior written notice of the time and place of the hearing and shall have the opportunity at the hearing to present evidence. Any person aggrieved by the decision of the superintendent of public works may appeal such decision to the board of public works which after hearing the evidence shall affirm or reverse the decision of the superintendent of public works. The decision of the board of public works shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 1413,  J, 2-15-06) 
Sec. 16-76. - Remedies. 
    If a permit holder or licensed contractor shall be in default the superintendent of public works may: 
(1)  Suspend or revoke the street opening permit as provided above. If the street opening work has commenced but is not completed at the time of a suspension or revocation, the superintendent of public works can order the street opening work to be completed by another licensed contractor the cost of which is paid fro from the permit holder's refundable deposit account or by the permit holder if the refundable deposit is insufficient or does not exist. 
(2)  Recommend to the board of public works the revocation or nonrenewal of the licensed contractor's public works construction license. Should such a recommendation be made, the contractors shall be given written notice of the recommendation and given an opportunity to be heard by the board of public works prior to board action on the superintendent's recommendation. The decision of the board of public works is final. 
(Ord. No. 1413,  K, 2-15-06)

    Private ways regularly traveled by the general public for access to adjoining public ways shall be subject to the requirements of this division.

    Any person granted a permit pursuant to this division shall notify the chief of police and obtain a police officer to supervise the safety of travelers or a written waiver of the necessity for a police officer from the chief of police. Said notice must be received by the chief of police no later than 4:00 p.m. On the day prior to the commencement of the scheduled work.

Sec. 16-80. - Unlawful street cut, obstruction. 
    Persons who, without the permit required by this division, proceed with work requiring such a permit shall be punished by a fine of $300.00. Each day of violation shall be deemed to be a new offence. 
(Ord. No. 1413,  O, 2-15-06)

Sec. 16-96. - Recordation of plans; record book to have index. 
    All orders laying out, relocating, altering or discontinuing any street, highway or private way, or part thereof, together with a plan thereof, shall be recorded by the city clerk in a book kept for that sole purpose. Such record book shall have an index. 
(Code 1971,  15-58) 
Sec. 16-97. - Street width required; exception. 
    No street or highway shall be laid out by the city of a width less than three rods except as provided by section 16-99 and streets with single access/exit shall have not less than 24 feet of paved roadway. 
(Code 1971,  15-59) 
Sec. 16-98. - Grading, surfacing requirements. 
    Subject to the provisions of M.G.L.A. c. 41,  77, so far as the same are applicable, no street or highway shall be laid out until it conforms to a grade determined by the board of public works and until the roadway has been surfaced with at least 12 inches of gravel or other equally good material so as, in the judgement of the board of public works, to be safe and convenient for public travel, and the board has filed with the council a certificate that the provisions of this section have been complied with except as provided by sections 16-99 and 16-100. 
(Code 1971,  15-60) 
Sec. 16-99. - Waiver of width and grading requirements under unusual conditions. 
    The city council may, in unusual cases where conditions seem to warrant such action, upon petition of the owners of more than one-half of the frontage of all lands fronting upon any street or way, or any portion thereof, by a three-fourths vote of its membership, waive the requirements of this chapter as to such street or way, or portion thereof. However, in case of section 16-98, suitable provision shall be made in connection with such waiver for the assessment of betterments in accordance with the general laws relating thereto. 
(Code 1971,  15-61) 
Sec. 16-100. - Acceptance of streets; special benefit. 
    Whenever a petition for the acceptance of any street or way signed by the owners of more than one-half of the frontage of all lands fronting upon any street or way, or any portion thereof, is presented to the city council, the city council may accept such street or way or any portion thereof as a public street of the city if in such petition it is agreed that the land of each of the abutters is enhanced in value an amount equal to its proportionate share of the cost of improvements, and that the abutters receive special benefit other than the general advantage to the community. 
(Code 1971,  15-62) 
Sec. 16-101. - Petitioners to pay cost of surveying, etc., deposit. 
    Persons who are petitioning to have a street, highway or private way laid out, relocated or altered shall, in all cases, first pay the costs of surveying, giving notices, making plans and other expenses of such proceedings. Each such petition shall be accompanied by a deposit made with the board of public works sufficient, in its estimation, to pay such costs. Any unexpended balance thereof shall be returned to the petitioners. 
(Code 1971,  15-63) 
Sec. 16-102. - Order for betterment assessment. 
    The city council, upon being informed of the total expenditures for the purpose of section 16-101, shall, thereupon, cause an order to be passed providing for a betterment assessment equal to the total amount expended under the provisions of M.G.L.A. c. 80. 
(Code 1971,  15-64) 
Sec. 16-103. - Acceptance of streets. 
    No street or way that has been constructed by private interests in the city shall be deemed eligible for review by the city's board of public works for certification for acceptance of the street or way as a public way in the city system of streets until two years after its normal completion and for a period of not less than two years of public use. The petition for acceptance of any street or way as a public way in the city's system of public streets shall have originated with residents of the street and the date of the petition shall be evidence of the beginning of the two-year period for the public use of the street or way. 
(Ord. No. 884, 12-15-83) 
Sec. 16-104. - Street appropriation; improvement. 
    Upon acceptance of a street in accordance with the provisions of section 16-103, and upon an appropriation being made by the city council of an amount sufficient in the opinion of the board of public works to construct and lay out such street or portion thereof in a manner to comply with all the requirements of this chapter, the board shall cause such changes, repairs and alterations to be made as will place such street or portion thereof in such condition as is required by this article. 
(Code 1971,  15-65) 
Sec. 16-105. - Laying out, relocation, etc., to be supervised by board of public works; exception. 
    Surveying, laying out, relocating or altering streets shall be done under the supervision of the board of public works, except when a street or highway is laid out, relocated or altered in accordance with sections 16-99 and 16-100. 
(Code 1971,  15-66) 
Sec. 16-106. - Monuments to be erected at terminal and angles. 
    The city council shall cause permanent bound stones or monuments to be erected, as provided by statute, at the terminal and angles of all streets or ways laid out or altered by the council. 
(Code 1971,  15-67)

Sec. 16-107. - Temporary repairs on private ways. 
    Subject to the following, the board of public works, by a majority vote, may authorize repairs to be made on private ways: 
(1)  Such repairs must be limited to grading, surfacing and/or resurfacing and may include installation or repair of drainage. 
(2)  Such repairs are required by public necessity. 
(3)  If such way has been opened to public use for a period of 50 years or more. 
(4)  A petition signed by at least 51 percent of the abutters of such way is presented to the board of public works requesting such repairs. 
(5)  Betterment charges shall not be assessed to said abutters. 
(6)  The city shall not be liable for any damages caused by such repairs. 
(Ord. No. 879,  15-68, 10-20-83) 
DIVISION 4. - STORMWATER MANAGEMENT 

Sec. 16-108. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions describe the meaning of the terms used in this division:
