No. 1657 , 11-17-16; Ord. No. 1690, 10-4-18; Ord. No. 1703, 4-4-19) 
Sec. 17-74. - Obedience to yield signs. 
(a)  Every driver of a vehicle or other conveyance approaching an intersection of ways, where there exists facing him an official sign bearing the word "Yield," such sign having been erected in accordance with the written approval of the department of public works of the commonwealth and such approval being in effect, shall surrender to oncoming traffic his right to enter the intersection until such time as he has brought his vehicle or other conveyance to a complete stop at a point between the yield sign and the nearer line of the street intersection; provided, however, that this requirement to stop before entering the intersection shall not apply when a driver approaching a yield sign can enter the intersection in safety without causing interference to approaching traffic. 
(b)  This section shall not apply when the traffic is otherwise directed by an officer or by a lawful traffic regulating sign, signal or device or as provided in section 17-81. 
(c)  In accordance with the foregoing, the erection and maintenance of official yield signs are authorized to face: 
Holyoke Road, northeastbound drivers at North Elm Street. 
Meadow Street, northbound drivers on Union Avenue (Great River Bridge, northbound). 
(Code 1971,  16-56.1; Ord. No. 1597, 5-1-14) 
Sec. 17-75. - Flashing warning beacon. 
    Flashing warning beacons shall be erected as designated in this section. 
East Mountain Road, flashing yellow pedestrian crossing sign at the Western Massachusetts Hospital. 
This is to replace an existing sign. 
Shaker Road, northbound traffic shall obey the flashing warning beacon at the intersection of Little River Street. 
(Code 1971,  16-57; Ord. No. 1441, 2-28-07) 
Sec. 17-76. - Underpass or overpasses; intersections with islands. 
    At any junction or crossings of ways where the roadway grades have been separated and where the ways are connected by ramps and at any intersection of ways in which there are traffic islands, drivers of vehicles shall proceed only as indicated by official signs, signals or markings. 
(Code 1971,  16-58) 
Sec. 17-77. - Emerging from alley, driveway or garage; yield right-of-way. 
    The driver of a vehicle emerging from a private road, driveway or garage shall stop such vehicle immediately prior to driving upon the sidewalk area extending across such driveway or garage, and where no such sidewalk exists, the stop shall be made at the building or property line as the case may be, and upon entering any city street shall yield the right-of-way to vehicles approaching on such street. 
(Code 1971,  16-59) 
Sec. 17-78. - Care in starting, stopping, turning or backing. 
    The driver of any vehicle, before starting, stopping, turning from a direct line or backing, shall first see that such movement can be made in safety. If such movement cannot be made in safety, or if it interferes unduly with the normal movement of other traffic, such driver shall wait for a more favorable opportunity to make such movement. 
(Code 1971,  16-59.1) 
Sec. 17-79. - Driving on road surfaces under construction or repair. 
    No operator shall enter upon the road surface of any street or highway or section thereof when, by reason of construction, surface treatment, maintenance or the like, or because of some unprotected hazard, such road surface is closed to travel, and one or more signs, lights or signals have been erected to indicate that all or part of the road surface of the street or highway is not to be used, or when so advised by an officer, watchman, member of a street or highway crew or employee of the city, either audibly or by signals. 
(Code 1971,  16-60) 
Sec. 17-80. - Driving on sidewalks. 
    The driver of a vehicle shall not drive upon any sidewalk except at a permanent or temporary driveway. 
(Code 1971,  16-61) 
Sec. 17-81. - Rights and duties of driver in funeral or other processions. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of each driver in a funeral or other procession to keep as near to the right edge of the roadway as is feasible, and to follow the vehicle ahead as closely as is practicable and safe. 
(b)  At an intersection where a traffic-control signal is operating, the driver of the first vehicle in a funeral or other procession shall be the only one required to stop for a red or red and yellow indication. 
(c)  At an intersection where a lawful stop sign exists, the driver of the first vehicle in a funeral or other procession shall be the only one required to stop before proceeding through the intersection. 
(Code 1971,  16-62) 
State Law reference- Funeral processions, M.G.L.A. c. 14A.

Speed limits shall be posted by the department of public works and shall be strictly enforced by the city police department.

(c)  Thirty miles per hour. 
Radisson Lane.

Sec. 17-86. - Rotary traffic. 
    Vehicular traffic shall move only in a rotary counterclockwise direction within the area: 
(1)  Bounded by Main Street, Elm Street, Court Street and Broad Street. 
(2)  At the intersection of Parker Avenue, Pochassic Street and Montgomery Street, vehicular traffic shall move about a traffic island which is within the intersection. Such island is circular with a radius of about 25 feet and its center is located on the southeasterly extension of the southerly location line of Parker Avenue, and its center also is about 62 feet distant from a stone monument marking the intersection of the southerly location line of Parker Avenue with the westerly location line of Pochassic Street, the area included within the intersection of Parker Avenue, Pochassic Street and Montgomery Street more particularly bounded and described as follows: 
Beginning at the aforementioned stone monument at the intersection of the southerly location line of Parker Avenue with the westerly location line of Pochassic Street; running thence southerly about 114 feet along the line of Pochassic Street to an angle point; thence southeasterly about 50 feet across Pochassic Street to a point in the easterly line of Pochassic Street; thence northeasterly about 165 feet along the easterly line of Pochassic Street and its extension to a point at the intersection of the northerly line of Montgomery Street with the extension of the easterly line of Pochassic Street; thence northwesterly about 170 feet along the northerly line of Montgomery Street to a point; thence southwesterly and at right angles to Montgomery Street about 53 feet across Montgomery Street to an angle point in the southerly line of Montgomery Street; thence southerly about 82 feet along Montgomery Street and across the easterly end of Parker Avenue to the stone monument marking the point of beginning. 
All vehicular traffic shall move counter-clockwise in a "Rotary Pattern" between the curblines and the "No Parking" restrictions shall prevail within the aforedescribed area bounding the intersection of Parker Avenue, Pochassic Street and Montgomery Street. 
(Code 1971,  16-66)

Sec. 17-90. - Penalties for restricted vehicles. 
    No vehicle shall operate or be permitted to operate on any way owned or controlled by the city in violation of M.G.L.A. ch. 90 sec. 19 and 19A. At no time shall any vehicle operate or be permitted to operate, over a posted bridge, while exceeding such posting, as defined in ch. 85 sec. 34 and 35. 
    Violation of this section shall result in a penalty to be consistent with M.G.L.A. ch. 90,  19, 19A and 20, also ch. 85,  34 and 35. 
    Police officers appointed as public weighers or deputy public weighers shall be empowered to enforce the provisions of this article. Portable scales may be used as provided for in M.G.L.A. chapter 90 section 19A. 
(Ord. No. 1265, 11-2-00) 
Sec. 17-91. - Motorized scooters-Regulation of operation. 
(a)  No person shall operate a motorized scooter on or upon any public sidewalk. 
(b)  No person shall operate a motor scooter on a public way or private way to which the public has a right of access except as authorized and in compliance with M.G.L.A. c. 90,  1E. 
(c)  A police officer, upon observing a violation of this section shall impound the motorized scooter and all fees associated with towing and storage shall be the responsibility of the owner of the motorized scooter. 
(Ord. No. 1366, 12-4-03; Ord. No. 1393, 3-17-05) 
Sec. 17-92. - Same-Violations, penalty. 
(a)  Each duly appointed city police officer is hereby empowered to enforce the provisions of this section pursuant to M.G.L.A. c. 40,  25D. Whoever violates the provisions of section 17-91 shall be penalized by $25.00 non-criminal penalty for the first violation; and for a second violation, a non-criminal penalty of not less than $25.00 and not more that $50.00; and for a third and subsequent violation, a non-criminal penalty of not less than $50.00 and not more that $100.00. non-criminal penalty of $25.00. 
(b)  A police officer upon observing a violation of section 17-91 shall impound the motorized scooter. All fees for towing and/or storage of the motorized scooter shall be the responsibility of the owner of the motorized scooter. 
(Ord. No. 1366, 12-4-03; Ord. No. 1393, 3-17-05)

ARTICLE IV. - PARKING, STOPPING AND STANDING GENERALLY 

Sec. 17-111. - Places where parking is prohibited generally. 
    No person shall park a vehicle in any of the places set forth in this section. Vehicles found parked in violation of the provisions of this section may be moved by or under the direction of an officer and at the expense of the owner to a place where parking is permitted. 
(1)  Within an intersection. 
(2)  Upon any sidewalk. 
(3)  Upon any crosswalk. 
(4)  Upon a roadway where parking is permitted unless both wheels on the right side of the vehicle are within 12 inches of the curb or edge of the roadway, except upon those streets which are designed as one-way streets. On such one-way streets vehicles shall be parked in the direction in which such vehicle is moving and with both wheels within 12 inches of this curb. This shall not apply to streets or parts of streets where angle parking is required by these regulations. 
(5)  Upon any roadway where the parking of a vehicle will not leave a clear and unobstructed lane at least ten feet wide for passing traffic. 
(6)  Upon any street or highway within ten feet of a fire hydrant. 
(7)  Upon or in front of any private road or roadway. 
(8)  Upon any street or highway within 20 feet of an intersecting way, except alleys. 
(9)  Within 15 feet of the wall of a fire station or directly across the street from such station; provided, that signs are erected acquainting the driver of such restriction. 
(10)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when such stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic. 
(11)  Upon any tree belt as defined in section 17-1. 
(12)  In any area located on private property which is open to the public and is designated either by upright sign or by ground markings as a fire lane. 
(13)  In or upon any space designated for the parking of motor vehicles which has been posted as being reserved for the parking of motor vehicles either owned and operated by disabled veterans or by handicapped persons pursuant to section 17-134 or any other ordinance of the city unless the motor vehicle so parked shall bear the distinctive number plates as authorized by M.G.L.A. c. 90,  2; or shall display the special parking identification plate for vehicles which transport handicapped persons as authorized by M.G.L.A. c. 90,  2; or shall bear an official identification of the motor vehicle as being one owned and operated by a handicapped person as issued by the public officials of any other state of the United States or of any province of Canada. 
(14)  No heavy vehicle in excess of 2 1/2 tons, shall park on any city street or way for a period exceeding two hours unless actively engaged in the loading or unloading of goods or wares. There will be no parking of such vehicles between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. for any reason without a permit obtained by the chief of police. At no time shall a trailer, not attached to a registered vehicle be allowed to remain on any street or way. 
For the purpose of this subsection, the definition of "heavy vehicles" shall mean, vehicles in excess of 21/2 tons G.V.W.R. vehicles with dual wheels, campers or any vehicle or combination in excess of 30 feet. 
(15)  Prohibited parking. 
(16)  Restricted area. 
(17)  During a snow parking ban. 
(18)  Within a bus stop/taxi stand. 
(Code 1971,  16-80; Ord. No. 1123,  B, 1-6-94; Ord. No. 1213, 9-3-98; Ord. No. 1464, 11-27-07) 
Sec. 17-112. - Municipal building parking areas. 
(a)  Classes. For the purpose of this section, parking areas and nonparking areas at the municipal building are to be divided into five classes to be known as: 
(1)  Public parking. In public parking areas only members of the general public and municipal employees with offices other than in the municipal building having business within the municipal building are to use the public parking areas except in emergency situations. 
(2)  Staff parking. In staff parking areas only those persons whose name or number is designated upon the spaces provided may park in the staff parking areas. 
(3)  Employee parking. In employee parking areas only employees of the city having offices in the municipal building are to use the employee parking area. 
(4)  No parking; tow-away areas. No person may park a motor vehicle in those areas designated as a no-parking area. Any motor vehicle parked in a no-parking area shall be towed from such no-parking area at the expense of the owner of such motor vehicle. 
(5)  Handicapped parking; tow away area. There shall be an area designated as parking for the handicapped consisting of three marked lanes on the southwesterly side of the municipal parking lot nearest to the ramp entry to the municipal building, on the easterly side. Such area shall be posted "Parking for the handicapped-Tow away area." 
(b)  Diagram. Such areas are as shown, defined and bounded on the diagram entitled "Sketch Showing Municipal Building Area" or as such diagram is hereafter amended, which diagram is hereby adopted and made a part of this section together with all explanatory matter thereon. Such diagram shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk. A conforming copy of such diagram shall be posted in a prominent position in the municipal building. 
(c)  Rules and regulations. In order to facilitate the efficient administration of municipal government in the city, the following regulations relative to parking in the municipal building parking area are hereby established. 
(1)  Vehicle parking in the municipal parking area shall be as designated on the official map entitled "Municipal Building Parking Area," dated January 24, 1979, and as may be amended from time to time by the city council. 
(2)  Such official map shall be located in the office of the city clerk. Facsimile maps shall be displayed in three prominent locations within the municipal building. 
(3)  Parking regulations shall be in effect for the hours of 8:00 a.m. through 6:00 p.m. on all business days of the city, except that handicapped parking shall be in effect for all hours of each and every day. 
(4)  No employee of the city shall use the areas designated as public parking. 
(5)  Any vehicle parked in a no parking zone shall be towed and any expense incurred by the city shall be paid by the owner of such vehicle. 
(Code 1971,  16-80.1; Ord. No. 799,  16-251, 3-15-79; Ord. No. 832, 8-21-80; Ord. No. 1123,  C, 1-6-94) 
Sec. 17-113. - Parking during a snow storm. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to park such vehicle on any street from the beginning of a snow storm until after the storm ceases, and the plowing has been completed on that street, unless such period is extended by order of the mayor or superintendent of public works or their designee. 
(Code 1971,  16-81; Ord. No. 1166, 9-5-96; Ord. No. 1181, 3-6-97) 
Cross reference- Parking during snow and ice storms, ch. 17, art. V. 
Sec. 17-114. - Temporary parking prohibitions. 
    The chief of police is hereby authorized to prohibit, temporarily, parking on any street or highway or part thereof in an impending or existing emergency, or for a lawful assemblage, demonstration or procession, provided there is reasonable justification for such prohibition. Vehicles parked in places where parking is prohibited temporarily may be moved by or under the direction of an officer. 
(Code 1971,  16-82)

Sec. 17-133. - Fire lanes. 
(a)  Established. The city council shall establish fire lanes in the city. 
(b)  Parking within prohibited. No person shall park a vehicle in any of the places set forth as fire lanes. Vehicles found parked in violation of the provisions of this section may be moved by or under the direction of an officer and at the expense of the owner to a place where parking is permitted. 
(c)  Designated. Upon the following streets or ways or parts thereof, parking is hereby prohibited: 
Park Square, a strip of roadway 15 feet wide adjacent and parallel to the northerly curbline of Broad Street and extending generally in a westerly direction to the easterly line of Elm Street. 
(Code 1971,  9-31-9-34) 
Sec. 17-134. - Parking reserved for disabled veterans and handicapped persons. 
(a)  Any person, entity or body, including the city and any department, authority, board or commission thereof, that has lawful ownership or control of improved or enclosed property used as off-street motor vehicle parking areas for businesses, shopping malls, theatres, auditoriums, sporting or recreational facilities, cultural centers, multifamily residential dwellings, or for any other place where the public has a right of access as invitee or as licensee shall reserve motor vehicle parking spaces in such off-street parking areas for motor vehicles owned and operated by a disabled veteran or handicapped person whose motor vehicle bears the distinguishing license plate authorized by M.G.L.A. c. 90,  2 or for any motor vehicle which transports a handicapped person and which displays the special identification plate authorized by M.G.L.A. c. 90,  2 according to the following formula: 
(1)  More than 15 parking spaces but not more than 25: One. 
(2)  More than 25 parking spaces but not more than 40: Five percent of the spaces; minimum of two. 
(3)  More than 40 parking spaces but not more than 100: Four percent of the spaces; minimum of three. 
(4)  More than 100 parking spaces: The number of spaces as set forth in M.G.L.A. c. 40,  21(23)(a), the formula as set forth therein which is hereby incorporated herein by reference. 
(b)  Parking spaces designated as reserved under the provisions of this section shall be located as near as possible to a building entrance or walkway; shall be adjacent to curb ramps or other unobstructed methods permitting sidewalk access to a handicapped person; and shall be 12 feet wide or two eight-foot wide spaces with four feet of cross hatch between them and shall be identified by both: 
(1)  An above grade sign with white lettering against a blue background which bears the words "Handicapped Parking: Special Plate Required. Unauthorized Vehicles May be Removed at Owner's Expense"; and 
(2)  A marking of permanent nature on the surface of the reserved parking space which sets forth the wording "Handicapped Parking" and/or uses the "International Symbol of Access" as is commonly recognized as reserving the use of the parking space for the handicapped only. 
(c)  The failure of any parking space to be posted with both an above grade sign and a marking on the surface of the reserved parking space identifying the space as one reserved for handicapped parking shall not be a defense for any person whose unauthorized motor vehicle is parked in such a reserved space provided that at least one of the required identifying devices is present at the site at the time of the violation. 
(d)  In the event that a person, entity or body having lawful ownership or control of improved or enclosed property in existence as of the effective date of this section and that is subject to the requirements of the formula as set forth in section 17-134(a) is unable to comply with the requirements of the formula without the acquisition of or the paving of additional real estate, due to the effect of a conflicting state law or city ordinance, regulation or condition, then, in that event, the person, entity or body may apply in writing to the chief of police of the city for a waiver of the requirements of the formula. Should such a hardship be reasonably shown to exist, the chief of police shall grant a waiver of the requirements of the formula. Such waiver shall be in writing, shall specify the number of handicapped reserved parking spaces required, if any, and shall specify that any increase in size of the parking lot for which the waiver is granted or of the premises served by such parking lot shall automatically terminate the waiver. The chief of police may deny the request for a waiver. The decision of the chief of police shall be final. A waiver as granted hereunder may be reconsidered at any time by the chief of police upon a showing of changed circumstances. 
(Ord. No. 1123,  D, 1-6-94)

ARTICLE V. - PARKING DURING SNOW AND ICE STORMS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Parking during a snow storm,  17-113. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 17-156. - Declaration of emergency. 
    If, during the months of November, December, January, February and March of any year, snow and ice accumulation on the city's public ways or public parking lots causes or results in the parking of vehicles in a position or manner that may impede or prevent the free passage of emergency service vehicles, ambulances, fire apparatus, waste disposal, police, or any other vehicle, so as to interfere with the protection of the property, health and lives of people, a state of emergency shall exist and the mayor, by an announcement on radio, television or newspaper, shall make known that the aforesaid conditions exist, and shall declare that a state of emergency exists. 
(Code 1971,  16-107; Ord. No. 966, 11-19-87) 
Sec. 17-157. - Issuance of temporary emergency regulations by chief of police; announcement, termination of emergency. 
    Upon the declaration of a state of snow and ice emergency, the chief of police shall issue temporary emergency regulations preventing and prohibiting, during the emergency, the parking of any vehicle on the whole or any part of any or all public ways, public parking lots, and parks or playgrounds, or in the alternative, the parking of any vehicle on that side of all public ways where any building is designated with an odd number. The chief of police shall announce such emergency regulations by radio or television, or by newspaper. When the conditions creating the emergency no longer exist, the chief of police shall announce the termination of such emergency. 
(Code 1971,  16-108; Ord. No. 966, 11-19-87) 
Sec. 17-158. - Obedience to regulations required. 
    Upon the declaration of a snow and ice emergency, no person shall cause, permit or allow any vehicle to be parked contrary to the regulations of the chief of police. 
(Code 1971,  16-109; Ord. No. 966, 11-19-87) 
Sec. 17-159. - Towing of vehicles and storage at owner's expense; records of vehicles removed. 
    The chief of police may remove or cause to be removed any vehicle parked in violation of this article, at the sole expense of the owner of such vehicle, to any public garage located in the city; and such owner shall be liable to charges for the removal and storage of such vehicle. The chief of police shall maintain a record of all vehicles removed or towed, pursuant to this article, indicating date and time of removal or towing, place where the vehicle was parked, place of storage, name of towing service or company, and name of police officer issuing the order of removal or towing. 
(Code 1971,  16-110; Ord. No. 966, 11-19-87) 
State Law reference- Authority to remove vehicles parked in violation of the law, M.G.L.A. c. 40,  22D. 
Sec. 17-160. - Contractor liable for damages. 
    Neither the removal or towing nor the storage of a vehicle under the provisions of this article shall be deemed to be services rendered or work performed by the city or any of its departments or any of its employees. The towing company or contractor shall be liable to the owner of such vehicle for any damage to it arising out of negligence in the course of such removal or towing or storage. 
(Code 1971,  16-111; Ord. No. 966, 11-19-87) 
Secs. 17-161-17-185. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - VEHICLES INTERFERING WITH REMOVAL OF SNOW AND ICE 

Sec. 17-186. - Superintendent of streets; authority to remove vehicles interfering with removal of snow or ice. 
    Irrespective of the declaration of a snow and ice emergency, any vehicle located or parked on any public way or public parking lot which is interfering with the prompt and orderly removal or plowing of snow or the removal of ice from such way or lot shall, after reasonable notice, be removed by the superintendent of streets at the sole expense of the owner of such vehicle to any public garage within the city by means of towing or otherwise. For the purpose of this section, the presence of "Snow Removal" or "No Parking" signs, or an announcement by radio, television or newspaper shall be deemed reasonable notice. 
(Code 1971,  16-120; Ord. No. 966, 11-19-87; Ord. No. 1043, 6-7-90) 
Sec. 17-187. - Owner liable for storage charges; contractor liable. 
    The superintendent of streets shall inform the chief of police before or immediately after removal of vehicles pursuant to section 17-186. Upon being informed, the chief of police or his designee shall record such removal or towing in the same manner as provided in section 17-159. The provisions of section 17-160 shall be applicable to all vehicles removed, towed or stored under the provisions of section 17-186. 
(Code 1971,  16-122; Ord. No. 966, 11-19-87) 
Sec. 17-188. - Notification of owners within 24 hours. 
    Irrespective of the declaration of a snow and ice emergency, the chief of police and the towing company or towing contractor shall, within 24 hours from any removal or towing pursuant to sections 17-159 through 17-186, make reasonable efforts to notify the owners of vehicles removed pursuant to the above mentioned sections, and inform them of the location or place where they may take repossession of their respective vehicles. For the purposes of this section, a telephone call to, or personal contact with, the owners of such vehicles shall be construed to be reasonable notification. 
(Code 1971,  16-123; Ord. No. 966, 11-19-87) 
Sec. 17-189. - Requisites for repossession by owner. 
(a)  Before the owner of any vehicle impounded pursuant to this division shall be permitted to remove a vehicle which has been so towed or removed to a public garage, he shall: 
(1)  Furnish satisfactory evidence to the superintendent of streets and to the owner or person in charge of such public garage of his identity and ownership of such vehicle. 
(2)  Pay all charges for towing or removing such car and all storage charges, such charges to be set by council from time to time, and pay to the superintendent of streets all charges for publishing any and all notices hereunder. 
(3)  Sign a written receipt acknowledging delivery of such vehicle. 
(b)  Any charges made or incurred hereunder shall in no way be considered to be a fine, penalty or forfeiture. 
(Code 1971,  16-124) 
Sec. 17-190. - Removal not to preclude institution of criminal proceedings. 
    The removal and storage of any vehicle under the provisions of this division shall not prevent or preclude the institution and prosecution of criminal proceedings against the owner or operator of such vehicle. 
(Code 1971,  16-125) 
Secs. 17-191-17-215. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - OFF-STREET PARKING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1599, adopted May 15, 2014, repealed the former Art. VI,  17-216, 17-217, 17-241-17-251, 17-271, 17-272, and enacted a new Art. VI as set out herein. The former Art. VI pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1971,  16-211-16-223, 16-231, 16-232; Ord. No. 895, adopted Dec. 20, 1985. 

Sec. 17-216. - Finding of fact. 
    It is hereby declared that excessive curb parking of motor vehicles on the streets of the city would create congestion, obstruct the free circulation of traffic, diminish property values and endanger the health, safety and general welfare of the public. The provision of conveniently located off-street parking facilities are beneficial to the City of Westfield and the establishment of public off-street parking facilities are a proper public or municipal purpose. 
(Ord. No. 1599, 5-15-14) 
Sec. 17-217. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Parking facilities may consist of lots, garages or other structures and accessories; they may be surface facilities or facilities above or under the ground. 
    Public off-street automobile parking facilities are accommodations provided by public authority for the parking of automobiles off the street or highway and open to public use, with or without a charge. 
(Ord. No. 1599, 5-15-14) 
Sec. 17-218. - Off-street parking commission established; composition; appointment, terms, compensation, removal of members. 
(a)  There is hereby established a commission, to be known as the Westfield Off-Street Parking Commission for the purpose of establishing and maintaining public off-street automobile parking facilities. 
(b)  The commission shall consist of seven members. Six members shall be appointed by the mayor, with council confirmation for a term of three years. One member shall be a member of the city council and shall serve coterminous with the term of the mayor who appoints them, unless sooner removed. The commission shall choose a chairman from its own membership. 
(c)  Members shall serve until the qualification of their successors, who shall be appointed for a like term. Any member of the commission may be removed by the mayor pursuant to the City Charter. 
(d)  The commission shall adopt rules, not inconsistent with the provisions of any applicable statute or ordinance, for conducting its business and meetings and otherwise carrying out the purpose of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1599, 5-15-14) 
Sec. 17-219. - General authority. 
    The off-street parking commission is hereby authorized to plan, design, maintain and operate public off-street parking facilities. 
(Ord. No. 1599, 5-15-14) 
Sec. 17-220. - Disposing of property. 
    The commission may sell, lease, exchange or otherwise dispose of property and property rights in accordance with M.G.L.A. c. 30B, the Uniform Procurement Act and the City of Westfield Charter. 
(Ord. No. 1599, 5-15-14) 
Sec. 17-221. - Authority to design and locate off-street parking facilities; facilities to be in compliance with zoning, building, subdivision, police and fire regulations; use of city personnel and services. 
(a)  The off-street parking commission is authorized to design and locate such off-street parking facilities as the public interest and the purposes of this division require. Such facilities may consist of lots, improved or unimproved, single or multilevel garages, other structures and accessories, or any combination thereof; provided, that no products used in or for the servicing of motor vehicles shall be sold or dispensed at or in connection with public off-street parking facilities by the commission or any lessee thereof; and provided further that such facilities shall be in compliance with the existing zoning ordinances, building code, subdivision regulations, and police and fire regulations. Any facility so designed or located may be on the surface or above or below the surface. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, the commission is authorized to use the personnel and services of other departments of the city, provided that the cost of such services and personnel is properly charged against the commission. 
(Ord. No. 1599, 5-15-14) 
Sec. 17-222. - Procedure for award of contracts for construction of off-street parking facilities. 
    The off-street parking commission is authorized to construct or cause to be constructed public off-street facilities of such design and in such location as authorized by section 17-244. All contracts awarded under this section shall conform with the public bidding and procurement statutes, including M.G.L.A. c. 7,  38A1/2-38O, c. 30,  39M, c. 30B and c. 149,  44A-44J. 
(Ord. No. 1599, 5-15-14) 
Sec. 17-223. - Maintenance and operation of off-street parking facilities; regulations; accounting and revenue. 
(a)  The off-street parking commission is hereby authorized to maintain and operate public off-street parking facilities, or to lease by competitive bidding to any individual firm or corporation upon such terms as the public interest may warrant. 
(b)  Regulations for the orderly use of off-street parking facilities shall be prescribed and maintained by the commission as well as a schedule of parking fees and other charges for the use of such facilities. Such regulations may be revised from time to time by the commission. A true copy of such regulations shall be kept and maintained in the parking clerk's office and available to the public for inspection. 
(c)  The commission may from time to time accept such portion of parking revenue as is properly allocated to it, provided that such funds shall be maintained by the commission as a separate account. 
(d)  The commission shall maintain proper accounting and financial records of all transactions and provide annual financial statements. Annual reports of all activities shall be made to the mayor and to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1599, 5-15-14) 
Sec. 17-224. - Powers not to supersede powers of council or police department. 
    Nothing in this division shall be construed as giving the off-street parking commission power to supersede the city council or police department or the regulation and enforcement of the parking of the streets of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1599, 5-15-14) 
Sec. 17-225. - Facilities established. 
    The following off-street parking lots are hereby established: 
(1)  Arnold Street Lot (separated into East and West)- Parcel numbers 55-65, 55-66 and 55-75 and located at 36 Arnold Street, 32 Church Street and 23 Church Street, respectively. 
(2)  Franklin Street Lot-Parcel number 55-127 located at 0 Elm Street (Rear). 
(3)  Main Street Lot-Parcel number 12-2 and located at 33 Main Street. 
(4)  Thomas Street Lot-Parcel numbers 9-21 and 9-12 and located at 0 Elm Street (rear) and 87 Elm Street. In addition are the permanent easements including portions of parcel numbers 9-11, 9-10, 9-9, 9-8 and 9-7 located at 89 Elm Street, 81 Elm Street, Elm Street, 73 Elm Street and 67 Elm Street, respectively. 
(5)  Riverwalk Lot-Parcel number 1-3 and 1-2 and located at 2 Meadow Street. 
(6)  Railroad Avenue Lot-Parcel number 217-9 and located at 21 Railroad Avenue. 
(7)  Reader Lots (separated into Reader 1, Reader 2 and Reader 3)-Parcel numbers 55-41, 55-39, 55-49 and 55-50 and located at 10 Church Street, 0 Church Street, 0 School Street ad 47 School Street, respectively. 
(8)  Depot Square Lot-Parcel number 219-00. 
(Ord. No. 1599, 5-15-14) 
Sec. 17-226. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the parking enforcement officer and the police to enforce the provisions of this section. 
(b)  Any person who violates the provisions of this article shall be subject to the penalties provided by M.G.L.A. c. 90,  20A, and any other penalty provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 1599, 5-15-14) 
Secs. 17-227-17-290. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - PEDESTRIANS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Use of byways by pedestrians; rules and regulations; violations, M.G.L.A. c. 90,  18A. 

Sec. 17-291. - Obstructing traffic. 
    No person shall stop, stand, loiter or saunter on any sidewalk, street or highway so as to obstruct or impede the normal movement of traffic, and any person doing so shall move on if directed to do so by an officer. 
(Code 1971,  16-171) 
Sec. 17-292. - Playing in streets. 
    No person shall, within the limits of any street, play any game of ball or football, throw any snowball, stone or any hard substance, fly any kite or engage in any other amusement, game or exercise interfering with the safe and convenient use of such street by any person traveling or passing along the same. 
(Code 1971,  16-172) 
Cross reference- Streets and sidewalks, ch. 16. 
Sec. 17-293. - Crossing ways or roadways. 
    Pedestrians shall obey the directions of police officers directing traffic, and whenever there is an officer directing traffic, a traffic-control signal or a marked crosswalk within 300 feet of a pedestrian, no such pedestrian shall cross a way or roadway except within the limits of a marked crosswalk and as hereinafter provided in this article. For the purpose of this article, a marked crosswalk shall only be construed to be that area of a roadway reserved for pedestrian crossing located between two solid white reflectorized 12-inch pavement markings in rural areas or markings not less than six inches wide in urban areas, such markings or lines being no less than six feet apart. 
(Code 1971,  16-173) 
Sec. 17-294. - Actuation of traffic-control signals; yielding to emergency vehicles. 
(a)  At a traffic-control signal location where pedestrian indications are provided but which are shown only upon actuation by means of a pedestrian push button, no pedestrian shall cross a roadway unless or until the pedestrian control signal push button has been actuated, and then he shall cross only on the proper pedestrian signal indication. At traffic-control signal locations where no pedestrian indication is provided, pedestrians shall cross only on the green indication. If necessary, the green indication shall be actuated by the pedestrian by means of a push button. 
(b)  At a traffic-control signal location, pedestrians shall yield the right-of-way to vehicles of a funeral or other procession or authorized emergency vehicle while in performance of emergency duties regardless of the signal indication given, and they shall not attempt to cross the roadway until such vehicles or procession has passed, at which time pedestrians shall then cross the roadway only as provided in these regulations. 
(Code 1971,  16-174) 
Sec. 17-295. - Obedience to traffic-control signals. 
    Traffic-control signal color indications and legends shall have the pedestrian commands ascribed to them in this section and no other meanings, and every pedestrian shall comply therewith, except when otherwise directed by an officer. 
(1)  Red and yellow or the word "Walk." Whenever the red and yellow lenses are illuminated together or the single word "Walk" is illuminated, pedestrians facing such indication may proceed across the roadway and in the direction of such signal only. 
(2)  Red alone or "Don't Walk." Whenever the words "Don't Walk" or any indication other than red and yellow shown together are illuminated in a traffic-control signal where pedestrian indications are provided, pedestrians approaching or facing such indication shall wait on the sidewalk, edge of roadway or in the pedestrian refuge area of a traffic island and shall not enter upon or cross a roadway until the proper indication is illuminated in the traffic-control signal, but any pedestrian who has partially completed his crossing on the walk indication shall proceed or return to the nearest sidewalk or safety island on the yellow indication, the red indication or when the words "Don't Walk" are illuminated by rapid intermittent flashes. 
(3)  Green alone. At traffic-control signal locations where no pedestrian indication is given or provided, pedestrians facing the signal may proceed across the roadway within any marked crosswalk in the direction of the green indication. 
(4)  Yellow alone, red alone or flashing "Don't Walk." Pedestrians approaching or facing a yellow, red or flashing "Don't Walk" illuminated indication shall not start to cross a roadway. 
(5)  Flashing red, yellow or green. At any traffic-control signal location where a flashing red, flashing yellow or flashing green indication is being given facing a crosswalk, pedestrians shall actuate, where provided, the pedestrian signal indication and cross the roadway only on the red, yellow or "Walk" indication when such indication is in operation. If no pedestrian signal is provided, pedestrians shall cross within crosswalks with due care. 
(Code 1971,  16-171) 
Sec. 17-296. - Crossings and use of roadways. 
(a)  No pedestrian shall suddenly leave a sidewalk or safety island and walk or run into the path of a vehicle which is so close that it is impossible for the driver to yield the right-of-way. 
(b)  Pedestrians shall at all times attempt to cross a roadway using the right half of a crosswalk. 
(c)  Where sidewalks are provided, it shall be unlawful for any pedestrian to walk along and upon an adjacent roadway whenever the sidewalk is open to pedestrian use. 
(d)  Where sidewalks are not provided, any pedestrian walking along and upon a highway shall, when practicable, walk only on the left side of the roadway on its unfinished shoulder facing traffic which may approach from the opposite direction. 
(e)  Persons alighting from the roadway side of any vehicle parked at the curb or edge of the roadway shall proceed immediately to the sidewalk or edge of the roadway adjacent to vehicle, and shall cross the roadway only as authorized by this article. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person to actuate a pedestrian control signal or to enter a marked crosswalk unless a crossing of the roadway is intended. 
(Code 1971,  16-177) 
Sec. 17-297. - Crossing at nonsignalized locations. 
    Every pedestrian crossing a roadway at any point other than within a marked crosswalk shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. At a point where a pedestrian tunnel or overpass has been provided, pedestrians shall cross the roadway only by the proper use of a tunnel or overpass. 
(Code 1971,  16-178) 
Sec. 17-298. - Operators to exercise due care. 
    The provisions of this article shall in no way abrogate the provisions of M.G.L.A. c. 90,  14 and 14A, which provide "Precautions for Safety of Other Travelers" and for the "Protection of Blind Persons Crossing Ways." Furthermore, notwithstanding the provisions of this article, every operator of a vehicle shall exercise due care to avoid colliding with any pedestrian upon the roadway and shall give warning by sounding the horn when necessary and shall exercise proper precautions which may become necessary for safe operation. 
(Code 1971,  16-179) 
Sec. 17-299. - Pedestrians soliciting rides or business. 
    No person shall stand in a roadway for the purpose of soliciting a ride, employment or business from the operator or occupant of any vehicle without the written permission of the board or officer having control of such roadway or highway. 
(Code 1971,  16-180) 
Sec. 17-300. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this article governing the use of ways by pedestrians shall not apply to pedestrians actually engaged in work upon a roadway closed to travel or under construction or repair; to municipal, state, federal or public service corporation employees while in the performance of their duties; to officers engaged in the performance of their public duties, or to pedestrians acting in an emergency when such emergency necessitates departure from any part of this article. 
(Code 1971,  16-181) 
Sec. 17-301. - Penalties. 
    Any person who violates the provisions of this article which deal with the proper use of ways by pedestrians shall be punished as provided in M.G.L.A. c. 90,  18A as most recently added by chapter 409 of the Acts of 1962. Any person convicted of a violation of any other provision of this article relative to the operation of vehicle shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $20.00 for each offense. 
(Code 1971,  16-182) 
Sec. 17-302. - Pedestrian traffic safety markers. 
(a)  Pedestrian traffic safety markers may be used by the police department to designate crossing areas within the city. 
(b)  Temporary erection of pedestrian traffic safety markers by the police department shall have the same force and effect as regular crosswalks. 
(Ord. No. 815, 11-15-79) 
Secs. 17-303-17-325. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - BIKEWAYS 

Sec. 17-326. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bicycle means a nonmotorized vehicle in, upon or by which a person may be transported upon a bikeway by human power. 
    Bikeway means an area within the city designated by the city council, the flood control commission, the park and recreation commission, or the school committee. 
    Driver means the person in control of a bicycle. 
(Code 1971,  16-200) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally,  1-2. 
Sec. 17-327. - Established. 
    The city council may from time to time designate areas within the city on municipally owned property as bikeways. The city council hereby authorizes the flood control commission, the park and recreation department, and the school committee to designate areas as bikeways, subject to conditions set forth in this article. 
(Code 1971,  16-201) 
Sec. 17-328. - Bikeways to be set out on plan and designated with appropriate signs. 
    All bikeways in the city shall be set out on a plan recorded with the city clerk. All bikeways shall be designated as such by appropriate signs. Such signs shall be displayed at intervals of no less than 1,000 feet. 
(Code 1971,  16-202) 
Sec. 17-329. - Unauthorized vehicles prohibited on bikeways. 
    No unauthorized vehicle may use any bikeway within the city which has been designated for the exclusive use of bicycles. An unauthorized vehicle shall be any vehicle not propelled by human power. 
(Code 1971,  16-203) 
Secs. 17-330-17-350. - Reserved.
