After the city board of public works has reviewed the evidence, it may issue an administrative order to the user responsible for the discharge, and assess a civil penalty in such amount as it deems appropriate in accordance with the provisions of section 18-181(j)(3) of this division, and/or direct that, following a specified time, the sewer service be discontinued unless adequate treatment facilities, devices or other related appurtances are properly operated. Further orders and directives as are necessary and appropriate may be issued. 
(g)  Permit actions. The city may revoke, suspend, modify or refuse to renew any permit issued under this division during its term for cause. Such causes include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Violations of any terms or conditions of the permit or applicable lay or regulation; 
(2)  Obtaining a permit be misrepresentation or failure to disclose fully all relevant facts; 
(3)  Intentionally falsifying or misrepresenting records, rendering inaccurate, tampering with or manipulating any monitoring device or method used or required by the city, to hide actual or potential violations of the permit or applicable law or regulation; or 
(4)  Intentionally violating or failing to comply with actions, orders, directives and/or assessments imposed pursuant to this division. 
(h)  Appeals. When a notice of violation, administrative order and/or assessment of penalties is issued or a permit action taken without a preceding show cause hearing, the actions, orders, directives and/or assessments contained therein may be appealed to the city. The appeal must be made in writing no later then 14 calendar days after notification of the appealed action, and must contain complete and sufficient information for evaluation of the factors to be considered by the city. No later than 30 calendar days after the filing of an appeal, the city shall, in writing, either grant or deny the appeal, stating the reasons for its decision. 
(i)  Further appeal. After issuance of a final decision under wither section 18-181(f) or (h), a user having the right to seek judicial review of the decision may file with the appropriate court. 
(j)  Administrative civil penalties. Any user that violates any provision of this division or any order or permit issues hereunder, or who knowingly makes any false representation in an application, record, report or plan, or falsifies, tampers with or renders inaccurate a monitoring device or method required by any regulation, order or permit issues hereunder may be punished by an administrative civil penalty not to exceed $5,000.00 pursuant to Chapter 173 of the Massachusetts Acts of 1990,  3(e). The city may, in the case of continuing non-compliance, assess each day of such noncompliance as a separate non-compliance. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the city may proceed directly to court or may enter into a consent order with the user specifying an agreed amount of civil administrative penalty in accordance with section 18-181(c). 
(1)  An administrative civil penalty may be assessed by the city against a user for: 
a.  Non-compliance with this division, or 
b.  Non-compliance with a notice of violation or administrative order issued pursuant to section 18-181(b) or (d) of this division, or 
c.  Which is willful and not the result of error, or 
d.  Which has resulted in significant impact on public health, safety or welfare of the environment. 
(2)  The city may serve upon such user a penalty assessment notice which shall contain a concise statement of the violation, the date of violation for each penalty to be assessed, state the amount of each penalty assessment, the factors considered in determining said amount, and the method and deadline for payment of the penalty. 
(3)  A penalty shall be paid by certified check, cashier's check or money order payable to the City of Westfield. Each administrative penalty shall be paid in full within 30 days of issuance of the penalty assessment notice or consent order. Said payment requirement shall be stayed during the pendancy of a hearing pursuant to this division. A person who fails to pay a penalty in full and on time shall be liable to the city for costs, interest and attorneys fees incurred in collecting the penalty. This is in addition to any other remedy authorized by law. 
(k)  Damages. Any user that violates this division shall be liable for any expense incurred by the city as a result of such violation, including, but not limited to, any or all of the following: costs, attorney's fees, losses, penalties or damages. 
(l)  Termination of discharge. In addition to the provisions in section 18-181 of this division, any user that violates the following conditions of this division, wastewater discharge permits, or orders issued hereunder, is subject to discharge termination. 
(1)  Violation of wastewater discharge permit conditions; 
(2)  Failure to accurately report the wastewater constituents and characteristics of its discharge; 
(3)  Failure to report significant changes in operations or wastewater volume, constituents and characteristics prior to discharge; 
(4)  Refusal of reasonable access to the user's premises for the purpose of inspection, monitoring or sampling; 
(5)  Violation of the pretreatment standards in section 18-178 of this division. 
(m)  Civil actions. The city may bring a civil action for appropriate relief to enforce this division, including any requirement of a permit or order issued hereunder, in a court of competent jurisdiction. Such relief may include, but is not limited to, any or all of the following: a permanent or temporary injunction, the imposition of penalties and/or the recovery of expenses as set forth in section 18-181(j) and (k). 
(n)  Other procedures. Nothing in this division shall prevent the city from pursuing other legal or equitable rights or remedies, which may be available to it under federal, state or local law, rules or regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-182. - Setting sewerage system rates. 
    The city council shall have the power to determine or assess rates for the use, entrance, connection and service of the sewerage system and shall set such rates from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-183. - Review of charge. 
    The sewer use charge shall be reviewed by the board of public works every two years with recommendations for change, if any, forwarded to the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-184. - Keeping books and records generally. 
    The board of public works shall have charge of the keeping of the books, accounts and records of the sewerage system, except collecting. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-185. - Preparation of bills; mailing date of same. 
    Bills for the use of the sewerage system and for other charges in connection therewith shall be prepared by the board of public works. Such bills shall be sent by the board of public works to the sewerage system user or owners of premises on which the sewerage system is used, containing statements of amounts due, on or before April 1 in each year, and at such other times as the board of public works may determine. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-186. - Sewerage system rates payable in advance. 
    All rates for the use of the sewerage system shall be payable in advance. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-187. - Notice of delinquent account. 
    In any case of nonpayment of a sewerage system bill for 60 day's after the same is due, the city collector shall send a notice to the delinquent, and shall inform the board of public works in writing that such notice has been sent. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-188. - Duties of city collector. 
    Sewerage system bills shall be committed to the city collector for collection. The city collector shall notify the board of public works monthly of the amounts of sewerage system bills collected, and shall keep records of all paid and unpaid sewerage system bills. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-189. - Enforcement of sewer use fee. 
    If the sewer use fee remains unpaid for 60 days after it becomes due and payable, the city collector may maintain and recover in an action of contract or in any other appropriate action, suit or proceeding either in his own name or in the name of the city against the person assessed for such sewer use fee. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Secs. 18-190-18-199. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SEWER EXTENSION PLAN 

Sec. 18-200. - Permitted extension areas. 
    The plan titled Sewer Extension Plan, City of Westfield; dated October 25, 2010, is hereby adopted by the city and incorporated by reference in this division. Sanitary sewer system extensions shall only be permitted within the areas so designated on this plan. All uses and properties located within the area so designated for extension on the above referenced plan are eligible to connect into the city's sanitary sewer system without an infiltration and inflow waiver (as stated below) provided: 
(1)  For commercial/industrial uses, that the cumulative total (beginning on the date of adoption of this division [April 2, 2015]) of waste flows generated from such uses does not exceed .23 mgd, (as determined by the state Department of Environmental Protection, or such entity as shall succeed, replace or supersede the state Department of Environmental Protection). 
(2)  For residential uses, that: 
a.  The street that they are fronting on was constructed and in existence prior to the adoption date of this division [April 2, 2015], and 
b.  The cumulative total (beginning on the date of adoption of this division [April 2, 2015]) of waste flows generated from such uses does not exceed .53 mgd (as determined by the state Department of Environmental Protection, or such entity as shall succeed, replace or supersede the state Department of Environmental Protection). 
    Once the city's wastewater treatment facility's design flow capacity has been reached (as determined by the State Department of Environmental Protection, or such entity as shall succeed, replace or supersede the State Department of Environmental Protection) for these uses, additional projects of such uses within the extension area must apply for and receive an infiltration and inflow waiver. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-201. - Infiltration and inflow waiver option. 
(a)  Purpose. In adopting the Westfield Sewer System Expansion Plan, the city recognizes that some projects which benefit the overriding public interest may warrant a waiver from strict compliance with the requirements set forth in section 18-200. The infiltration and inflow (I&I) waiver option has been adopted to guide and direct the city council, on a case-by-case basis, in the process and criteria for evaluating and rendering a decision on any applications for a waiver. 
(b)  Criteria. An I&I waiver may be granted to eligible projects as are set forth in section 18-202 when treatment capacity at the water pollution control plant is capable of being created through the elimination of points of infiltration and inflows of groundwater and stormwater in the city's sanitary sewer system. 
(c)  Fee. In the event of the approval of a waiver request, the applicant shall be required to pay a fee, to be determined by the city engineer, equal to the city's expense to eliminate five gallons of groundwater/stonnwater infiltration/inflows for every one gallon of sewerage projected to be generated (based on average flows) by the project. Said fee shall be paid to the city prior to the beginning of construction for work authorized in approving the application. All such fees shall be kept in a separate dedicated account to be used specifically for the purpose of eliminating infiltration and inflows of groundwater and stormwater in the city's sanitary sewer system. 
All  I&I option applications and approvals are reviewed independently and shall not set a precedent for future applications and approvals, with each petition is evaluated on its own merits. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-202. - Eligible projects. 
    Only the following are eligible to apply for an infiltration and inflow waiver: 
(a)  All properties shown on the above referenced sewer extension plan as being within the extension area (at such time as the city's wastewater treatment facility's design flow capacity has been reached) 
(b)  All properties not shown on the above referenced sewer extension plan as being within the extension area, for the following specific uses: 
(1)  For residential uses which cannot be serviced by an on-site sanitary sewage system and which comply with at least one of the following criteria: 
a.  Such use provides affordable housing (must be chapter 40B qualified/eligible), 
b.  Such use is located on the water resource protection area as identified in the Westfield Zoning Ordinance and Zoning Map (such use must still have the required two-acre minimum lot sizes), 
c.  Such use is to serve an area of multiple septic systems failures and certified by the board of health as requiring public sanitary sewerage as the only viable alternative. 
(2)  For industrial/commercial uses which comply with both of the following: 
a.  Such uses increases the job and tax base of the community, and 
b.  Such extension does not create residential access. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-203. - Application procedure. 
    Applications for the infiltration and inflow waiver shall: 
(a)  Be made in writing to the city council and filed with the city clerk; 
(b)  Include: 
i.  Detailed engineering plans and cost estimates of all required improvements, prepared and stamped by an insured professional engineer licensed by the state, 
ii.  Detailed calculations determining the amount of sewerage anticipated to be generated by the proposed use prepared and stamped by an insured professional engineer licensed by the state, 
iii.  A study, prepared by a qualified professional, of the anticipated impacts of such extension on the future growth and development patterns of land in the area. 
(c)  Be referred by the city council to the city engineer, board of public works, board of health, waste water treatment plant and planning board for their review, comment and recommendation. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-204. - Approval. 
    The city council, by a two-thirds majority vote of its entire membership, may, at a public meeting (no public hearing is required), approve a petition for an extension, not in accordance and/or compliance with the approved extension plan when, in their opinion, they find all of the following: 
(a)  That such petition complies with the requirements of sections 18-202 and 18-203, and; 
(b)  That such petition will not promote additional development in the area of a nature or at a density which the city council feels is unsuitable or undesirable, and; 
(c)  That, once the I&I improvements are completed, there will be available capacity at the water pollution control plant to accommodate the sewerage generated by the proposed use (the commencement of the proposed use may begin prior to the actual I&I improvements being made), and; 
(d)  That the cumulative total of all I&I options approved does not exceed the total treatment capacity (i.e. that capacity associated with I&I in excess of that required to be removed under the permit) of the water pollution control plant, and; 
(e)  That the granting of such petition is in the best interests of the health safety and welfare of the city and its residents. 
Secs. 18-205-18-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SERVICE, RATES AND BILLING 

Sec. 18-211. - Application for water service-Required. 
    To have the water service to any premises turned on, an application shall be filed with the department of water resources. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-212. - Same-Contents. 
    The application required by section 18-211 shall be made in writing by the applicant for water service, and shall include an agreement to be bound by all city ordinances and rules and regulations pertaining to water use. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-213. - Conformance with chapter, rules, required to have water turned on. 
    No water shall be supplied to any building unless the pipes and fixtures in such building conform to the rules and regulations of the board of water commissioners and the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-214. - Records of persons, premises, etc., served. 
    The board of water commissioners shall keep, in suitable books, the names of all persons who take water, the name of the street on which water is taken, the nature of the use, the number of takers, the amount charged and the amounts of abatements. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-215. - City authorized to install meter; cost. 
    The city shall have the right to install a water meter in any premises, at its own cost. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-216. - Rates when meter is installed. 
    Where the city has installed a water meter, the water charge may be established by the quantity of water used, rather than by schedule rates. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-217. - Connected fixtures in occupied premises to be charged for. 
    In all occupied premises, every fountain, water closet, set-basin, sink or other fixture, whether used or not, will be deemed and held to be used, and shall be charged for, so long as the same shall be connected with the water pipes. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-218. - Supply of water to more than one taker through single service pipe; responsibility of property owner. 
    When water is supplied to more than one taker through a single service pipe, the bill for water rates may be made either to the owner of the estate or to the tenant. In case of nonpayment, the water may be shut off, notwithstanding the fact that one or more takers may have paid their proportion to such owner or to the city. The owner shall be responsible for water supplied to his premises, although a charge for water rates may have been made against a tenant. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-219. - Preparation of bills; mailing date. 
    Bills for the use of water and for other charges in connection therewith shall be prepared by the board of water commissioners. Such bills shall be sent by the board of water commissioners to the water takers or owners of premises on which water is used, containing statements of amounts due for water, on or before April 1 and October 1 in each year, and at such other times as the board of water commissioners may determine. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-220. - Water rates payable in advance. 
    All rates for the use of water shall be payable in advance. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-221. - Notice of delinquent account. 
    In any case of nonpayment of a water bill for 60 days after the same is due, the city collector shall send a notice to the delinquent, and shall inform the board of water commissioners in writing that such notice has been sent. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-222. - Duties of city collector. 
    Water bills shall be committed to the city collector for collection. The city collector shall notify the board of water commissioners monthly of the amounts of water bills collected, and shall keep records of all paid and unpaid water bills. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-223. - Cutting off water for delinquency; cutting water back on. 
(a)  Unless any delinquent water bill is paid within three days of sending the notice of delinquency, together with the stipulated late fee for such notice, the city collector shall notify the board of water commissioners, who may cut the supply off to such premises. The water shall not be cut on again until the amount due, together with any fee for such notice, and the charge for the cutting off and cutting on, is paid. 
(b)  In cases of specific supply, or where the water has been let on for fractional parts of the term and the water bill is delinquent, the delinquency notice may be served and the water shut off immediately, and water shall not be let on again except upon the conditions set forth in this section. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-224. - Lien upon real estate for water rates. 
    With reference to the statutory lien upon real estate for water rates, the board of water commissioners shall be the board or officer in charge of the for the purpose of carrying out the requirements of M.G.L.A. c. 40,  42A, and the board shall file in the registry of deeds a statement as provided by such section in each case when the board shall receive a notice from the city collector that the rates and charges for water supplied to any estate have remained unpaid for 60 days after the due date. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-225. - Wasting water prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to allow the waste of water. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-226. - Procedure in case of excessive use or waste of water. 
(a)  The board of water commissioners is authorized to impose charges for excessive use and to prohibit waste of water which, in the opinion of the board of water commissioners, the water system cannot supply to the general public. 
(b)  The owner, or the agent of the owner, or the tenant who is responsible for any premises where a waste of water occurs for the first time in a calendar year, shall be given a written warning. In case of a subsequent waste, the fine, penalty or charge shall be $50.00. Each calendar day of waste shall be subject to a separate fine, penalty or charge. The board may respond to chronic waste of water by restricting the flow of water to the premises. The board is authorized to achieve noncriminal dispositions of violations of this section and other ordinances or regulations regarding the public water supply pursuant to M.G.L.A. c. 40,  21D, or other lawful authority. Unpaid charges shall be added to water bills and, together with interest and costs, shall constitute a lien against the premises pursuant to M.G.L.A. c. 40,  42D, or other lawful authority. The employees of the board of water commissioners and the employees of the police department are authorized to enforce this section by initiating water charges or noncriminal penalties. The police officers of the police department are authorized to initiate enforcement of this section by fines imposed by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-227. - Restriction on use of water by hose, fountain, etc. 
    The board of water commissioners shall restrict the use of water by hoses, fountains and otherwise, as it may deem necessary. For violation of such restrictions, the occupant of the premises shall be liable to have the water shut offto the premises, and shall be liable for the penalties imposed in the preceding section for waste or improper use of water. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-228. - Abatement of water rates-Generally. 
    The board of water commissioners may make abatements in water and sewer rates in all proper cases. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-229. - Same-Vacancy or nonuse. 
    When any abatement of any water rate on account of vacancy or nonuse of water is desired, notice thereof must be given to the board of water commissioners. The water shall then be shut off by an employee of the board, and an abatement made. No abatement or rebate shall be made for a less term or period than three months of any particular six-month period for which bills are rendered. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-230. - Use of seal locks. 
    When water service is cut off, seal locks as may be prescribed by the board of water commissioners may be placed upon faucets in tenements connected with other tenements in such fashion that they cannot be separately shut off in the street. Such seal locks shall not be put on any house that can be so shut off, except for particular fixtures. The charge for putting on such seal locks shall be established by the board. Such seal locks shall not be taken off by anyone except an employee of the board, on penalty of forfeiture of all claim for abatements, and of having the water shut off from the premises. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-231. - Alteration in pipes or fixtures resulting in increased consumption; permit required. 
    No alteration in any water pipe or water fixture which increases the consumption of water shall be made without giving notice to the board of water commissioners, and obtaining a permit from such board. No plumber or other person shall make any such alteration in or addition to a water pipe or fixture except under such permit and then only in accordance therewith. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-232. - Right of entry. 
    The board of water commissioners, or any authorized agent of the board, may enter the premises of any water taken to examine the quantity of water used, the fixtures, or the manner of use, or to shut off the water for nonpayment of rates or for violation of any board rules and regulations, or the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-233. - No claims allowed for damages caused when water is shut off to make extensions, etc. 
    No claims shall be allowed for lack of water or damages caused by shutting off the water in the main pipes to make extensions, connections, or for any other reason found necessary by the board of water commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
Sec. 18-234. - Concealing purpose of water use. 
    There shall be no concealment of the purpose for which water is used. 
(Ord. No. 1623, 4-2-15) 
APPENDIX A - RULES OF COUNCIL[1] 
Footnotes:

No. 885, adopted Feb. 2, 1984; Ord. No. 981, adopted Sept. 1, 1988; Ord. No. 1033, adopted March 1, 1990; Ord. No. 1449, adopted April 24, 2007. 
Cross reference- City council,  2-36 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - ORGANIZATION; MEETINGS; PROCEDURE 

Sec. 1. - Election of president. 
(a)  One of the members of the council shall be elected by the council as its president at the first meeting in January and shall serve until the first meeting in January next following or until his successor be elected. Candidates for president shall be nominated by any member of the council. The city council president shall be elected by roll call vote of the majority of the entire membership of the council sworn to office. 
(b)  A sitting president may be removed upon a two-thirds vote of the council. The vote to remove may be initiated by any member of the council by motion to rescind the election of the president. Advance notice of such a vote shall be provided to the public in conformity with the requirements of section 21 of chapter 30A of the General Laws (Open Meeting Law). 
(c)  In the event that the motion to rescind is adopted, the floor shall be open to nominations for president and the office shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as is used in the election of the president at the first meeting in January. 
Sec. 2. - Quorum. 
    At all meetings of the council, a majority shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. Whenever a measure may be adopted by majority vote, the affirmative vote of a majority of the entire membership of the council shall be necessary to adopt the motion, ordinance, resolution or other measure unless otherwise specifically so stated. 
Sec. 3. - Duties of the president. 
(a)  The president of the council shall take the chair at the hour appointed for the meeting. In the absence of the president, a president pro tempore shall be chosen. He shall have the duties and powers of the president as presiding officer at the meeting for which he is elected and no others. The president pro tempore shall be nominated and nominations seconded. The city council president pro tempore shall be elected by a majority with a roll call vote. 
(b)  The council president shall serve as presiding officer of the meetings of the council and shall assume the chair at the hour set by ordinance. As presiding officer the president shall ascertain that a quorum is present, shall call the meeting to order, and shall request the reading of the record of the preceding meeting. He shall conduct the meeting in accordance with the order of business as required by Rules of Council and the agenda, subject to such change in order as may be allowed under council rules. He shall recognize members who are entitled to the floor. He shall state such measures as come before the council, as necessary stating the number of votes needed for passage, and shall put to vote such measures as require a vote. He shall enforce the rules relating to debate and decide questions of order as set forth in council rules, subject to such right of appeal as contained therein. He shall declare the meeting adjourned upon the conclusion of business when the council so votes. 
(c)  The president shall refrain from debate while presiding. If the president desires to speak on an issue he or she must vacate the chair and select a president pro tempore to preside. 
(d)  Upon his election in January, the president shall appoint the standing committees of the council. The president shall assign seating or designate a methodology for assigning seats to the other members of the council. 
    The president shall appoint such ad hoc committees of the members as the council votes to create. The president shall have the power to create and appoint a special advisory committee by a majority vote of the city council. The special advisory committee shall terminate after one year unless extended by a majority vote of the city council. The president shall have the power to fill a vacancy on a committee whenever a vacancy arises. 
(e)  The president shall preside over all public hearings that are required to be conducted by the city council and, for such purposes, shall have, in addition to the duties and powers enumerated at subsection (b), above, such other duties and powers as are required by law, ordinance or the Rules of Council. 
(f)  The president shall have the authority to authenticate by his signature, when necessary, all acts, measures, and proceedings of the council. 
Sec. 4. - Order of business. 
    At every regular meeting of the council the order of business shall be as follows unless changed by a motion and second to suspend the rules and with a majority vote to change the order. 
(1)  Pledge of Allegiance. 
(2)  Reading of the record of the previous meeting. 
(3)  Public participation. 
(4)  Communications from the mayor. 
(5)  Communications and reports from city officers. 
(6)  Presentation of petitions, remonstrances and other papers. 
(7)  Reports of committees. 
(8)  Unfinished business of preceding meetings. 
(9)  Motions, orders or resolutions. 
Sec. 5. - Business to be considered at council meetings to be presented to clerk. 
    No business shall be considered by the city council at any regular meeting, unless the same shall have been presented to the clerk of the council in writing no later than the close of business of the city clerk's office on the Monday preceding the next regular meeting. In the event that Monday is a holiday, then the time shall be extended until Noon on the Tuesday preceding the next regular meeting. All requests, information, or notices must be submitted electronically to the clerk of the council unless the presenter indicates in writing that they are unable to adhere to this requirement. Such documents as are submitted shall be submitted in accordance with the City Clerk's Acceptable Electronic Document Specifications in use at the time of submission. 
Sec. 6. - Papers addressed to council. 
    All papers addressed to the council shall be presented by the president or by some member of the council, and they shall be acted upon in the order in which they are presented, unless the council shall otherwise direct. 
Sec. 7. - Reserved. 
Sec. 8. - Order of submission of questions. 
    The president or president pro tempore of council shall submit all questions in the order in which they are moved, unless the subsequent motion shall be previous in its nature; except, that in naming sums and fixing times, the largest sum and the longest time shall be first put. 
Sec. 9. - Motions to be read by presiding officer; withdrawal. 
    After a motion is stated, or read by the president or president pro tempore of the council, it shall be deemed to be in possession of the council, and shall be disposed of by vote; but the mover may withdraw it by unanimous consent at any time before a decision of amendment to the motion or vote on the main motion itself. 
Sec. 10. - Procedures when question is under debate; form of putting previous question. 
(a)  When a question is under debate, the president or president pro tempore of the council shall receive no motion but to adjourn, to lay on the table, the previous question, to postpone indefinitely, to postpone to a day certain, to commit or amend, to close debate, which several motions shall have precedence in the above order, and the first three shall be decided without debate. 
(b)  The previous question shall be put in the following form: "Shall the main question be now put?" and all further amendments or debates of the main question shall be suspended until the previous question is decided. A motion to strike out the enacting clause of an ordinance shall be equivalent to a motion to postpone indefinitely. 
(c)  The president or president pro tempore shall declare all votes. If the vote is questioned by any member, the president or any member may, without permitting further debate upon the question, require a review of the votes by a roll call. 
Sec. 11. - Procedure when multiple members seek recognition at the same time. 
    When two or more members seek recognition at the same time, the president or president pro tempore shall signal who is entitled to the floor. 
Sec. 12. - Reconsideration of matters. 
(a)  When a vote has passed, except for adjournment or to lay on the table, any member voting with the prevailing side may move a reconsideration, to be acted upon at the same meeting. Any member voting with the side that did not prevail may move a reconsideration, to be acted upon at the next meeting, which latter motion shall have priority, if made before the motion first mentioned shall have been decided. 
(b)  Except in accordance with the procedure specified at subsection (a), a declared motion may be considered only once. 
Sec. 13. - Duties of clerk generally; absence. 
(a)  Subject to subsection (b), the clerk shall attend all regular meetings of the council, and all special meetings of the council, but shall not be required to attend committee meetings except when the council convenes as a committee of the whole. The clerk shall keep the records of all meetings the clerk is required to attend and the clerk shall record the names of the members present. The clerk shall have the care and custody of the city records and of all documents, maps, plans and papers, respecting the care and custody of which no other provisions are made. The clerk shall maintain and keep on file all approved minutes of committees and make the minutes available for review by the public once received from a committee. The clerk shall maintain an accurate written list of the matters referred to each committee which shall include dates of referral and disposition. A copy of the list shall be available to any member upon reasonable request and to the public as required by law. 
(b)  The city clerk shall designate an employee within the office of the city clerk to serve as clerk of the council pro tempore to perform the functions of clerk of the council at any meeting of the council for which the attendance of the clerk is required but which, due to temporary disability or other reason, the clerk is unable to attend. In the absence of the city clerk or the city clerk's designee, the council shall elect, as its first order of business, after nominations from the floor, one of its members to serve as clerk pro tempore. 
(c)  The clerk shall prepare for each member at such meeting a statement of the business to be transacted, to which shall be added a list of matters laid on the table or postponed to a day certain. 
Sec. 14. - Duty of clerk in absence of president. 
    In the absence of the president, the clerk shall call the council to order, receive nominations, and preside until a president pro tempore shall be elected. 
Sec. 15. - Manner of addressing council. 
    When any member seeks to speak, the member shall make that desire known by raising his hand and, upon recognition by the president, the member shall respectfully address the president from his seat and confine his comments to the question under debate while avoiding commenting upon personalities. 
Sec. 16. - Manner of addressing members in debate. 
    Members shall refer to each other in respectful terms that may include the councilors title, name, or place he occupies or such other designations as may be intelligible and respectful. 
Sec. 17. - Interrupting members speaking; calling member to order, etc. 
    No member speaking shall be interrupted by another, unless by a call to order or to correct a mistake. If any member, in speaking or otherwise, transgresses the rules of the council, the president shall, or any member may, call him to order. A member called to order shall thereupon immediately yield the floor and cease speaking unless permitted to explain by the president. Any question asked of a member shall be asked through the president. 
Sec. 18. - Speaking more than twice to same question. 
    No member shall speak more than twice to the same question, or more than once until other members choosing to speak shall have spoken, or more than five minutes at each time, without obtaining leave of the council. 
Sec. 19. - When motion reduced to writing. 
    A motion shall be reduced to writing if the president directs or any member requests it. In the event that a member objects, the president shall put the question of whether the motion shall be reduced to writing and the request shall be required if so voted by a majority vote. 
Sec. 20. - Taking roll-call vote; order of voting. 
(a)  A roll-call shall be taken on any question or motion upon the request of one of the members present. When the president puts the question, a member may, by point of order to be ruled upon by the president, seek to delay putting the question to allow additional debate in accordance with council rules. If the president declines to extend debate, the member having raised the point of order may promptly call for a vote of the members by roll-call and a majority vote shall decide whether to end or extend debate. 
(b)  In all cases where a vote by roll call is requested, or otherwise required by law, it shall proceed in the following manner: The clerk shall call the name of each member present by a rotating alphabetical order which shall begin with the first vote of the first meeting of the calendar year, that is, the vote to elect the council president. The first to vote shall be the first in alphabetical order by surname and thereafter at the next meeting with the second surname in alphabetical order beginning the vote, continuing through the alphabet at each meeting. 
Sec. 21. - Members voting or serving where private rights concerned. 
    No member shall vote or serve on any committee on any questions where his private right is immediately concerned distinct from the public interest. Each city councilor must adhere to the conflict of interest law as specified in chapter 268A of the General Laws. 
Sec. 22. - All members to vote; exception. 
    Every member who is present, including the president, when a question is put, where he is not excluded by interest, shall vote unless the council, for special reason, excuses him. The abstaining member must state his reason for abstention. Application to be so excused shall be made before the vote is taken and shall be decided without debate. 
Sec. 23. - Tie vote. 
    In case of a tie vote, the matter shall fail. 
Sec. 24. - Reserved. 
Sec. 25. - Action on nominations made by mayor. 
    Nominations made by the mayor shall not be acted upon at the meeting in which they are received but may be acted upon at any subsequent meeting, regular or special. 
Sec. 26. - Committees to be appointed by president; chairman. 
    In accordance with Section 3, all committees shall be appointed by the president. The member first named to a committee, whether standing, ad hoc or special advisory, shall be the chairman. 
Sec. 27. - Standing committees enumerated; committee quorum. 
(a)  There shall be appointed by the president the following standing committees: 
(1)  Finance committee-Consisting of three or five councilors whose duties and responsibilities shall include the investigation of all matters concerning municipal finance and administration of financial affairs and to work in conjunction with such member as appointed by the president to serve as liaison to the city auditor, city treasurer, city collector, and assessing department. The finance committee shall have initial jurisdiction over the annual city budget and the setting of the property tax rate. 
(2)  Legislative and ordinance committee-Consisting of three or five councilors whose duties and responsibilities shall include investigation and recommendation on all resolutions, orders, and ordinances. This committee shall have initial jurisdiction over legislation and resolutions proposed by the Commonwealth or the United States government. 
(3)  City property and facilities committee-Consisting of three councilors whose duties and responsibilities shall include the investigation and report on all matters coming before the city council concerning city property, engineering, and gas and electric facilities. This committee shall work in conjunction with such member as appointed by the president to serve as liaison to the board of public works and the municipal light board. This committee shall have initial jurisdiction over street acceptances, abandonments, and discontinuances. 
(4)  Public health and safety committee-Consisting of three councilors whose duties and responsibilities shall include the investigation and report on all matters coming before the city council concerning public health, public safety (fire, police, and emergency management), human services, traffic, streets, highways, sidewalks, public transportation and street-lighting. 
(5)  License committee-Consisting of three councilors whose duties and responsibilities shall include the investigation and recommendation of all applications for licenses and permits submitted to the city council. 
(6)  Zoning, planning and development committee-Consisting of three councilors whose duties and responsibilities shall include the investigation and report on all matters coming before the city council concerning all proposed zoning changes within the city. This committee shall work in conjunction with such member as appointed by the president to serve as liaison to the planning board, department of planning and community development, development and industrial commission, and the industrial development and financing authority. The committee shall also submit a report on any new proposals concerning industrial development. This committee shall have initial jurisdiction over all applications for zoning changes. 
(7)  Personnel action committee-Consisting of three councilors whose duties and responsibilities shall include the investigation and recommendation on all appointments submitted to the city council. 
(8)  Natural resources committee-Consisting of three councilors whose duties and responsibilities shall include the investigation and report on all matters coming before the city council concerning the preservation and enhancement of all natural resources including, but not limited to, issues such as water, sewers and sewage treatment facilities, aquifer protection, and solid waste disposal. This committee shall work in conjunction with such member as appointed by the president to serve as liaison to the conservation commission. This committee shall have initial jurisdiction over the setting of sewer rates. 
(9)  Governmental relations committee-Consisting of three councilors whose duties and responsibilities shall include the investigation and report on all matters coming before the city council concerning computer planning and to work in conjunction with such member as appointed by the president to serve as the liaison to the park and recreation commission, airport commission, cultural council, school committee, chamber of commerce, the Massachusetts Municipal Association and such other municipal boards and officers, and civic organizations, not specifically assigned to another committee. This committee will have initial jurisdiction relative to proposals from adjoining communities or districts. 
(10)  Long range financial overview committee-Consisting of the president of the council, a member of the finance committee and one to three additional members as appointed by the president. The duties of the committee will be to review long term financial strategic plans, including five-year projections of revenues and expenses, as well as long-term liabilities of the city. 
(b)  A majority of the members of a committee shall be a quorum to transact business. A measure shall be considered as recommended upon the vote of a majority of the committee members present and voting. 
Sec. 28. - Public participation. 
    The following rules shall apply to public participation: 
(a)  Public participation is limited to 15 minutes. This time limit may be extended upon motion made, seconded and voted by a majority. 
(b)  Each person speaking during public participation is limited to one three-minute presentation unless, upon motion made, seconded and voted by a majority, the person is allowed a second presentation or is voted an extension of the time limit. 
(c)  Public participation is not suitable to express opinions regarding, or to state complaints or charges against, a named public officer, employee, staff member or any individual if the opinion, complaint or charge involves the competence, character, reputation, physical or mental health of that individual. Participants are expected to conduct themselves in an appropriate manner, respectful of the opinions of others that may be contrary to their own. 
(d)  Public participation shall not be allowed for matters which are, or have been, the subject of a public hearing before the council. 
(e)  Failure to adhere to this rule, or to comply with an admonishment from the president, shall be grounds for forfeiture of the right to address the council. 
(f)  Council business shall not be conducted by the members during public participation. 
Sec. 29. - Reserved. 
Sec. 30. - Reserved. 
Sec. 31. - Committee reports. 
(a)  Each committee shall be required to make a report to the council on each item as is referred to it within 90 days of the initial referral. Thereafter, the item shall be the subject of a committee report no less frequently than once each 90 days until action is taken by the full council. 
(b)  Upon the expiration of ninety days from the date of an initial referral of an item to a committee, any member may bring a motion to the floor seeking to recall from that committee the item that has previously been referred thereto and, upon an affirmative vote by a majority of the members, the item shall be on the floor for consideration by the full council. 
Sec. 32. - Rejection of measures. 
    When any question has been finally rejected, no measure substantially the same shall be introduced by any member during the same calendar year. 
Sec. 33. - Suspension, amendment or repeal of rules or orders. 
    Except as specified at Section 4, no standing rule or order of the council shall be suspended unless three-fourths of the members present shall consent thereto; nor shall any rule or order be repealed or amended without at least one day's notice being given of the motion thereof, nor unless a majority of the entire council shall concur therein. 
Sec. 34. - Determination of procedure in the absence of Council Rule. 
    In the absence of a rule that determines the proper course of parliamentary procedure for a matter under consideration, the president shall declare the procedure. However, by point of order promptly made, any member may raise the question as to the proper procedure and the president shall refer the question of the proper procedure to the judgment of the members. In the course of debate, any member may reference the text of "Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised" but said text shall not be determinative, the question to be decided by majority vote. 
ARTICLE II. - ORDINANCES, ORDERS AND RESOLUTIONS 

Sec. 35. - Stages of passage of ordinances. 
(a)  Subject to the exception as set forth herein, each proposed ordinance shall pass through the following stages before it shall be considered as having received the final action of the council: introduction and a first reading in full by the clerk; passage by vote to a second reading at the next regular meeting, at which time it shall again receive a reading in full and be in order for final action. It shall then be voted upon, and if approved by a majority of all members of the council, be accepted. An ordinance proposed as an emergency measure in accordance with the terms of the City Charter shall follow the foregoing process but may be finally passed on the date that it is introduced consistent with City Charter. 
(b)  Every proposed ordinance or loan order, except an emergency measure, shall, at least ten days before its final passage, be published as required by the City Charter and by such additional means as may be required by Council Rule. An emergency ordinance passed upon the date it is introduced shall be published on the earliest practicable date using the means required by the City Charter and by such additional means as may be required by Council Rule. 
Sec. 36. - Reading by title; final vote to be by roll-call. 
(a)  By unanimous consent the second reading of an ordinance, order, or vote may be by title only. If the proposed measure has been laid before the members in printed or electronic form, the council may, by vote, direct the reading to be by title only at any of its readings. 
(b)  The vote for final passage of an ordinance shall be by roll-call. 
Sec. 37. - Persons requesting appropriation ordinances etc, to make statement. 
    No measure relative to the appropriation of money shall be passed at the meeting of the council at which it is first presented unless the mayor or head of the department making such request shall appear in person and publicly state the reason for such action and it is adopted by unanimous consent as specified in City Charter. 
Sec. 38. - Majority vote required on certain financial measures, granting of rights-of-way. 
(a)  In case any order, resolution or vote involves the borrowing, appropriation or expenditure of money in an amount that may exceed $2,000.00, or the laying of a special tax assessment, or the granting to a person or corporation of any right in, over or under any street or other public ground of the city, the affirmative vote of the majority of all the members of the council shall be necessary for its passage. Every such order, resolution or vote shall be read twice, with an interval of at least ten days between the two readings, before being finally passed, and the vote on the final passage shall be by roll call; provided, however, that upon and after the written recommendation of the mayor, the city council may pass such order, resolution or vote upon the same day by a roll-call vote, with two-thirds of the members of the entire council voting in the affirmative. 
(b)  The provisions of chapter 719 of the Acts of 1913 and the amendments thereof relating to incurring debts for loans, so far as they apply to the necessity of a two-thirds vote of all members of the council, and the taking of such vote by roll-call, shall be observed. 
Sec. 39. - Readings required for orders and resolutions. 
(a)  All orders shall, unless rejected, have two readings, after each of which debate shall be in order, and they shall be put on their passage. All resolutions, except those resolutions contained in Section 38, shall require only one reading, and they shall then be put on their passage. 
(b)  No order or resolution imposing penalties, or authorizing a loan or the expenditures of money, shall have more than one reading on the same day, but this rule shall not apply to an order to print a document. 
Sec. 40. - Preparation and preservation of copies of ordinances. 
    After an ordinance shall have been passed, a written or printed copy shall be prepared by or under the direction of the clerk and, having been compared by the clerk with the original, the same shall be signed by the mayor and city clerk or, the absence of the mayor, by the president of the council and the same shall be preserved by the clerk as an official record of the city. The city clerk shall, as soon as reasonably possible after securing the necessary signatures, cause the text of the ordinance to be available to the public via access through the City of Westfield website. 
Sec. 41. - Copies of ordinances, orders and resolutions to be provided to members prior to second reading. 
    Typewritten or printed copies of ordinances, orders and resolutions shall be provided to the members of the council either in hard copy form or via email prior to a second reading.

CODE COMPARATIVE TABLE ORDINANCES 
This table gives the location within this Code of those ordinances adopted since the 1971 Code, as updated through December 15, 1977, which are included herein. Ordinances adopted prior to such date were incorporated into the 1971 Code, as supplemented. This table contains some ordinances which precede December 15, 1977, but which were never included in the 1971 Code, as supplemented, for various reasons. Ordinances adopted since December 15, 1977, and not listed herein, have been omitted as repealed, superseded or not of a general and permanent nature.
